reviewText:
Let me preface this by saying this game is definitely not for everyone. The story is terrible imo, and there is lack of documentation about the ruleset within the game. So good luck if you mess up your build early in the game (some talents and spells are useless). But, if you can get around those two factors, there is a nice TBRPG here.

Blackguards strength is easily its combat. Difficulty of encounters is not determined by the number of enemies nor the amount of hp they have but by the types of enemies and the environmental hazards on the map. Hell, even increasing the difficulty actually makes the AI smarter instead of having cheap mechanics like OHKOs.

For a first time RPG developer, Daedalic did a suprisingly good job. Unfortunately, Daedelic didn't just decide to make a better Blackguards 1 when making the sequel.

reviewText:
SUMMARY: 8 stars out of 10.  A solid and highly enjoyable RPG!

PROLOGUE: I show as having 88 hours playing this game, as of this review.  I probably actually was playing for 80 hours of that, for ONE playthrough. I am methodical and slow, so most of you whippersnappers who like to cut to the chase will likely finish in 40 hours or less.  I saw a lot of complaints about this game having spikes of frustratingly high difficulty, so I played the EASY/NOVICE setting, which I believe gives more Adventure Points (AP) than the other settings.  In retrospect, I can understand the complaints; but I never had that problem, maybe because of the easy setting, maybe for the most part because I pushed off what I suspected would be the tougher fights until I had more skills under my party's belts.  I ended the game with 1300 ducats (enough to ditch EVERYTHING the party needed and buy it all back again), lots of poisons, potions, provisions, projectiles, traps, and other stuff I never seemed to have the need to use.  I used one potion, and that in the second to last battle.  Perhaps on NORMAL difficulty I would have needed more...

REVIEW:  This game has a main storyline which is fairly linear, but the available sidequests (and locations they open) make it feel less so.  The RPG character development system is versatile and refreshing: You can mold your characters by earning and using AP to buy levels in any of a myriad of basic traits, talents, weapon talents, special abilities, and (for magic users) spells.  You get AP by fighting battles and completing quests.  You do not get enough AP to turn your characters into super heros; but, if you do most of the sidequests, you will get enough to make them excellent in their chosen specialty (magic, melee, ranged) and solid in a second specialty and/or support.  One word of caution: this is not the game for those who want to destroy waves of hapless foes with giant fire or frost balls.  Using magic to buff teammates (and/or debuff enemies) will carry the day.

There are approximately 180 fights available in the game, for those who wish to seek them all out, with plenty of tactical variety and some light in-fight" puzzle solving.  In all but a few cases
date: the game clues you in to what is needed to make a fight easier.  For those few where they fall short
recommended: there is the internet: I used it about six times.  There were about three fights I elected to replay because I failed or did not like the outcome.  All in all
hoursPlayed: I found the combat to be satisfying.\n\nSome have complained of running out of ammo (the shops do not re-stock arrows and bolts); but I ran two archers and one crossbow
voteText: and did not come close to running out.  I think someone relied too heavily on "triple shot" and "rain of arrows
helpfulPercent:
which skills none of my characters learned.

The storyline is nothing to write home about; and the ending cutscenes/wrap-up is lackluster.  But the character voice acting, approriate interjection of humor, and plot intrigue that is played out was, in my opinion, quite well done.

Replay value is modest.  The plot twists and intrigue are a lot of what pulled me along the first time.  Your party characters are a mandatory set of (up to) five characters, only one of which you get to roll from scratch, and even HIM not entirely (name, gender and appearance are all set for you).  After almost 90 hours on record for my first run, another one (this time on NORMAL) will have to wait until I am up for it.  But, for the pittance I paid for the game (got it on a deep, DEEP discount), one run was overwhemingly worth the price!

EPILOGUE / HINTS (which some might consider slightly spoilerish, but I will not give away plot.)
-- Screw the game's advice:  Roll your own character from scratch the first time.  It is almost impossible to fail if you buy in as a magic user and start him out good at SOMETHING.
-- Take magic, unless you are dead set on a heavy melee fighter.  the 500 AP cost might seem like a lot, but it is a pittance over the course of the game, compared to the advantages it gives.
-- Continuing this line of thought, a dedicated heavy melee fighter is probably not the best choice, as you will eventually end up having two excellent ones foisted upon you.  You will be much better served with a magic buffer/healer who is good at bows.
-- All your magic users should be good with staffs, or possibly daggers.
-- Study spells carefully before trying to achieve high ranks in them.  For most spells, level 4 is not worth the cost.
-- Hammer Blow (HB), coupled with level 3 Standfast Catlike" buff is OP.
-- The level 3 buff "Move like Lightning" (or some name llike that) is OP.
-- A fighter simultaneously buffed with level 3 Lightning and Standfast

reviewText:
Have you ever played Dungeons and Dragons with a Dungeon Master that absolutely hates you? Do you like campaigns in which dialogue options are almost meaningless and the plot is confusing? Well if you haven't, Blackguards can fill that void for you.

The plot isn't bad. It captured my attention fairly early and has some nice twists in it. The main focus of this game, however, is the combat system. I love the combat in this game. Blackguards uses a version of tabletop rules to fuel its combat. There are even simulated dice rolls for damage and hit chance. Unfortunately, (or fortunately depending) pretty much every dialogue option leads to some sort of cliche combat. Very rarely is there a non-combat solution to anything.

The character creation is pretty cool also. There are two modes; basic and advanced. The creation is very open and is manipulated by AP (adventure points (I think)). Using these points (earned from combat and completion of quests), you can add talents, special abilities, spells, and basic attributes to your character, none being restricted to your character (except spells in some cases).

Unfortunately, this game does have some downsides. Some of the encounters are downright frustrating and (at least for me), very difficult. A number of times I've had to walk away from the game or take a break. These particular encounters seem to me generated specifically to be hard and not at all story oriented. I won't go into much detail about them so I don't spoil the fun" for you. On the plus side however
date: there is no penalty for losing as the game forces you to keep trying unless you load a previous save before the encounter.\n\nThe graphics are actually quite nice and are better than I expected. The layout for combat is excellent
recommended: using hex-tiles and a partially destructible environment. The cities however seem more like pretty backdrops for my character sheets and are fairly dull.\n\nI would recommend this game if you are an avid tabletop gamer looking for your D&D fix
hoursPlayed: or someone who appreciates tabletop games.\n\n7.5/10"

reviewText:
Fantasy Adventure with a dark and mature story eh? Ummm... more like a very PG Fantasy Adventure.

Leading a band of misfits, scoundrels, criminals, outcasts, etc. sounded pretty cool, but that was far far from the case when I actually started to get moving along in the game. Blackguards in title and story is very ho-hum and has you playing the hero at almost every turn doing errands for NPCs... not really what I was expecting given how the store page spins the hype around it. Sure there are a few choice options that cater to your supposed anti-heroism but they are few and far between.

True to its billing I did clock in completing the game in about 40 hours. I liked the game for what it was (i've played better/worse turn based RPGs) and will most likely play it again with a different hero build but I'm not really in any rush to do so.

reviewText:
Blackguards is a turn-based strategy game with deep RPG elements based on the popular German pen and paper RPG The Dark Eye. You assume the role of your own custom character who is accused of killing the princess in the opening cinematic. Your only choice is to run away, assemble a cast of shady characters such as the suave mage Zurbaran, the feisty dwarf Naurim and the tribal warrior Takate. The storytelling and the characters are solid, but they really don’t stand out in any significant way, for the most part it really feels like a poor man’s BioWare story.

What makes Blackguards truly shine are its great combat system and wonderful game world. The combat system is hex based and may at first remind you of fantasy turn-based strategy games such as Heroes of Might and Magic or King’s Bounty. In reality, it’s more like a combination of Disciples III and Neverwinter Nights, a heavy mixture of classic turn-based strategy and role-playing philosophy. The fantastic thing about the combat system is that every single battlefield is completely unique. Not only are they all different from a visual standpoint, but they are all set up differently as well. Sometimes you’re surrounded, sometimes you have multiple goals, sometimes you have to defend something. You can also use the environment to your advantage. Cut the rope to make the heavy wooden chandelier fall on your foes or burn down the walkway spiderwebs causing deadly poisonous spiders fall to their doom.

Another big thing different from usual turn-based strategy games is that you’re not building an army, you have a party of up to five characters. As you progress through the game, you acquire adventure points which you can use to upgrade your characters in a wide variety of attributes, abilities, spells, talents and weapon talents. It’s a really robust system that allows for truly deep customization and experimentation. The only negative thing is that the game assumes that you’re familiar with The Dark Eye ruleset when in reality you will need some time to really figure it out.

The other problem stemming from the use of The Dark Eye ruleset is that almost any attack can be a hit or miss. Because the game is really tough and the opening battles are rather grueling, it can be really frustrating missing a 95% attack. There are ways to upgrade your characters to offset this, but again, this will take some time to figure out as the game doesn’t really explain much of anything. This can cause some really ugly bouts of frustration and anger, but it’s not a deal breaker.

The vast majority of the gameplay is in the battles. Apart from that, you’ll be using a lovely 2D map to travel from location to location. Towns are represented with a single screen depicting various points of interest such as shops, healers, blacksmiths and quests. The graphics are absolutely beautiful, the wonderful art style is sort of a mixture between fantasy, medieval Spain and 16th century Caribbean which is actually seldom seen in games. The accompanying soundtrack reflects that as well and fits the game very well. However, the animations aren’t that great and the voice work, while mostly solid, can be a bit cringe-worthy at times.

Blackguards is a hardcore game for hardcore gamers and it is completely unapologetic about it. So be prepared for some truly grueling stuff and a steep learning curve. The great thing is, it’s absolutely worth playing thanks to the great combat system, deep RPG elements and a wonderful game world.

8 OUT OF 10 (GREAT)

reviewText:
Very oldschool-ish RPG with turn-based fights, rich dialogues and wide character advancement options.
Pros:
1. RNG (it makes the fights so challenging)
2. Dialogues with humor and consequences
3. Rather advanced character development system with lots of attributes, talents and special skills
4. Plot twists
Cons:
1. RNG (when it stops being fun it becomes so annoying you will sometimes hate it)
2. Not so many useful spells
3. Crappy loot system (traders don't refresh their inventories, lots of similar useless weapons, limited ammunition supply, mage armor almost non-existent)
4. Buggy achievements
Still highly recommended to any RPG fan.

reviewText:
Presupposition : I recommend preceding with extreme prejudice in regards to playing this game.

I want to tell you I really enjoyed this game. I want to tell you the story is fantastic. Filled with all the ups and downs of great storytelling. I want to tell you the mechanics are fun, challenging and rewarding. I want to, I really do.

What I will tell you though, is that music is very atmospheric and enjoyable. I found the characters likable and humorous with the exception of Aurelia. They all were perhaps a bit over the top in most aspects of their personality. However, that's what makes them a character isn't it?

Turn based strategy games are slow affairs to begin with for obvious reasons. This one however, in specific battles, has more enemies than can fit on the screen. Some examples, Slugs (Morfus) Zombies, skeletons, other dead things that move incredibly slowly. And you have to watch each one take their horrifically slow turns. Perhaps there was a way to skip this or have it resolve faster, however I was unable to find such amenities.

The tactics leave something to be desired as well. I don't really have a real complaint about them just that they don't feel rewarding. It doesn't feel you've out smarted anyone or overcome some great obstacle. It just feels like you've done your due diligence. So the game decides to let you win now.

I did experience “the feels” when Niam is killed for little to no reason. But I can't help but question the anti-drug undertone.

This is possibly one of my least favorite games I've ever completed. (Completed being defined as credits are rolling) I liked it enough to finish, yet I can only truly recommend if you absolutely love turn based games.

reviewText:
I thoroughly enjoy Daedalic Entertainment's point-and-click adventure games so when I heard that they would be making a turn-based RPG I was super pumped.  I love the Dark Eye world and the gritty fantasy found therein and I feel that this game does not disappoint.

PROS

1) THE CHARACTERS! I adored the main characters and genuinely felt that each line of dialogue between them was solid gold.  Every one of them had a great personality and contributed to the overall value of this game a great deal.

2) The Dialogue and Story: You can take it or leave it but I what I came across I enjoyed.  While it is true that the story is linear and doing side-missions does nothing but help you grind this was never an issue for me.  I liked the story and the direction it was taken.  You're a bad guy doing bad things for the right reasons and it is not often to come across something that does this trope well.  The game does a great job of putting you into the antihero" mentality.

3) Combat: This game does not hold your hand.  You WILL redo fights
recommended: and unless you know how to build your stats and abilities you WILL fall behind but as long as you play your hand correctly you will always be able to win the next fight.  Similar to older iterations of D&D (which Die Schwarze Auge/The Dark Eye is the German equivalent of more or less) there are weapon AND damage types to consider.  Knowing what kind of weapons and what kind of damage types to use are crucial against certain enemies.  For example
hoursPlayed: DON'T USE PIERCING AGAINST THE UNDEAD!  They are completely immune to anything that doesn't impart massive physical trauma to their skeleton like slashing or bashing weapons would.  Some enemies are immune to poison

It will be trial and error to figure this out but this is also why you can equip each character with three different weapon load-outs which you can cycle through in combat so as to avoid being harmless to a specific enemy. reviewText: First time I played this through, I got myself stuck in a position where it was impossible to proceed.  I'd just get wiped over and over again in the late game. reviewText:
Let's start with character creation; You seem to have a lot of choices, but most of these are just number-crunching to get the few choices that matter. Although even those are just a numbers game, just bigger numbers. You can also choose your starting equipment, this is pretty neat, if it weren't for the fact that you lose all of your equipment after your first combat.

Speaking of combat, every action you do has a high chance of failing, from casting a spell to setting a trap to swinging a club. The chance to hit or be succesful is made harder by your enemies' defenses. Wait, that's not all, the damage range of your weapons goes from 1-6, 5-10, or 4-12 for example, this damage is further reduced by your enemies' damage reduction %, and flat damage reduction. This means that on top of the abnormally high miss chance(plus dodge and parry chances!), actually dealing damage is stupendously hard. Now imagine most enemies have around the same health as you, 30ish. So what do you do? You wail on the enemies until they fall down, hoping you even hit them. This makes combat feel sluggish, your actions meaningless, and generally make you waste time.

The story? You get to choose which lines are said first.. sometimes. It also appears you get some dialogue options at times. None of these worked, and didn't work the few times I did try them. Perhaps they work later in the game when you have a higher Charisma? Thing is, I maxed my charisma, it wouldn't go higher, so why have those options there at the start anyway? To waste my time? Make me feel like I have a choice? No, this is another kick to the nuts this game gives.

reviewText:
First: Blackguards isn't bad or good.  It's just extremely mediocre.  If you're into D&D alternatives and dig X-Com, it probably won't waste your time.  But I can't recommend it for most people.

The character customization is surprisingly lacking, despite the illusion of choice.  There are twice as many attributes as a D&D system, but they all just sum together to increase your attack, dodge chance, initiative, etc.  There are only a handful of combat abilities to use, so there's not a lot of choice as far stabbing/shooting.  The magic users are more nuanced; there are a ton of spells, each with 4 tiers, so you're constantly weighing the cost/benefit of those.

Combat itself is very similar to X-Com or D&D 4.0: you get either a move and an action, or a double move.  This all occurs on a hex-grid, and most maps have some sort of interactable element to spice it up.  They do an admirable attempt to differentiate the levels, but you will take place in about a billion combat scenarios, so a lot of them inevitably feel repetitive.  You'll probably be skipping side quests by the end out of boredom.

The plot is pretty linear.  There are batches of side quests that open up at various points, but none of them augment the main plot line at all.  It's your typical RPG save my daughter" or "escort my caravan" kind of stuff.  You become enslaved and forced to fight in a gladiatorial arena at one point

reviewText:
At a glance, Blackguards is a fun foray into the turn-based tactical genre. The system is both simple and overly complex at the same time, but it balances out nicely. The graphics and the storyline certainly aren't anything to write home about, but for a turn-based game they are more than acceptable - after all, the real focus of any turn-based strategy game is going to be the combat, not the sparkling wit or crisp graphics.

Unfortunately, the combat is where things really fall apart.

That's not to say that the combat system itself is at fault. It's passable, and roughly analogous to Dungeons & Dragons. The real problem is that many of the set-piece battles are designed to be inherently unfair. Even on the easiest difficulty, you'll often struggle with scenarios that are designed to be one step short of impossible. You'll often find your character(s) stripped of their equipment and forced to use random items that you don't have the skill to use. You'll often find yourself thrown into insane battlefields filled with literally dozens of hidden traps, endless hordes of respawning opponents, or obtuse victory conditions that require you to interact with five or more scattered pieces of scenery. Somewhere along the line, the designers seem to have gotten just a bit too clever about their level designs, inadvertantly making many encounters more frustrating than fun.

Fortunately, the developers made several adjustments as the game went through early release - so if you can power through the first two chapters (Chapter Two is particularly frustrating), then you'll find that the game opens up a good deal. At that point it becomes a much more enjoyable experience, although still occasionally plagued with annoyingly obtuse map design (one optional arena" map can easily take an hour or more to finish due to it's maze-like design and infinitely spawning enemies).

If you're a hardcore strategy gamer
date: then Blackguards is certainly worth buying. For anyone even slightly more casual
hoursPlayed: you should probably give Blackguards a pass."

reviewText:
For all the hype this game received it truly is infuriantingly awful!
The story is trope-ridden and uncompelling, a flaw which is compounded by the lack of any sense of progression due to enemies quickly becoming ridiculously overpowered (don't even get me started on the Iribar lily).
Combining an AP system with the need to locate a highly specific trainer to attain certain special abilities really damages the game, if you save up your AP hoping to find a trainer for a particular you find the enemies outclassing you due to the lack of uninvested points. When even a single missed hit can cost you the battle (which are frequently overly long) it seems counter-productive to have such low hit chances even when the relevant weapon skill is maxed out and complimentary stats are high.
I'm sure if you are a veteran of The Dark Eye, the choice of character build could be optimised such that the battles are easier; on the other hand the highly repetitive battle sequences, lack of character placement pre-battle, dreadful story, and lacklustre town interface probably wouldn't make the game enjoyable.
I was genuinely looking forward to this game heralding a new wave of turn-based/tactical rpgs (of which i am a great fan), but now I am left sincerely hoping the publisher never curses the world with a sequel.
voteText: 18 of 33 people (55%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I don't even know how to explain the lackluster gameplay. Simple put, if you enjoy games where you have to lose battles a dozen times to memorize trap locations, constantly fight unbalanced matches and only like to stick with non-intuitive,  cookie cutter builds, then this game is definitely for you.
If you want to experiment with unique builds, play melee or just want some fun battles and original gameplay, look elsewhere, this really isnt for you.

Not even a couple of hours into the game and I realised that the battle mechanics are absolutely one of the worst i've seen, in over a decade of playing turn based strategy games. It's another perfect example of developers compensating for horrible AI, by overpowering the player.

A few other problems: This isnt tactical, it's nearly impossible to be tactical in this game because the maps are way too simple, if you're looking for XCOM style tactics, this is nowhere close. Most of the obstacles can be shot through and they provide no additional defense(unless of course the enemy is behind them, in which case they will shoot from behind their obstacle and also through yours and still knock you down with an arrow, from the other end of the map), even with 90% hit chance you will constantly miss.

I've never once wanted to give up on a game so fast but I already see no incentive to continue with this game, it's just so boring and unrewarding for the difficulty. I regret buying it, even at the sale price of $15.

Please, for your sake, ignore the steam reviews and do some proper online research before buying this game.

reviewText:
I got this game in a bundle and was just curious to try it, so I first cheked the store page to see if there were good reviews. There weren't, and people was talking about it as too hard.
I agree, the character sheet is very complex and you end up wasting a lot of experience points, but it's not too bad.
I really enjoyed the story and I find that the voice acting is superb, there's a point in the game where you have more than 10 side quests and you really want to go on, but then there's a slow down and it gets quite heavy in the end. I don't think it's too hard, but I don't recommend playing this game at max difficulty, it's balanced enough at normal.
Overall it was a fun game, far from perfection but still enjoyable, I definitely won't play it a second time, but I will play Blackguards 2, which is said to be even better polished. Hope you found my review useful!

reviewText: Great game. I'm an older player. If you like old school D&D themed type of games and turn based combat with quite a few skills spells and stats..... this game is for you. If you want a pew pew own other players in an MMO this game is not for you. The game seems slow to many people because well... it  IS!!! It's supposed to be a kick back and enjoy the world story with fun turn based battles. It may not be the best game ever or anything, I'm not saying that, but it is damn good imo. The dialouge can be pretty damn funny at times and it's a pretty game. The loading screens can be a bit annoying when you are trying to find a particular trainer or whatever so I suggest using a pen and paper if you find yourself forgetting where destinations are. One thing that annoys me a bit is I still have not found anywhere that tells me my AR flat out....and some of the hover overs on new equiptment can be annoying as they are not intuiative... takes a bit to figure out and doesn't need to be that way imo. I'd still give the game a 4.5 out of 5 stars...and it's a lot longer than I expected it to be which pleased me so far. (not finished with the game yet only at the end of chapter 3). I usually don't replay games but I think I will for sure on this one just to mess with stats.

reviewText:
This game is the equivalent of Iron Man 3 - plenty of potential, a winning formula but just didnt pull it off where it mattered.

Let me explain.....
It has a good story that makes you want to invest time to find out what happens to the characters. It has turn based mechanics with lots of flexibility - shall i use the environment to my advantage, shall i switch weapons or shall i just spam the most powerful attack i have (yes. do the latter). Just the WORST thing about the game is when you successfully miss 4 attacks in a row each with a hit chance of 80%. This sort of treachery happens often and really spoils the battle.

The battle map is great and you can easily find your way around the battlefield although in my opinion the user interface is lacking a bit - all the useful buttons are grouped together and are a little bit too small for my liking. You can semi-personalise each character and evolve their skills and attributes to your liking - although unless you want to turn a mage into a bad-boy-brawler (and why the hell would you do that) there isnt that much choice.

All in all it is a better than average game although is only worth buying when on steam sale.

reviewText:
Blackguards Review Overall Score: 6/10

Storyline: (1/2)
+ Fun dialogues to read between characters.
- Bad storyline (I don't see it going anywhere besides a basic story of the advanture itself).

Graphics: (2/2)
+ Well designed character models and gears.
+ Good looking battle maps and towns.

Sounds: (2/2)
+ Voices matching the characters.
+ Good sounds in battlemaps and overall.

Gameplay: (3/4)
+ Easy and basic training progress to let you understand the game rules and mechanics.
+ Main and Side Quests (Each quest is intresting because it gives rewards and you never know who the enemy is and how many there are).
+ Visit each town and meet Blacksmiths/Healers/Merchants etc.. (Inventory/cash is usefull)
- Difficulties: It's good to have 3 level of difficulties but we need to understand the difference between each one because it feels hard even on Easy for a new player in Blackguards.

RolePlay Elements: (4/7)
+ Different Classes (Hunter/Mage/Fighter)
+ Rich variety of equippment (Weapons/Armor Sets/Items to use on A.I/self/enemy)
+ Happy Mage (A full page of spells only for the mage)
- Special Moves for other characters (You're able to unlock them with a trainer.. But I'm reaching 15 hours and I still haven't found this 'trainer' yet.
+ Talents : A sweet bonus in this game which let you upgrade each talent form level 1 to 5 and give you it's special effect [see below]
*Knockdown resistance *Animals/Humans stats detector *Healing Effect * Traps detector and more...
+- Stats : There are good sides and bad sides about the stats because in one hand you can match the stats to your liking
if you want a spellcaster archer or a dual wielding warrior but if you don't know what you upgrade to your character you might have a weaker character than you've expected.
- Equippment stats are a bit clumsy.
- Upgrade Points: It takes more time than it should be for a player to think about where to invest his upgrade points.

Combat: (4/5)
+ Each combat is exciting and makes you eager for the next one.
+ Basic turn-based combat rules/moves but more challenging then other TB games.
+ Usefull Objects : You can throw weapons on the enemy, use/disable traps , use battle objects to move them around or use them against the enemy. You can even hide in the bush from the enemy.
+ Satisfaction : For those 100% players, you will re-do the battle until you get it done the best way you want it to be.
- Frustration : In some battles I felt like my characters are over powered by the enemy. Had to re-try multiply times in different tactics.

To sum it up, I'm enjoying my new Turn Based experience with Blackguards.
It offers an addictive experience throughout the game so I recommend on trying this game if you're an experienced TB gamer.
Don't bother playing this if you're more of a classic TB gamer who doesn't want to focus much on character's stats and RPG elements that might confuse you along the way.


Enjoyment: (6/10)
Repetetive: (2/10)
Replayability (8/10)
Frustraiton (5/10)
Boredom (5/10)

Overall Score: 6/10
* Skip it.
** Not Recommended.
*** Give It A Try.
**** Recommended On Sale.
****** Recommended On Full Price.
Thanks for reading.

reviewText:
Good intro game to the Dark Eye universe.

Positives:
- fun tactical combat
- interesting characters and OK story.
- character customization according to the dark eye rules
- fast traveling from combat to combat, always in action no pointless roaming
- the best part of the game is probably early mid game when you are forced to fight in the arena. It's a nice change of pace.

On the negative side:
- RNG is sometimes really strong, like missing 95% hit chance 3 times in a row
- difficulty spikes, although end game boss was too easy
- low variety in armors for mages
- poisons everywhere

Not an easy game but very fun.
Bought the game around Xmas and spent most of the time efter Xmas playing it.

No crashes or any kind of freezing problems for me
There was only one dialogue screen in a trivial discussion that was in german while the rest was in english.

If your a fan of turned based RPG games and used to playing them on other than easy/normal I'd recommend this.
But if you always choose the "easy" setting when you play: This game is all but "easy".

reviewText:
EXPLORATION & ADVENTURE

The game has no exploration or sense of adventure. None. Zero. Your experience with exploring the world of Blackguards consists of clicking on an icon on the world map representing a settlement and loading up a marketplace view, said view having a few icons to click on that load up the various types of stores or that occasionally (a different icon) offer quests. And that's it.

The various settlements are highly detailed, but all of that detail exists on static backgrounds. The backdrop pictures could have offered a great sense of place simply by utilizing a nice exterior shot. Indeed, this being a fantasy world, and one where many of the settlements offer a rather distinct size and local elements, exterior views could have added a great deal of wonder and adventure to the player's sense of the world. As it is, though, settlements are just a series of the same four stores with minor hints at the diversity that the world has to offer with a few extra flourishes added to some of the marketplaces.

For the most part, one's interaction with the world is on the level of an mmo. There are stores to click on and buy stuff, and there is the occasional quest giver that is met once or twice, says his generic spiel to send you off on your generic quest, and one never sees them again after. Leaving the game with no sense of character.

STORY

The overall concept of Blackguards is generic chosen one gets chosen for unknown reasons to save the world. It's a bland and generic concept, but there's nothing inherently bad about it. One can take a generic concept and sprinkle originality upon it to make an exciting concept. Operative word being can. With Blackguards, the one conceit to originality is that the characters are blackguards".

Except they're not. The main character is
recommended: falsely accused of a crime he/she didn't commit. And he/she now roams the badlands
hoursPlayed: an outlaw hunting outlaws...a RENEGADE.\n\nSome of your cohorts have committed crimes. But other than a few - very rare - jokes
voteText: this never really comes into play. The only character who is actually a criminal during the game is quickly killed off. The rest of the characters are more in the "gang of rogues and misfits" territory. And the things that that band of rogues and misfits are called upon to do during the game are the usual generic RPG quests. Find the lost "ring"
helpfulPercent: rescue the damsel in distress
votesHelpful: kill these bandits
votesTotal: etc.\n\nWith only that unused conceit to count towards originality
votesFunny: there is nothing original in the Blackguards storyline. It is
commentsCount: unfortunately
column16: the usual generic
column17: bland template upon which to hand an RPG. But it actually gets worse than that
column18: because the various enemies and situations are also generic
column19: and the core development is a jumbled mess
column20: leading to no driving reason to progress through the story. (Stressing here that there is no driving reason to progress through the story
column21: not the game.)\n\nThere's a core of a good story lying within Blackguards. Evil villains
column22: saving the world
column23: high adventure. But none of it ever gets used. Instead
column24: the overall story sits in the background while the characters get captured - again - and drug around doing random combats against generic foes that have no personal stake in the overall story. The number of times that the party actually fights people who are involved in the threat to the world before reaching the final chapter is incredibly low. Instead
column25: in a world threatened with destruction
column29: and independent undead that the party meets.\n\nThe characters of the main party have some personality
column30: even if it is a bit two-dimensional. Their personalities are well-written. But there is little there to most of them
column31: and those personalities do not drive the story. The only driving force in the story is the Chosen One main character. The other members of the party simply offer some localized color here and there. And unfortunately
column32: the best personality is killed off early and replaced by someone as bland as the Chosen One main character. The remaining personalities are well-written
column33: but bland.\n\nWhich brings up one of the major points that are often brought up about games like Blackguards - "It's not about the story; it's about the combat". And while it is true that the centerpiece of Blackguards is combat
column34: one also spends a lot of time watching cutscenes following along the story. If the story isn't actually a major part of the game
column35: then it shouldn't occupy a major part of the time of the game. If it does occupy a large portion of gametime
column36:
then it is a major part of the game. End of story.

RESOURCE MANAGEMENT

At first
column37: the resource management of Blackguards seems like it will be an exciting and detailed system. But like so much else in the game
column38: none of what is met in that first impression is ever fully realized. There is a lot of meat here. The consumables system is highly detailed
column39: with a lot to offer a game that put pressure on those resources. But there is never any pressure. None of the resources matter.  The most glaring of these is rations. The sole use of rations is to allow the group to camp out on the world map. Yet
column40: since there are no wandering monsters and no risk or real time involved in traveling
column41: there is no reason not to simply click on a settlement and rest at its inn rather than lug around heavy rations units (other than the obscurely long loading times for the settlements).\n\nThe only resource that is regularly bought are arrows
column42: for those rare times when there aren't bundles of them found on the enemy
column43: or when - much more often - all of your equipment has been taken from you. As with so much else in Blackguards
column44: resource management is a highly detailed system that a lot could be done with
column45: but that never comes to fruition. Soon after it's introduction
column46:
it becomes left by the wayside.

COMBAT

For all of the famed glory of the Blackguards combat system
column47: there actually isn't much to it. The party is made up of five members
column48: and they usually fight from 6-7 enemies
column50: sometimes less. The battles take place on a hex-grid
column51: and they take place in turns based on individual character speed and an initiative roll.\n\nUnfortunately
column52: the enemies are underdeveloped. There is not a great deal of enemy variety. There are a large number of enemy portraits to fight. But there are not a wide variety of methods of attack. Most enemies are melee grunts who attack using the same pattern and single attack
column53: whether they are mindless zombies or (supposedly) intelligent bandits. A few combats have enemies with ranged ability
column54: which they use in a largely random fashion
column55: instead of a focused aggressive one. And a rare few  have spellcasters
column56: which use their spells in a largely ineffective fashion. Combats against opponents with special abilities beyond that are really rare.\n\nOn the other hand
column57: it is good for the party that enemies remain stupid and unfocused
column58: as the party are always outnumbered and usually fighting on empty square battlemaps
column59: and thus a focused effort would likely easily overwhelm the party. Likewise
column60: the enemy do not have all of the special abilities that the party do. Again
column61: this is a must for the survivability of the party. The power feats that are available are just so intensely powerful
column62: and there is so little defense against them
column63: that having any of those abilities is essentially an I-WIN button.\n\nWhich leads to the main issue with the combat - it's is badly balanced. Open character development systems are really hard to balance
column64: and this one is not even remotely in the balanced ballpark. There are some aspects of the character that are hugely beneficial (Super Improved Power Attack)
column65: some that are only of minor benefit (Read Enemy hp)
column66: and some that are of no benefit at all (fireball). Thus
column67: the difficulty of the lies entirely in the character sheet. Leading to different players having wildly different experiences in game difficulty."

reviewText:
Fun game so far, I'm enjoying it... Scratch that....

Combat which you will be doing alot of is bland and repetative. Be prepared to be posioned in alot of battles, also prepare for your spells to fail regardless if you are maxed out in them, For example I had 1 spell called  Cold Shock (Level 18) Maxed in the description I have a 99% chance to cast, in one battle this % drops to 8% with no explaination. This game is not not very forth coming in telling you the negatives that effect you well unless is poison :).

Magic, What the game does not tell you is with spells that effect all enemies your chances of casting these spells drops to stupid odds... For example in the last few fights in Chapter 5 I was trying to cast a few spells the chance was 1%, please understand I had all my skills maxed regarding spell casting, even reliable spells like the Fireball one was reduced to 48% from 99%. As a whole being a magic user you are punished. Does the enemy get punished in the same way? No they are able to case level 4 spells at 99%.

Storyline, seems non exsistant at the moment and I am on chapter 5 the last chapter, you arent made to care for your choices or characters sorry I like to feel my choices in RPGs actually make a difference.

Skill Trees, again like combat it is bland, if you go melee you want to go for Hammer Blow which forces you to take Two Handed Bashing or Axes and Maces. I did start the game of as dual wielding swords how wrong I was :(. There is very little choices in skills say unlike games like Path of Exile.

The equipment you get is standard and boring. You would expect from a Fantasy RPG to get some magic items well dont hold your breath, there are a few items that will give you the odd boost but they are few and far between.

Overall as a fan of Turn-Based games and RPGs Blackguards comes up short in so many ways.

I am glad I paid less than what its on sale for.

reviewText:
Ok, let me start by saying that I absolutely love this game; its got everything a true RPG'er would want in a game; good story, great game mechanics, addictive gameplay, good graphics, outstanding music score, and probably excellent replayability as well.

So why am I giving it a thumbs down?? its difficulty is just...brutal, before anyone accuses me of being a pancy COD button masher let me say in my defense that A) I have never played COD and B) I am actually an old school rpg'er that has bagged several classic rpg's on my resume, Wizardry games? check, Baldurs gate? check, Icewind Dale? check, might and magic? check, and also most modern RPG's as well such as the Witcher and the Dragon Age series. So I *know* when I talk about difficulty I mean it, this game is absolutely frustrating sometimes; on easy the enemies are more forgiving ( and I am not one to use that setting unless absolutely necesary) BUT the hazards and Obstacles are NOT.

I will still purchase whatever DLC the devs decide to release, and I will definitely purchase a second part of this game, just because I am a very passionate RPG'er, and this is truly a gem of game. However, a lotta folks will be put off by the brutal difficulty the game throws at you constantly and the (somewhat) steep learning curve.

reviewText:
There needs to be a review on this page telling steam users that at least 11 out of the 45 achievements are bugged and most players cannot achieve them. There are plenty of community posts surrounding the faulty achievements.

The game itself took a while for me to get into, it wasn't until part way through the second chapter that I found myself actually wanting to continue playing the game.

I experienced 2 bugs during my gameplay, once the game crashed when trying to add a new save to my list of game saves and once when casting a spell in battle, nothing happened after the casting animation so I had to crash out and re-load the battle.

As for game play and story line, you can tell this game was not finished when it was released due to the map being more than twice the size of the actual parts of the map you explore during the game. I found the ending very anticlimactic. The whole game is fully voice acted, yet the ending has a few words show up at the bottom of the screen over some scenic views... There is no obvious resolution to anything in the storyline and you are not told how the choices you made throughout the game have affected the outcome of the ending, meaning if you were to replay the game you wouldn't know what to do differently.

The game is visually very nice and the voice acting is good, although some times in battle I had a mans voice sound when I hit a female enemy and vice versa.

As a result, I have to say that Blackguards is a non-recommendation as I don't feel like the story provided me with anything to take away and think about, and also because of the bugged achievements meaning I can never 100% this game!

reviewText: There is little to recommend, thinking I shouldn't have bought this.   D&D style RPG that invokes quests that don't use your current stats.  One that takes away all the party's armor and gives everyone clubs.  Another that takes one of your party out of the fight (and kills them off).  While one might say it's a strategic RPG,  that only applies if there aren't so may variables as to make strategy next to pointless (it's mandatory, but still comes down to plain luck far too often).  Bad enough the normal D&D variables to hit, the variable damage, but then lets toss in higher numbers of opponents, invisible terrain traps, and opponents that always have poisoned weapons.  Flanking an opponent doesn't seem to have been included, so pointless, and while crit hits are included, when the opponents out number you, they have a greater chance of getting crits, by benefit of more of them means more chances for a crit role. High level of frustration.\nUpdate - 2nd attempt, a little better.  Got to the point I quit first time.  Believe first time it was bugged as chance to hit was only 55% and bugs hit for 8-10 dmg.  This time I see my hit chance at 75% and bugs hit for 4-5 damage.   Meant I could actually get through the quest.

reviewText:
Blackguards is an  average game at its best . Follows genetic fantasy tropes . Character creation is bare bones , you cannot modify starting stats .  Game offers large world map , but due to its linear nature you will be just staring at places you can't go . Story progresses by clicking on hubs where you will either enter a city screen or combat . Side quests are very limited .

Appearance customization is limited to picking  out of five pre-made characters per gender.  There is significant shortage of light and leather armor variety . 85-90% of all armors in a game are metal which means you spell caster wont be able to use it . Game has nice sandbox system where you are allowed pick whichever skills/perks you like . Perks require xp and trainer .  It can be difficult to find trainer to teach you perk . For example you might unknowingly leave act 1 and lose access to mage trainer for rest of act 2 .

Combat is dull . Most of it involves using same spell/melee attack and hoping you will get lucky.

Graphics and are style are uninspiring .  There is no camera angle rotation and overall camera controls are poor . This can lead to some frustration such as inability to target or see enemy hiding in a corner .

You can interact with some environment and there are some environmental hazards like methane gas in swamps. You characters and enemies can slip on wet floor . Some maps with lots of water spills turn into some kind of comedy involving every character falling to the ground at start of their turn .

Voice acting is decent . And dwarf you get in beginning of the game is awesome .

In terms of bugs and glitches game was polished in its early stages . I've only encountered one minor bug that was quickly fixed .

reviewText:
Let's address the elephant in the room.  The game can be VERY punishing.  An NPC in the tutorial village suggested I master many different weapon styles.  Seeing as it was an NPC in the tutorial village I took its advice...BIG mistake.  I got punished sooooo hard for making my warriors master 3 weapon styles.  I think what the NPC meant to say was make sure your PARTY masters different weapon styles.  For example, make sure everyone doesn't use piercing weapons because the undead are IMMUNE to spears and arrows!!!  Rekt....

But once I changed the difficulty slider from normal to easy I managed to get through the game and beat it with still a challegning final boss fight...on easy...

The jist of it is, if you're going to play Blackguards have a clear plan of what you want your group to do.  Warriors should be warriors not fighter/archer hybrids.  Mages should max buff and debuff spells not staff and 1 handed swords...sigh (I WANTED A MAGE TANK)...didn't happen. Archers should BE archers.  Don't teach your archers how to use 2 handed weapons you will get punished hard if you do.

Its a shame the game doesn't let the player do more hybrid, jack of all trade kind of builds, but it just doesn't.  Think of your party as an old fashioned dungeon and dragons group.  Dwarf uses axe, mage uses magic, elf uses bow.  That's just how it is in this game.

I picked this game up on sale for $10 and got over 40 hours out of it (and I may play again sometime down the line....waaaaay down the line).  So that's value.  Its fun so long as you play with a party build goal and don't over reach where you allocate your party stats.

reviewText:
So, Blackguards, eh? Well it is a good idea for a game, but the realisation is missing something.
What could that be?
Well the first impressions were good- the characters have a lot to learn, but somehow for the new players it is unknown could they learn everything, something or just few things? There is no explanation.
The game gives you to chose between 2 options that will define your game- will the main stats of the hero will be automaticaly distrubuted, or you will do everything manualy.
So far for me, my adventure was with 3 heroes, however I was with 2 warriors and a mage. Somehow I did not made a ranger and I found that as a mistake when advansing in the game.
I found myself more frequently repeating and reloading a map to find the best solution to win or get out from combat.
Yes, the combat.
Well, the combat is Turn Based so you have time to think your strategy, however heroes miss a lot, and sometimes a chance to hit or make a spell of 70%+ is not enough. Every fail punish could punish you really badly.
The maps are not so big, but for that kind of game I guess they are enough, however, for me, they looked someking small.
You could interact with some object in the map or use an object to take a cover from an enemy archer, however, not everytime this thing works. Some archers simply ignore that.
The audio is good. The voice acting is in good level.
The soundtrack is good. I liked it.
I made few side quests, but one of them was really pain in the ♥♥♥ in at the end I even did not finished it. It was horrible. Probably much higher level heroes could do it.
The grapics are nice for the eye.
I did not encounter any bugs, but I can not keep playing the game. It is enough.
So for final- this is avarage turn based strategy with RPG elements, however, there are better ones out there that you can play.
For me- I would not try this game anymore. I really wanted to like it, but I can't give it more time. 4 hours and a little bit more are enough.

reviewText:
Tactically Reallistic
its hard to say its good, its also hard to say its bad, so i'll give you both.

The Good
- Battle system is good.
- The Storyline is great.
- Limited sidequest available.
- Weapons & spells are extremely unique (only when you upgrade spells & weapon skills).
- You can use environmental traps.
- Battle skills & abilities are real great & useful.

The Bad
- This game is so reallistic that when you buy too many items & weapons pass your limit, it'll cause your characters to do negatively poor in combat (depends on the weight of items).
- If your not well prepared before events or battles, you'll have a tough time trying to complete that scenario.

my overall, if you are a person of poor judgement, don't buy this game
if you love Strategy/RPG type games, then this game is for you......

I give this game a 9 out of 10

reviewText:
This game is quite tough, but a lot of fun.  I am still really early in the game but here are my thoughts so far.

Money is sparce at best and you can never afford anything but the essencials.  If you picked a ranged charcter like I did, assume all your gold is going to provisions, healers and arrows.

No farming, since you can't just go get in an random battles, if you have an area to explore it is best to visit every location to get all the EXP you can.

Make sure you save in multiple save slots, you can get yourself in a chain of mission that you just can't win without an extra provision or something.  If you don't have that save game from before you trigger the chain of events you could be stuck.

One last thing, don't be afraid to click end turn 50 times in a row if monsters aren't activated to get your magic points back and heal everyone and then get them back of to be ready for combat.

Overall, I am really enjoying it so far.  I'd recommend a play.  I'll updated the review it if I feel the need later.

reviewText:
This is a pretty fun game.  There are a lot of looading pages, and even though the game auto saves before and after a battle, it is best to make your own save file. If you loose a battle, and the game reloads, it will autosave again, and unless you have your own save file, you'll be stuck in an endless loop until you succeed, and sometimes those battles weren't ment to be entered yet.

The voiceacting is actually pretty welldone. I was suprised. The art is decent, the story thus far is very predictable, but still enjoyable. There's lots of side quests you can complete. It seems to be a good idea to do them, just to get the experience and the points to spend on spells, and abilities. Makes the game a little easier, and allows for more battle options.

I'm not a fan of the buying system. There's seems to be a limited number of arrows. After buying all of them in a shop, it seems they don't restock. I've come back to shops after many battles to see if they resupply, but it doesn't seem they do. The potion prices are rediculous. Though you shouldn't need them very often.

There is a little bit of a freedom  aspect. At a certain point you can choose where you want to go, and dialog options give you different results. You can choose which side to be on in some battles.

I give the game a 6/10. It's nothing special, but I do enjoy playing the game.

reviewText:
A frustrating design nightmare.  Suffers from classic Euro-dev 'difficulty' design flaws.  Everytime you lull yourself into a state of enjoying this game, the devs ♥♥♥♥ up.  You can almost smell the body odour of the geek who thought taking away all your loot for an entire climactic segment of the game was a good idea.

Don't bother getting attached to characters or strategically saving points to spend on a worthwhile skill.  You can lose them without any notice, having wasted opportunities to use those points to get you through certain battles.  Cardinal error.

Some fights are designed to be artificially punishing.  I haven't used the word 'cheap' since I played Nintendo in the 90s.

reviewText:
I have wanted to love this game. I really, really have. The character development system is complex and has a depth rarely found in RPGs. The story and choices are a combination of dark and darker, and yet there is no shortage of humor in the game. Having said all of that, I do NOT recommend this game for the casual gamer who enjoys RPGs. This is for the hardcore gaming fans who want to spend hours agonizing over points spent in skill and character development, only to find that you have to start over because you lack core abilities in your characters to survive. Further, the combat system is ridiculous. You get a wizard at the beginning of the game as a companion who has an ~80% accuracy range - however, in my experience, his spellcasting is weak at best, and backfires most of the time, and at often critical moments. Unfortunately, healing is also problematic because it uses an entire action (turn), and so by the next round, you may be down more health points than you were before you healed. Following me so far? That's good, because on top of that, you can count on being outnumbered and outmaneuvered in nearly every battle.

I could go on to wax poetic about the ineptitude of the combat system and the way the developers correlated character development with combat in a way that is clear, but I think you can get the gist of it from above. I have to quit playing this game because after too much time trying the same battle over and over again to rescue some baroness who loves the less than useless wizard companion I have, I am going to retire this game entirely and quite playing it. It simply lacks any enjoyment for me at this point. I think the game designers have a lot of work to do to create a product that I would ever consider purchasing again. I feel cheated of my money and my time.

Oh, and you don't have the option of really grinding your characters up to par, either. There are a set number of quests and side quests, and you spend those character development points at your own risk.

Again, there may be a market for this to hardcore gamers and some others, but it is definitely not for the faint of heart.

reviewText:
I'm enjoying it. There are parts that need tightening up, like seeing the console commands on screen, but aside from that it's been a smooth experience for me.

The story is interesting, the world is intriguingly dark and the characters, so far, are all interesting (my favourite being Niam the crackheaded half elf). Combat plays out on small, hex based maps that keep the action from getting bogged down or boring. And, while in combat, that's all you focus on; you can't loot corpses, for example. All of that happens afterwards which I like a LOT.

The combat system is simple, really, but it works. There are enough special abilties to keep it all interesting and to give you a wide variety of tactics (at least when you get the right people to suit your style) but they're not exactly trying to break the mold here. Basically, you've probably seen this all before. It didn't bother me, but I could see it boring some people.

The graphics do their job, though they're nothing to write home about. The voice acting has been surprisingly good for the main characters, although I find the NPCs tend to fall into stereotypes (villains sound like they're about to go NYAH I'M EVIL"). It's not really distracting

reviewText:
This is again a tricky one. Overal Blackguards is an extremely fun game but it has one big flaw.

First the positive points:
The strategic turn-based hex battles are great, I'm happy that finally game developers are taking this up again instead of all that RTS nonsense. The combat system with different moves goes smoothly, also the interface using a radial menu is OK. It does take a while getting used to.
Nice character development using a skill/talent system which is unconventional. This feels fresh and is an interesting change compared to other typical RPG's.
The voice acting is great and really adds to the immersion, also the characters themselves are well fleshed out and the interaction between them is hilareous at times (which is positive i.e. there is a lot of humor in the game).
There are many different (side-)quests, lots of items to find and experiment with etc.
The story itself is interesting and while the game is very linear it doesn't come as a hindrance. This also is a nice change of pace compared to other games recently where everything has to be 'open'.

Now to the one flaw which at times totally screws up the game: 'nonsense' battles ...
Each time I play, the battles are sometimes challenging, sometimes easy but overal quite fun. However, when you reach the pinnacle of that fun and are really enjoying the game ... the devs throw in what I call 'nonsense' battles which totally kill the mood and make you want to remove the game from the harddrive.

These 'nonsense' battles for example require you to rescue someone in 6 turns. The first say two attempts it won't work since you have to figure out what is needed, the next couple of attempts you run into traps (you can't detect them since there is no time in 6 turns). So in the end you have to constantly reload and reload and reload. Try a fireball on the first turn, if it fails, reload since no miss can be afforded. The game in such battles also feels as if the 'to hit' percentages are inversed. For example a 'to hit' percentage of 95% in these battles feels as if it's 5% since suddenly everything misses (so reload and reload and reload). It thus has nothing to do with strategy anymore but purely boils down to finding that one single path which 'could' lead to victory and then pray that your attacks actually succeed.

The above is really sad since it totally spoils the mood. After completing such a 'nonsense' battle (which is really a waste of time) the game is again great and fun until you again reach a point where they decided to dump such a miscreation.
It feels as if the game was designed by two different people. One person designed 85% of the game which is great and 15% was designed by someone who's only goal was 'How can I annoy the player the most?.

The game also has some minor issues like incorrect voices in cutscenes or a slight stutter when using certail skills (hammer blow) etc but nothing game breaking. I didn't have any crash or anything
date: overal it runs smooth.\n\nIn total it took me 47 hrs to complete it on medium.  Considering the fact that it has some interesting replay value (different starting class
hoursPlayed: ....) the game delivers quite some content.\n\nSo

reviewText:
Blackguards is a turn-based combat focused RPG, that will most likely frustrate you a lot with the amount of dice rolling in it!

My opinions won't really add much to the discussion, as they're mixed... like almost everyone else's. Also, I'm farily new to the genre, so the min-maxing aspect present in the attributes and skill-trees in the game don't really appeal to me, yet (mostly how of ignorance, but anyway...).

I really like RPGs in general, but I'm not one to read up on the game's numerous systems to learn what the optimal builds are -- I like to shape my characters as I please, leading to some interesting, fun, but not necessarily good decisions. I've done the same in Blackguards and will admit that, for the most part, it went alright. I played through Normal mode, and never got truly stuck, which was my biggest worry.

Many people complained about reaching an unbeatable point in the game because they had a sub-optimal build. Maybe they were either playing on Hard, or I've simply been fairly lucky in my decision.

I will say that there were lots of details in the game that I simply did not delve into -- potions (offensive), traps, etc. Those didn't seem all important in any of the battles in Normal.

Anyway. It's tough. Some of the battles were infuriating, missing 3x in a row when I had a 90% chance to hit, having some periods of extended battles that far overstayed their welcome, etc.

But I did enjoy it quite a lot. Until I finished the 3rd Chapter, that is. Then the game offered nothing new.

The game is very linear, although it opens up a bit in the 3rd Chapter, giving you quite a lot of sidequests. The following 2 chapters barely have any of those, which felt strange.
It seems like the focus of the game was only the 3rd chapter, the other ones being mostly to build it up or simply carry the story.

The story was pretty bland, and the sidequests weren't too interesting either. Gameplay-wise, it's almost a pure combat game. You move from battle to battle. Other than battles, you just go to cities to buy equipment/heal/train, and get sidequests. Sidequests simply lead you into more battles. You never explore anything, never really find emergent gameplay or anything of the sort. It's very, very combat focused.

But hey... I really have very little to add that would be in any way meaningful. I want to talk about one thing exclusively -- and that is how opaque the game actually was! It was one of the biggest sources of frustration, for me.


Sometimes, the game pushes you into extended battles. Battle after battle after battle without an opportunity to heal, restock, change equipment, etc. These, of course, are a much bigger challenge -- especially because, if you do poorly on one battle, you'll carry that penalty onto the next one.
These battles felt extremely tense, to me. Sometimes they could go on for 2 hours, even if they were just 2 or 3 battles. The game is very slow paced, and a mistake can cost you quite a lot of time, which is frustrating. And the game often likes to pull tricks on you that it never pointed to. They're unwelcome surprises.

This is one side of it. The other, happened in the end of the game. After the point of no return, you're lead into a serious of battles, but you can heal and re-equip between them. What you can not do, is buy anything. Every healing potion, equipment, etc. that you can use is what you've taken with you.
There were a few problems here -- first, you had no idea how many battles there would be, so you couldn't really judge. Second, what the game showed you was very misleading, by having it spread over 2 pages"

reviewText:
English:
Blackguards is a good game that demonstrates the ability of its developers to create games that are not classic point-and-click adventures. It is more a strategic, heavy combat-based game than a role-playing game, but it will be surely appreciated by those who likes this kind of experiences. A nice first step for Daedalic Games outside of their roots.

Game is fun, very thought through and have tons of detail put in to every aspect of it. Trully an amazing rpg, the story is great as well which is a huge plus as story kills games for me, if they are bad.

reviewText:
Blackguards is based on The Dark Eye ruleset (German pen & paper RPG). This foundation is both the strongest and weakest characteristic of the game.

Strong because the combat system is very smart and tricky, challenging you to really think when spending adventure points or making actions in turn based battles.

Weak because this system has rather long learning curve and is very unforgiving for players who don't know its rules well.

This is probably the main reason for so many bad user reviews here. It's a shame because Blackguards really isn't frustratingly hard"
recommended: and can be very rewarding for your strategical planning and tactical thinking. Also it has enchanting graphics
hoursPlayed: entertaining story
voteText: good music and great voice acting.\n\nSo yes
helpfulPercent: I can't recommend this game to the general audience. But that doesn't mean it's a bad game
votesHelpful: although it has some quirks of course (weird user interface for example). If you like to dig into character stats and adjust attributes and skills

reviewText:
Fantastic game set in Germany's most popular fantasy world

I am really baffled by some of the luckwarm reviews that this title was getting. I found it to be a fantastic, visceral turn based strategy RPG set in a refreshingly dark fantasy world.

Perhaps the initial bad press was due to the fact that it wasn't X-Com: The current turn based darling.

Indeed, there is no permadeath and the story is relatively linear. However; about 40% of gametime is dedicated to non essential side quests.

I especially liked the art design on the game; the battlefields, warriors and beasts seemed stylized as living toys; I could almost imagine this game being played on that chessboard in the Millenium Falcon.  Expect to see dozens upon dozens of battle maps and a variety of winning conditions.

reviewText:
Not ready for primetime.

First the good:  It looks fun and I enjoyed the first part of the first chapter.  Voice acting is decent and the combat flows OK if you like turn-based (and I do)

The Bad:  Constant crashes; gamebreaking to the point where I can't continue.  Not my first rodeo and I have tried all I can think of to resolve them.  I deliverately waited until the game was out of early access and patched before purchasing.  I regret doing so now.  I'm not your beta tester.  I'm a customer or WAS a customer.

Look elsewhere to avoid frustration.

OK Update - After several trys, I was finally able to get the game to continue.  Felt like walking on eggshells.  Did I do anything profound? Nope.. Just kept loading from a save until it finally continued.

After further play, I still feel the game needs balancing.  Some of the fights are super-easy, others are nigh impossible.  I stand by my review.  Will this game be enjoyable at some point?  I bet, sure.. Does it need patching?  Yes it does...

reviewText: While I don't have a lot of time invested yet in Blackguards I must say that I am enjoying the turned based combat and overall feel of the game.  The game is very pretty and seems bug free for the most part at least for the 3 or so hours I put into the game.   I really haven't gotten to invested into the story yet but it is interesting enough.  Visually the game is very pretty and gameplay wise it seems rewarding.   I haven't seen anything that reinvents the wheel but that said what it does it does well.  I so far highly recommend the game.  Honestly in the short time I have been playing I have had more fun combat wise than with games like Dragon Age.  Of course it isn't completely fair to compare a Real Time with Pause game with a turned based game.   I will say that between this and Divnity: Original Sins it makes a turned based strategy RPG gamer happy with glee to see such great games coming out.

reviewText: Blackguards combines engaging tactical combat with a pretty nifty story. It's pretty much what D&D Tactics wished it could have been, even though I personally liked that as well. reviewText: A terrific return to Turn-Based Combat, with a slightly darker, fantasy story. It at once feels like a renaissance of the turn-based genre, but with some newer, unique ideas. Character customization looks outrageous and daunting at first, but with a single type of Adventure Point and clear class-goals, linear guidance eases the pain, while still allowing anyone to experiment with wild combinations. It's a classic tale of old-school meets new-school, all in a really tightly-produced package. Graphics, story and gameplay are all great.

reviewText: I enjoyed Blackguards. The gameplay is fantastic and the level design is great. Unlike most of the RPG I played, this game is brutal*: the heroes are either undernumbered or weak compared to the enemies and you have to take advantage of the environment in order to win. On top of that, my mage, the squishy guy with low initiative was always in the wrong spot at the start of the fight. On the other hand, some fights (only a few tho) were simply bad designed: in one of them I had to fight a mage and a tank with my mage and tank who's weapon was poisoned. They were way better than my guys and there was no trap, no object, no catch on that map. It took me about an hour to win and it was only possible with the help of the RNG gods.\nI did not like the story.\nThe RPG" aspect is ok. There are a few weapon categories with unique features and access to a number of skills

reviewText:
This is just the sort of game I love and as it was half price I snapped it up. That is where the fun ended sadly. The skills/abilities sound great but there is no way you can know what you need to go for. I built a fairly rounded party so I could be flexible and now can't even defeat basic enemies. This is, for me, a major problem as I now have to go back to an earlier save to re-spec.

Not so bad you would think. Well this is where the problem is multiplied hugely. The point I am at in the game, for some unknown reason, is at the end of a series of very tedious battles. These do not allow you to save of even gather experience between them. So I have to go back beyond this point. Which is frankly killing any enjoyment I got from this game.

Honestly this is a decent attempt at a turn based RPG. What lets it down is the total lack of freedom in your choices. No random battles means you have to know where to spend those skill points as you aren't getting any more from anywhere. Couple this with the fact that there is no real way of knowing what you need to spend them on till you have a go and this ruins what could have been fun.

I am aware of the online guides on how to spec characters but what is the point of having lots of options only to have them reduced down to a handful that are actually feasible? Really feel that at half price I have been robbed.

reviewText:
Just finished the game.  After getting to the last battle and finding it frustrating not to have Aurelia, I went back through chapters 4-5 changing strategies.

The good:
-If you really miss Temple of Elemental Evil, this game will be nice for you
-Not a lot of min/maxing of gear (some of the best gear is available early in the game, and most of the stuff you'll find in the game will not be an upgrade)
-Each of the companions have really well-drawn out personalities (the dwarf, for example, will complain when you heal him that he doesn't need it"; the playboy mage will flirt with NPC's you meet).

The bad:
-There are not a lot of varieties of bad guys in the game.  You'll find yourself saying "didn't I just fight this battle?" a bit too frequently
- For people that like seeing gear progression
date: you will not get it here.\n- The ending was quite a bit of a let-down.\n- During combat
recommended:
there is no way to speed up the monsters' turns; and you will sometimes literally be waiting a minute between turns while a slug slugs its way across the screen.

Will you like it?
-If you liked Temple of Elemental Evil because it was super "true to the rules"--Yes
-If you liked Baldur's gate because your Party AI would let you not have to micromanage--No"

reviewText:
Full Review: http://www.coffeebreakgaming.co.uk/pc-game-reviews/review-blackguards/

Blackguards is a turn-based fantasy RPG from German outfit Daedalic which is solely based on the Dark Eye roleplaying system. It provides a welcome return to the true turn based RPG combat genre which forces you to greatly consider every action you make, whether that be skill points, combat skills and many more. It provides a good level of difficulty, without going too over-board whilst allowing you a ‘life-line’, a bone for when things get tough – i.e. the all-important and crucial save feature between battles. The overall storyline, writing, voice-acting is good whilst providing enough depth to avoid it being a drag.

Combat is where Blackguards best feature occurs and is perfect for players who enjoy the battles on hex tiles to that of the stories behind them. The use of objects on battle-maps combined with an easy to understand combat interface and a variety of character abilities/skills allows the player to get in and get on with gameplay.

Difficultly in digesting a variety of character abilities, skill points and equipment load-outs, specifically the equipment system, as that proved most challenging and somewhat confusing due to the amount of resistances available. However, once you’ve taken the time to understand how they all interlink, this section opens up to provide the player with a great variety of levelling up elements.

Can appear to be somewhat repetitive if players aren’t enveloped in the storyline. Far too many loading screens which stops the flow of the story and battles far too often.

A very stylish and graphically intense RPG, scoring high on the styles category, specifically in the gorgeous looking towns/outposts, where players are faced with beautifully designed shops and scenery which differs throughout the storyline.
A mediocre score for value with its current (09/03/14) price tag of £26.99.

Blackguards provides players with the opportunity to play for hours on end, experiencing a whole array of new content/utilising new tactics, however players are forced to read every snippet of information/guide to fully understand its complicated character system and some battles can appear to be rather repetitive.

reviewText:
Tough but rewarding. This is (luckily in my eyes) a typical The Dark Eye game. If you do not know this RPG system: it's Germany's biggest and probably oldest Pen & Paper RPG system that is still maintained. And as many things from Germany it is deep and complex, but needs a certain degree of dedication.

You will not be able to simply start this game, kill some enemies and have fun. You really need to have a look at the rule system and how all the character values influence your fighting, casting and other skills. The same goes for spending your experience points, if you simply raise a stat here and there you will find the game very hard and probably quit. If you decide what role a character will have and raise the necessary stats and skills for this you will have a much easier time and will be able to enjoy the very complex fight options.

One definitive pro from my point of view are the really varied battle maps. Most maps have unique interactive features that you can use in the battle, like alchimistic tables that will poison bystanders when smashed. Or drawbridges that can be raised or lowered. Or cranes with crates that might smash your heroes from the docks - or the enemies if you position yourself smart enough.

Alltogether it is a clear recommendation for me if you like complex strategy games with RPG-like character development. Do not buy if you look for Diabloesque casual RPGs.

I wanted to like this game but just doesnt seem ready or have enough depth for my liking.
