reviewText:
The game itself is about gathering a group of criminals and misfits together to form a band of anti-heroes to take on the bad guys and rescue a damsel in distress.  Its broken down into Chapters which were released through beta piece at a time.  I bought the game in beta and enjoyed playing it immensly.  The battles are turn based so no need to rush and a much better opportunity to win through tactics and strategy.

HOWEVER when the full version was released it all went drastically downhill.  Yes there were a few minor bugs that I could live with when it was a beta.  The final release version has a number of major flaws in it.  My existing save game made any new battles unfinishable as you couldnt end a turn - all your characters just stood there with no end turn available.  That's okay I thought, I will start a new game, it will be fun choosing a different character from Chapter 1.  Oh no ....... BIG FAIL.  When you try to start a new game, you get the character creation part fine but once you finish adjusting your new hero you try to start the game and all you get is a black screen and some music.  Immediately I thougt oh it must be a graphics resolution problem, but yet I had just loaded a older saved game and it loaded fine (even if I couldnt advance through the next battle) and indeed it loaded fine again when I tried.  So now I am at an impasse, with no new game possible and all my saved games bugged.

I checked the forums and it is not just me with these issues.  And it appears that the publisher is doing nothing to resolve the said issues.

So overall this game now has some major flaws that make it unplayable.  Stay away.

reviewText: For the most part I really like this game. Character development is very deep and interesting for an indie RPG and the combat, while not incredibly nuanced, is fun and challenging. On the other hand however, the game's marketing material tout that you play as a band a criminals and miscreants - even the name of the game hints at this. However the game appears to reward you for being the 'good' guy and punish you by omission for being the 'bad' guy, which is surely counter productive if you want your players to be nasty 'Blackguards'. However that's just my opinion.\n\nI can't recommend this game in its current state. There are far too many bugs and design issues that should have been weeded out during testing. Another testament to how pointless and anti-consumer the early access system is. The game is simply not worth the asking price as it is. However once these problems are fixed and perhaps the game comes down in price a little, I'd happily recommend it. At its core it's a very enjoyable game.

reviewText:
Blackguards is at first an interesting turn based RPG, with combat occuring on premade hex grid based maps. It is interesting because it does away with most of the filler that comes with most every RPG. You do not control your characters in any way outside of combat, you simply shift to a different spot in a city where you can talk to a couple of NPCs and that's it. Outside of towns you travel on the world map by clicking on a selectable point on the map and you are instantly transported to a town, or into combat if you have a quest going on outside of town.

This makes the game more fun at the beginning, because you always get to the important parts of the game instantly, that would be the combat and the story. However as you progress through the game the positive turns into a negative because you never start feeling a connection with any of your characters. The only time you control them is in combat and in combat they are simply damage dealing stats.

So the game becomes tedious as you start clicking through all the dialogue to just pick up the quests and then you do the quests, almost always by going into combat and you soon realise that the primary things you do in the game are combat and clicking through the story, which I might add is very simple and not at all interesting.

The combat at first is satisfying, especially for me since I am a fan of turn based, tile based combat. However you will probably start getting more and more annoyed with it because of its randomness (nearly every action has at least a small chance to fail and it seems to happen more often than it should). And also because of the lack of data while in combat, the battlelog is very nearly completely useless so you have to constantly pay attention to know what is happening, since the camera can jump around a bit if it's a larger map and you can lose track of the enemy actions. And there isn't enough contextual information with the game for when you move your characters. For example I'd like to know if one of my characters will pass through where an enemy can do an attack of opportunity on him, it's true that it isn't too hard to figure out for yourself if that will happen, but honestly you probably won't have the patience to do it after you are controlling 5 characters and have 5+ enemies each taking their own turn. The combat just becomes too slow at that point.

Outside of combat you also manage the equipment of each of your characters, which isn't really that interesting because there isn't much choice of weapons or armour and what little there is it's always a straight upgrade or not, so there isn't much thinking involved. Somewhat more involved is improving the skills of your characters, but even that becomes straightforward after a while, since you get an abundance of points to allocate throughout the game and you soon pick up the more desirable skills.

So to summarise my main points: no filler makes for a fun start, but it also destroys any potential character building, the story is very simple and not at all interesting, the combat is at first fun but it becomes tedious after a while, not much variety in equipment and finally not enough interesting skills which are worth putting points in. Definitely try the game if you are into turn based, tile based RPGs however be warned that the game can become tedious to play and it did so for me.

5 / 10

reviewText: Although it has an interesting idea for a story, the gameplay itself is porrly executed. The fight sequences are repetitive and even on normal mode seemed arbitrarily hard, suggesting not a lot of creativity went into the difficulty just number values. The side quests were uninteresting, the characters were fairly stock and it just had the feeling of an unfinished game in general. Too be fair, I never made it out of Chapter 1, so I can't say it doesn't get better; however, I'm a firm believer in having the beginning of the game be the hook, to entice the gamer to play more. Another reason being: if the first chapter feels unfinished, how is the rest of the game going to feel better? And spells that have a chance of failing? I understand Magic Resists/Immunities creating another level of gameplay, but buff spells that have a 46% chance to fail?\nOverall 5/10.

reviewText:
I really don't like this game.

Confusing for the sake of confusing doesn't make a game complex or interesting.  The character stat screen tells you very little of the impact that your leveling decisions make.  So much of the directional choices you make with characters appears to be hidden.  The hit percentage system, how to recover health/mana efficiently and the effects of decisions are just a few examples of this.

I understand that a fair amount of people believe that this hidden veil makes the game more complex, and that they consequently are more intelligent" because they "figured it out".  I would argue that they wasted their time fiddling with a poorly designed game when they could have been playing a game that isn't a waste of time.

I should have played the friggin' demo first.  So for that

reviewText:
This game has some good concepts, but unfortunately it simply balls it up. It commits every sin in the CRPG handbook.

Ultimately this game is NOT an enjoyable experience. The first mistake the developers make is confusing complexity with challenge. The character system in this game is needlessly complex and completely opaque. The fights are incredibly unbalanced, and while it is possible to scrape your way through using tactics, it all comes down to luck.

The combat system is absurd. My archer has repeatedly missed 100% chance to hit shots. Not parries, mind you, just completely missed. When you miss 5 90% shots in a row, against an opponent that has no special buffs, and meanwhile the enemy are not just hitting you but criting away, leaving you wounded and dying.

Twice now the game has committed the cardinal sin of CRPGs of taking away your progression for the sake of a gimmick. Too bad if you were trying to make an archer, here's a club, go knock things on the head for 2 damage. See, the thing is, unless you picked the fighter class you won't have power attack, which makes melee weapons as good as useless since you'll just be scratching the ticks of the enemies back.

You can play as skillfully as you want and you will still be screwed over by RNG and the absurd combat mechanics. Here's an example: My archer just missed 5 90% shots in a row on a target. Missed. Not parried. The target was not buffed with dodge enhancing stats. Now, in some games that would be okay, you'd curse your luck but recover and reorganize your strategy. In Xcom you might pull back and try to lure the enemy into an overwatch trap while you heal up your guys. In this game, every shot you miss, every hit you do not land sets you further and further behind and it is completely out of your hand due to the level up system and comparitive enemy strengths.

This is not fun. The game itself is boring enough without having to go back and redo every freaking fight over and over trying to find some way to have just one of your guys survive.

The loot drops are hilarious. Fifty pairs of hardened leather boots. Not one usable piece of armor. Boots. Boots all day. But don't think you can just buy armor for your party, the gold costs of the items mean that at best you will have one reasonably equipped and maybe leather pants on your other guys.

And why on earth do the combat percentages change every round? Why when nothing else has changed does my warrior go from 90% to 50% then back to 85% ... if anything, im hitting the enemy it should go up. None of this makes any sense, it makes tactics pointless. Nothing is every explained.

Honestly do not waste your money.

reviewText: Great hexed based rpg, I really enjoyed this game and would recommend this game to any rpg fan. reviewText:
I am not sure why this is getting so many negative reviews. I have played a pretty good amount of this game so far. Is it the best? No. However it is not bad by any means.

If you like turn based RPGs then this game is great. People REALLY should research games before they buy them. The game has a little bit of a steep learning curve but if you are even a semi-decent gamer and are familiar with TBS games then that should not be a problem at all.

Personally I am REALLY REALLY sick of all the games nowdays hand holding you and making things so simple. What some say about the leveling and skills/stat points is true however. There is really not alot of explaination about how to do this. Trial and error is all you have. I ended up starting the game over a few times before I really started to figure out how to do it properly.

The story is not the greatest and neither is the gameplay or graphics. However I have had alot of fun with this game. I like the darker story. I like that your crew is not a bunch of goody goody types. The movement and cities are pretty bland but that is ok beacuse the fights are alot of fun IMO. The enviornmental parts of the battles are very cool. I like that you have to open cells to create a distraction and get away from the guards. It was way cool that I had to lead the troll into some flammable gas and then shoot him with a fireball to do a ton of damage. Cutting the rope and dropping a chandelier on some  guards was pretty damn cool. There is alot to like in this game if you can get around the mediocre graphics and horrid voice acting!

If you are looking for a AAA super polished graphical game this is not for you. If you like a decent story, dont really care about graphics, and you like TBS RPGs then this is for you!

Overall this is a pretty good game. There are not alot of TBS RPGs out there to pick from and if your a big fan of that genre then you will like this game.

Divinity: Original Sin is a better choice IMO but that is still in Alpha and has ALOT of bugs. I bought both of them and I really enjoy them both.

Again this is not the prettiest game. The voice acting and cut scenes are ATROCIOUS!!!!! But who cares as long as the combat and RPG elements are good.

Graphics: 5/10
Sound: 5/10
Story: 5/10
Gameplay: 7/10
Overall: 6/10

Like I said its not the greatest game out there. But in this genre there is really not much to choose from. TBS RPGs are probably my favorite type of game and this game does an above average job.

Buy it if you are like me and really jonesing for a TBS RPG!

reviewText:
Would I recommend this game to everybody?  No, not at all.
Would I recommend this game to people who I know love Dungeons and Dragons?  Yep! (Only when the game is on sale)

This game, as you know, is based on the Darkeye D20 ruleset and is only for those who like stategy turn-based RPGs.  Darkeye is pretty big in Europe from what I understand but I personally never ran a game with it and I wanted to experience the system in an easier to digest way and I felt I got that from this game.  Package that with the honestly funny writing and interesting characters and I enjoyed myself.  Note, however, that this game is entirely about the combat system and RPG progression.  The story is there, but weak, and there is no exploration.  The retail price is too steep for what you get but if you see this game for $15.00 USD or less then I'd suggest picking it up for fans of the genre.

reviewText: Really fun turn-based tactics game. I don't like the P&P system that it uses as its base (The Dark Eye), but the game has truly amazing level design. All of the encounters are hand-designed, and they play like a tabletop campaign, with environmental effects being hugely important on many maps. reviewText:
The Combat in Blackguards obviously carries this game through all its shortcomings. Each battle-map is different fom the last and has a unique feel to it. Customizing your characters in weapon skills and magic feels rewarding. The most fun comes from figuring how this game actually works, like when the points you just spent make a noticeable difference in the overall challenging battles. Don't expect too much offensive magic, you're better off keeping your mages in a support-role (where they ROCK hard). You probably heard about the interaction with stuff in battles, but that's totally overrated: Wasting a turn to push a box or set something ablaze is rarely worth it. Occasionally this is implemented quite nicely, like trapping something in a cage, but most of the time there's only boxes to push.

I hear people drooling over how interesting the characters are, but honestly your party members are *completely* one-sided and sometimes downright dislikeable  (*minor spoiler* Zurburan selling Takate to some slaver...seriously? *spoiler end*). Their is no intruiging background story to them and definetly no progression in personality whatsoever. The story on the other hand is compelling, but since story-specific dialogue is only few and far in between the dominating combat, it's ultimately thin...very thin (if you know DBZ, you lnow what I'm talking about *lol*). The world itself feels a bit on the bland side and the streamlined gameplay leaves little room for Lore or in-depth consideration of your potentially stunning surroundings.

The biggest issue here is how barebone the gameplay is. After a fight you basically point&-)click your mouse button a few times to advance the dialogue or move to the interchangeable towns to check on the completely interchangeable merchants and start the next fight. Combat-Dialogue-Click-Combat-Repeat. Kudos for the quest-writing though which I found top notch!


So: Combat: AWESOME. The rest: *MEH*. I enjoyed it a lot, also because it is more fast-paced than some of its TBS-brethren.

reviewText:
Great game!

This is my 3-part review of the game. 1. The RPG system, 2. The actual roleplay, 3. The feel of the game. It is worth mentioning that I am a RPG guy with long experience in both Pen and Paper RPG (mostly PF, but also Vampire), and a lot of CRPG. So, naturally, this has an impact on how I liked or disliked the game.

1. The roleplaying system The Black Eye is really nice and has a lot of depth and will be candy if you, like me, havent tried it before. I cannot accout for the differences between the pen and paper 4th edition (witch the game mechanic is derived from) and the system Blackguards has implemented. But as far as I am concerned its really nice. Different attributes combinate to give different base statistics - and control how well you fight / use talents / casts spells. There are no levels for characters, insted you gain Adventure Points from combats and finished quests that you either continually spend or save up to spend on more expensive upgrades. It really is a fun system and has similarity with the way Vampire the masquerade works. The turn based tactics is nothing but pure enjoyment!

2. The actual roleplaying is somewhat linear. If you like that then no problem. If you want more choice, then it has shortcomings. Things are pretty much set up and you cannot deviate too much from the path. The choices you are given doesnt even have that much impact. For instance one side quest presents you with two identical twins, the one is evil and the other is good - but who is who. In the end, if you chose to root out the good guy OR the bad guy there is no impact on the game other than your own conciousness. (...and honestly, who cares abouth truth when it comes to a book worth 50 ducats?!)

3. The acutal feel of the game is, at least to me, awsome. The characters you pick up are rather strange, a paranoid dwarf, a sleezy magician and later on a drug addict elf to name some. But this is what strangley keeps it interesting - actually highly enjoyable. Bugger off with the lawful good paladin that does good at every turn. Here its like plant unlawful poison at a highly esteemed noble to get him arrested" or "Get a new slavegirl / trophy for the master of the city".

To sum up
date: I really enjoy the game - (not finished yet as this is written) and I see a replay possibility with choosing differet abilities. If you enjoy RPGs and in particular the combat part - this is a game for you."

reviewText: Blackgaurds is one of the most addicting games I have played and has been a great game to start out 2014 for me. This game has some of the best voice acting and music I've heard and its gameplay feels like it actually melds with the story. Quite a few times you'll be presented with interesting alternatives in combat most wouldn’t think of in a turn based RPG. You could go the classic route and just beat the baddies in a one on one fight, or if you’re feeling creative lure them into hazards that you normally wouldn't think of. For instance lure them into a bush then set it on fire or release a group of prisoners to fight for you. Even some battles have great story elements. Need to collect some mushrooms while a giant troll is guarding them. Distract the troll and gather the mushrooms, then run. It’s these types of options that make you feel like you’re having an impact and cause you to think outside the box. The few problems I do have with the game mostly revolve around a few graphical glitches and sometimes the enemy AI can be a little too slow. Graphical glitches like people suddenly having mouths that stretch way too far when they speak or the amount of a silver currency you earned being blocked has happened to me. While the biggest flaw is probably the AI, I like how you can set traps for them but when an enemy chooses to continually get burned in a bush and not leave it that’s when I call stupid on the AI. These bugs can be annoying but they don't break the game and I recommend this game to any RPG or Turn-Based Strategy fan.

reviewText: Very nice tactical RPG. Characters reminicent of old school bioware characters and the combat is very thought-out. Each battle map is very different from the last in the way it impacts the battle, the developers seem to have spent a long time designing different terrain and objects that have effects. For example in one map there are fire braziers which you can have your characters knock over and they set large patches of oil on fire. reviewText:
I have only played Blackguards for a couple of hours at this point. But the game brings me back to the old pen and paper Dungeons and Dragons (tm) nights with the boys. If you ever played a Kick-in-the-door style game, where the focus was on combat and the story, though good, only was an excuse for rolling the combat dice, and enjoyed it - then Blackguards is a game for you. The focus in on combat and character advancement in classic RPG style. Towns work as a supply hub, and the story advances in cutscene in between combat sequences.
All in all a very enjoyable game - that I will recomend to people that like RPG combat like in the  old Baldurs gate series.

Keep in mind that, at the time I write this, the game is available as early access (still in development), and your expectations should be set here after.

reviewText:
I am not sure why this is getting so many negative reviews. I have played a pretty good amount of this game so far. Is it the best? No. However it is not bad by any means.

If you like turn based RPGs then this game is great. People REALLY should research games before they buy them. The game has a little bit of a steep learning curve but if you are even a semi-decent gamer and are familiar with TBS games then that should not be a problem at all.

Personally I am REALLY REALLY sick of all the games nowdays hand holding you and making things so simple. What some say about the leveling and skills/stat points is true however. There is really not alot of explaination about how to do this. Trial and error is all you have. I ended up starting the game over a few times before I really started to figure out how to do it properly.

The story is not the greatest and neither is the gameplay or graphics. However I have had alot of fun with this game. I like the darker story. I like that your crew is not a bunch of goody goody types. The movement and cities are pretty bland but that is ok beacuse the fights are alot of fun IMO. The enviornmental parts of the battles are very cool. I like that you have to open cells to create a distraction and get away from the guards. It was way cool that I had to lead the troll into some flammable gas and then shoot him with a fireball to do a ton of damage. Cutting the rope and dropping a chandelier on some  guards was pretty damn cool. There is alot to like in this game if you can get around the mediocre graphics and horrid voice acting!

If you are looking for a AAA super polished graphical game this is not for you. If you like a decent story, dont really care about graphics, and you like TBS RPGs then this is for you!

Overall this is a pretty good game. There are not alot of TBS RPGs out there to pick from and if your a big fan of that genre then you will like this game.

Divinity: Original Sin is a better choice IMO but that is still in Alpha and has ALOT of bugs. I bought both of them and I really enjoy them both.

Again this is not the prettiest game. The voice acting and cut scenes are ATROCIOUS!!!!! But who cares as long as the combat and RPG elements are good.

Graphics: 5/10
Sound: 5/10
Story: 5/10
Gameplay: 7/10
Overall: 6/10

Like I said its not the greatest game out there. But in this genre there is really not much to choose from. TBS RPGs are probably my favorite type of game and this game does an above average job.

Buy it if you are like me and really jonesing for a TBS RPG!

reviewText:
Blackguards is a turn-based fantasy, often dark and frequently humorous, RPG.

While still a beta product it is polished and one of the best RPG's I have played in a while. It is a good feeling to catch myself laughing at the well voice acted humorous dialogue, which I haven't experienced to this degree since way back in games such as KOTOR and Jade Empire. Daedalic Entertainment might just be the new old pre-EA BioWare we all fondly remember.

Probably the only frustrating thing I experienced was the questionable stated odds of a spell succeeding, but I am also not sure if that percentage was meant to take into account the defender's resistances.

I give it a 9 because it is hard to me to envision a better RPG without my mind drifting back to old BioWare. So this is a real user score, not an artificially inflated rating meant to preemptively fend off the incoming 0's from reviewers that found fault in this product.

I eagerly await the Chapter 5 release...

reviewText:
I'll add on to this as I play more but for right now I have the following:

The first thing I have to say about this is I really, really like these types of games. I really enjoy games like Fire Emblem & Onimusha Tactics on the GBA and XCOM on the PC, which are specifically turn-based games. Blackguards also gives me the vibe/atmosphere of old school RPG games I love like Baldur's Gate I & II, Path of Radiance: Ruins of Myth Drannor, Icewind Dale and Neverwinter Nights + expansions + mods (The old bioware game, not that new MMO). While the games I just listed are not turn based, they do have pause button tactics, and they share the fantasy setting and RPG skill allocation, feats, that sort of thing. The most recent game of this genre was Dragon Age Origins but it has been a while since that came out. To me , Blackguards feels like a true merger of those two types of games I listed above, the action is turn-based, but the environment and customization is very much just like old school RPG.

Anyway, since then, I have been waiting for another game to grab my attention the same way all these massive titles did. I decided to pick up Blackguards, and I will admit that I was scared because it was Early Access. I will tell you now this game has not disappointed me in the slightest, even though it is Early Access. The characters are fun, the gameplay is exactly what I wanted. I have to say they won me over pretty quickly. I wrote down a few pros/cons that were most apparent for me.

Pros:
-I personally love the turn-based gameplay/combat system
-Nice artwork and environments
-Plenty of voiced dialog
-Fun characters
Cons:
-Kind of easy even on hard difficulty, but I like these types of games so.....yea
-Graphics are a tad dated so this might bother some
-Some features are kind of buggy but it is still Early Access so calm down (using bandages ect...)
-I would like some cooler / more tiered armors and weapons
-Seeing the reference tags on characters/objects is distracting
-No in depth character customization (but it is to be added later!)

Verdict:
YES pick it up, if it is on sale (erm Winter Holiday Flash sale) even better. This is a fun game to play even early access. I am glad I did it and I think the RPG community will come together to love it.

reviewText: An interesting RPG game with some strategy that was initially sold to me by referring to it as being in a similar vein as Shining Force (still one of my all time favourite games).  It does have to be said that the premise and characters aren't as dark as you would initially expect, given that this game promises something close to flawed dark 'heroes', but does make a nice change to the usual knight in shining armor.\nAm only in the 2nd chapter so am not sure how the slighly repetative layouts and fights will play out as I progress, as do feel that it may grow stale after anothter 10 or so hours.  Also the inability to grind to gain AP (like EXP) does irritate in a game where every point counts and you feel as though you have never levelled up the right stat/skill/spell.\nBug-wise tha game has been fine thus far.  One gripe I do have is that I expected the bonus from equiping a set of armour to be more obvious and worthwhile than it currently is.

reviewText:
I've played through chapter one and this took me approximatly 10hours. First of all I really enjoy the game even if I sometimes feel the desire to hammer the game against a wall.
Classes:
-Mage
I've started as a Mage and even if it is really frustrating at the beginning, because your spells miss all the time (one 7times in a row...(This needs to be fixed!)), at the end of chapter one I have no clue how you would survive without having main char mage + the story-mage that joins your party. The story-mage is even worse at castin than your main-char and sometimes next to useless but for a few heals now an than...if he manages to cast them...My main char-mage now casts some spells with 99% accuracy but I'm not really sure why this improved...
-Warrior
So far my warrior is pretty useless besides sucking up damage, of course this is his main aim at the moment, but it is still frustrating that just 1 out of 5 attacks succed because the parring/evasion rate of most enemies is pretty high.
So far my warrior only fought with axe and shield, so maybe that's just an unfortunate combination.
-Archer
Nothing much to say here, I think this class is pretty good balanced at the moment, or a bit too good if Mage/warrior are taken as standard.

A few pros and cons:
-Until chapter one the game is quite linear, besides a few flashbacks. You can't explore any areals or wander around between cities you just leap from to the other most of the time.
-I really like the difficulty of the game, even though I'm playing on normal" is quite demanding at times
date: but as mentioned above it's a bit up to luck in hard mission weather you succed or not depending on if you miss the first few hits or not...\n-I would really like it if after you explored a city there would be a Sign above the city on the world map indicating what kind of trainer you found in this city
recommended:
because otherwise you got to go through the cities to find them again.
-The skilling system is nice but sometimes a bit annoying because I don't know when I'll find the next trainer or which skills he can teach me so I end up not really knowing where to invest my points.

I'd like to state again that I think it's a great game despite a few issues and I'm having quite a lot of fun playing it.
"

reviewText:
Really love it! This game is misunderstood very often.

+ great gameplay (not as good as XCOMs but still nice)
+ based on The Dark Eye - refreshing compared to all the games based on D&D
+ nice story
+ nice quests (and side quests)
+ funny interaction in-between the characters
+ really good value for money when on sale
+ lots of different skills and builds to explore (a bit confusing and overwhelming for beginners though)
+ good difficulty (it will be very challenging at times and you will have to change your tactics which worked before)


-	Obviously not a huge development budget (they made the best out of it)
-	Graphics are nice but could be way better (eg. cutscenes …)
-	Skills & talents can be difficult to understand. You’ll probably need to google a bit to understand the different character values.
-	Some bugs can be frustrating, eg. when the healer in-between the gladiator fights won’t heal you anymore. There aren’t many but this one made it very hard for me
-	Save often. (same as xcom). It could save you time.
-	Usability in the stat/spell/… screens could be better, especially when trying to figure out which weapon does more damage.

All in all, I can live without the best graphics and animations (like XCOM does superb). I was willing to learn about the skills and mechanics. I accepted the couple of bugs I encountered – it only lead to the game being more difficult but didn’t break the game itself.

After reading many negative reviews I think the problem is that this game isn’t like many other games out there, it’s comparable to XCOM but with possibility to skill your characters in a complex way. You can’t save every minute and decisions you made today could be a problem much later. You may have to do some side quests to get the experience to advance. You won’t be able to blindly upgrade every skill and spell there is. You will have to use different tactics. Using Takate with his piercing skill will work awesome most of the time, but if an enemy is immune to piercing you should better have given him some other weapon and skills (I learned this the hard way).

Obviously something went wrong during the beta version, because most of the negative reviews are from back then. I didn’t experience many of the problems from back then. If you like turn based games with a lot of strategy involved you’ll probably like this. If you want to kill many monsters with huge firewalls better get path of exile ;)

reviewText:
I know its been a long time in the making, but I have finally defeated the game that is Blackguards. In this game you will be taking on the role of a commoner who is friends with those in high places, especially a princess, but wait, what was that? Oh no the princess has been killed, and you are having the finger pointed at you. This is where the true story begins, and where you will met the first of your companions that will help you through the game with either their strength or their magical abilities.

Graphically this game has a couple of small hiccups from time to time, but the overall game gives you the feel of a dark and desolate world that is clinging to the world of old gods. Even though you don't get to actually walk through the towns, you are given 3D scenes that you can click on the action icons to interact with, they all have depth and personality. Another thing is that there is a lot of different models used when it comes to interacting with towns, you are not going to see a lot of repeats, though to be fair its not like any of the towns are overflowing with people. Now as far as the combat graphics are concerned you are placed in a 3D hex-based grid system in which you will be moving from 3/4s side view to top down view so that you can see the whole field and make sure you're not missing anything such as traps or enemies that could be hiding behind walls, plants, etc. I do like the fact that at the bottom of the screen, since this is turn based, that there are images of the enemies, and they have about 3 to 4 stock images so that the enemies have a little bit of variety to them. Sure the models all look the same with the exception of if the enemy is a specific class or sex.

The music in the game was very well made, and there were quite a few haunting tunes that as soon as they start I immediately think about the game. The voice acting for the most part was solid as well, there were a couple of over the top performances, but sometimes that's going to happen when try too hard to capture a specific type of character.

The controls in the game are pretty straight forward. You are going to use the mouse coupled with WASD for most everything while moving around a map, or on the battlefield. You will of course be using the usual 'i' for inventory and 'c' for character sheet.

So this game is pretty deep when it comes to all the little tweaks you can make to your character. There is a good number of spells to cast, there is weapon proficiency to think about, active and passive skills to learn, traits to learn, and of course stats to increase. I have to say that this was always a daunting task for me, but for the most part, once I really got into the game, I had the feel for what was really important for my party to not only survive, but to succeed. You'll also be given weapons, armor, and items galore that you will have to learn to balance. I found out the hard way that putting items or equipment on your characters does not take away much if any of the load in your inventory. So when I had my party fully decked out I almost had no room for much else, unless of course I wanted to play encumbered. That being said it didn't created THAT big of an annoyance.

You of course have your own main quest, starting off with you trying to figure out what is really going on, and then of course the twists happen and all hell possibly breaks loose. The thing is that there are a ton of side quests to keep your eyes out for. Now I will say this, until the very end of the game you might lose access to some quests, but have no fear you will regain it later on in the game. There's also many quests that you might miss out on if you don't periodically check in on all the cities. Yes, I understand that that means that you will be dealing with a ton of load screens, but none of them are really unbearable, and when you get to the end of the game, you will thank me for making you search for extra quests.

I'm going to be totally honest with you, it took a couple of attempts for me to get into this game, but once I was invested in the game I couldn't stop. I wanted to see what was behind the next bend in the road, what enemies would stand in my way, and of course it stood out to me because I've always loved pencil and paper RPGs, and this felt like a pretty good transition from sitting around a round table with friends and experiencing and adventure. So in the end I have to say that through it all I have to give this game an 8.9 out of 10.

reviewText: Great hexed based rpg, I really enjoyed this game and would recommend this game to any rpg fan. I have read some of the reviews that were negative and I don't understand how people give this game a negative rating because they thought it was something different. That is their fault for assuming they knew what the game was. If you watched the trailer, it shows what exactly the game is, a hexed based rpg with strategy elements and has a story that has been done before a bunch of times. That being said I enjoyed the game very much and while the story wasn't groundbreaking the story kept my attention, kept me interested enough to see what was going to happen next and did have a few suprises. While the game can be cheap at times during combat, in no way is the combat broken or unfair, you just have to use your head a bit and have a strategy which I can understand might be hard for some people on here. reviewText:
Its not a bad game and I do appreciate a developer bringing turn based fantasy RPG's back to the market. However, it just feels like it fell short of its potential. Not to knit pick but starting with the lack of facial customizations. I know its not a big deal but in my opinion, it starts the game off on the wrong foot and goes on from there.

there is really no exploration, its extremely linear and predictable as far as the encounters go. The rules of turn based combat are also not the greatest and are very vanilla. No attack from behind bonuses that I could see so you can retreat and not worry about taking a blade to the back if you were standing in a hex next to an enemy.

My biggest frustration was in upgrading my gear. Theres RNG involved for what you can loot from battles, so dont count on picking up that axe that this guy just done done whacking at you with for the past 10 minutes.  It just vaporizes apparently leaving you with your trusty ol' starter torch.
Weapons and armor cost a lot of money and while you may be able to gear your guy up with a basic sword after the first half dozen encounters, that will be it for quite a while until you can afford more. Meanwhile, wave after wave of baddies wielding swords, shields, axes, armor, bows and arrows will make sure you pull your hair out before you can afford to gear your party adequately enough to fight them.

reviewText:
Stale and unappealing, but it's close. If I could give a thumbs-sideways, I would.

Actual battles can be enjoyable, offering challenge and rewarding strategy. Too often, though, the challenge is presented unfairly, in a way the player can't possibly avoid; taking away your party's gear or positioning your party disadvantageously at the start of a fight are examples.

Character building has interesting elements, the way stats and abilities interact and a slider for individual weapons to favor chance to hit or block/parry.

But Blackguards as a whole is disappointing.

reviewText: I liked the idea behind the story of Blackguards; there aren't enough games out there with 'evil' characters, however this game had a really slow story with frustrating blockages from not being as overpowered as the game expects and no way to 'grind' up the levels.  The middle section of the game was probably the most interesting with its non-linear gameplay, but a slow and boring 8hr lead-up and a slow and boring 4hr let-down of an ending accompanied by its repetitive and repetitive and repetitive fights in between.  The only thing keeping me going was the vague hope that it would get better, or stay as good as the 3rd out of 5th chapter.  Only worth playing if you are *really really* into repetivie turn-based combat

reviewText:
Blackguards is a hexagonal turn based strategy game with some fun elements to it.
The story line is fairly interesting, with many offshoots in the plot to keep you entertained.The graphics are nice and clean and the voice acting surprisingly good, with many humorous lines from the characters as they play off of one another during your adventures together.
The learning curve isn't too harsh and the tutorial helps a lot during the start.
However it can at times be a little punishing and you will find yourself hitting the restart button on quite a few occasions, especially any levels involving poison, to which there seems to be many. In my opinion the mechanic is used maybe a little too much throughout the game and the effects can start to become a little irritating, so spec to counter this when you get a chance. There are a few bugs, but nothing I would consider to be game breaking, so all in all Blackguards is worth the buy, but I would recommend waiting for it to be on sale and avoid the full price. I picked this up discounted and am more than satisfied with what I got for the money.

reviewText:
In brief: fairly linear hex-map RPG with good character system and decent storyline. You'll enjoy it if you like that sort of thing.

Blackguards is an old-school gaming experience dressed in modern threads, a pen-and-paper RPG brought to life on the PC. The graphics are appealing, animations smooth, sound effects satisfying and voice acting mostly good. You take the role of an assistant to a noble family who gets into trouble at the outset and goes on the run, and your attempts to unravel what's happened ultimately take on a global significance. The story, chiefly told in cutscenes whose animation is best described as economical, follows a fairly linear path, but a wealth of subplots and sidetracks provides a pleasant illusion of free movement which probably won't convince today's open-world gamers.

Your character is provided with several sidekicks and you marshall and move your party on the world map. Movement is essentially the selection of locations and passage of time is not tracked. In towns and similar locations you'll find traders, trainers, inns, healers, and the like, as well as NPCs who advance the plot and give you quests. Party management is done through the stat sheet and inventory of each character, and true to the RPG that gave birth to this game, the system is satisfyingly deep and complex. Your decisions about character development will win or lose you the game, and new players should take note: it is possible to build a character badly and it's very difficult to undo this once you've done it, so take the time to read the manual and the in-game character creation notes (which don't appear in the manual and are very useful).

Quests and plot advancement almost always involve a skirmish, and it's these hex-map clashes where you'll spend most of your game hours. It's clear that a lot of thought has gone into skirmish map design: in some cases it's a straight fight to the death, but often there are environmental factors to deal with and in some cases the map is a puzzle which you must solve to win. In fact you can think of every skirmish as a puzzle which must be solved, as enemies differ in their capacities and susceptibilities and you must apply the right tools in terms of weapons, spells and equipment to prevail. That said, the game depends ultimately on the roll of the dice, so luck is always a factor. Fortunately death isn't permanent and so long as you have the last man standing, you'll walk away with your party intact.

Some reviewers have complained of the game's excessive difficulty. At the time of writing this review I've completed the game on Normal difficulty and have clocked up over 80 hours of play. I think I saw every skirmish there was to see, well over a hundred in total, and more than half of those I completed first time. There were only a handful I had to attempt more than twice. The final battle is difficult, but so it should be – my only gripe is that the plotting, or perhaps the scriptwriting, feels a bit wrong at the end, but YMMV. If you find yourself stymied by a skirmish, see whether you can go elsewhere to level your party up a bit; if not, it's very likely that you're either missing something important in the skirmish (always check the interactive objects) or you've taken a serious misstep in character building. Be careful not to spread XPs too thin on your characters: you can't take all spells and weapons to the maximum in the course of the game, and you do need some top-level skills and spells by the end if not by the middle.

Two things bothered me about this game: loading times, and the ending. My system isn't top-of-the-line but neither is this game, and I saw far too much of the loading screens for my liking (Mengbilla in particular tried my patience quite a bit). The ending... without spoiling things, I was surprised to see essentially the same cutscene after winning the final battle that I'd seen when I lost it. I'm unsure if your choice in dialogues makes any real difference to the way the game pans out, and online chatter suggests that a lot of players were left confused by the denouement. I can't honestly recommend that anyone other than a genre purist buy this game at full price, but if you see it on sale grab it and give it a try, and be sure to get to the top of the bow skill tree as early as possible!

reviewText:
I am glad I only got this as part of the HumbleBundle (Side note, support Humble).
This is a turn based, hexgrid, dungeon crawler, rpg based on a not unheard of tabletop system.
It plays like a fan created mod to another game, in every way this game screams its lack of polish, it's terrible design and its aweful assets. This game makes NWN 1+2 look cutting edge

*FLAWS*

1) Inconsistant Mechanics; in short, they're half baked. An early mechanic is terrain tiles (water is slippery, bushes are flammable etc) and in theory these could make for some more complex tactical play, but sometimes thats not the case, water may just be a watery looking tile, or it may cause you to fall on your ♥♥♥ and be prone for a turn. Enemies never use them either, they just move to attack range throw fire, ice and poison.

2) Incorrect RNG; this is a tabletop system adapted for the PC, so of course its simmulating (with a pretty bad generator I might add) die rolls under the hood. You get told a percentage chance to hit (and can level up enough to see other stats) but the percentage shown is WRONG. That's right, the game actively lies to you because its number generation system isn't implemented right. 100% chance is actualy 90%, 65% is actualy 40%. You will also see the same resualt consistantly for mid range %, every time I fire an arrow at a humanoid enemy with a 65% chance to hit I would miss without fail. same goes for 50% with melee, this makes me think the random generator isn't so random after all.

3) Atrocious Voice acting; Dear gods is it terrible, it's not even laughably bad, the actors are often re-used but its like no-one told them they were doing different characters so everyone they voice sounds identicle. They were also clearly recorded completly seperatly without any lead in or practice because they're all delivered with the same dry detatchment of people with a full frontal lobotomy.

4) Poor story telling; The plot may improve as time goes on, but from what I've experienced so far I can already tell you my version And so it was that the brave ranger stabbed the annoying sidekicks while they slept and went to live away from the continent full of madmen". Honestly it started out bad enough with the giant wolf having killed (or having been eating) a random damsel
date: you kill the wolf and then get arrested for her murder. The wolf was right there
hoursPlayed: its body is lying on the ground next to the corpse
voteText: yet they arrest you for her murder. The rest of the story was following a bread crumb story into a veriaty of linier dungeons
helpfulPercent: speaking of which.\n\n5) Dull Dungeon Design; if you're making a dungeon crawler then you need decent dungeons
votesHelpful: so far everything has been a straight line with preset encounters
votesTotal: no element of maze
votesFunny: mystery or surprise. You know you will need to enter each point on the dungeon map

reviewText: I hate to vote down this game because there are a lot of things I do like about it.  However I think the games biggest problem is that it just isn't open enough which doesn't feel right for an RPG.  If you run into a rough spot to where you just aren't a high enough level to win without a one in a milion chance of getting lucky every move then you just get stuck since there is no way to go and do a couple of battles to where you can get strong enough to complete the quest.  The only battles I've been able to do so far are all battles within a quest.  I've heard this game opens up a bit later on but I'm not willing to retry a ton of battles over and over again to get to that point when I can find similar games that start out being that open.\n\nI hated to vote this game down and I think a lot of people will like this game but it's just not for me.

reviewText:
Not for the weak at heart, or those looking for an ARPG.

This has got to be one of the hardest RPG's I have played since Pool of Radiance, and I'm tempted to place Blackguards higher in that category just because I know very little about The Dark Eye rules, or at least much less than D&D. And it is great because of it.

Graphics are wonderful. They won't blow you away but are for the most part hand drawn and look phenominal. Musical score is excellent. (Really wish I had gotten the SE for the bonuses) The story seems well written, however I have not gotten very far to give a decent opinion about it.

The combat may turn some people away as it can be very difficult at times (and since it relies on dice rolls it can be quite rage inducing) but if you show determination (there is no shame in saving and walking away for a bit, might save a monitor and keyboard or 2) the combat is extremely rewarding.

If you like The Dark Eye world, or am just a fan of strategey based RPG's, take a long look at this game. Just don't forget to spend time reading details about every skill and stat before you use your AP (like XP) on them, because it can be really easy to screw up a build.
voteText: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Daedalic's first attempt in the RPG genre is a solid one. An experienced software house, mostly famous for their many graphic adventures, managed to bring us a game which delivers a grand amount of turn-based tactical rpg goodness, focusing on combat, even if it doesn't shine in terms of storytelling and pure roleplaying. What is mainly fine with the game is the fact that it never gets boring, since every battle is different, well thought and characterized, other than being intelligent for example making the battlefield often interactive with the party characters skills: a mix of variety and possibilities with a functional adaptation of the TDE combat system.\nPersonally enjoyed all over the long duration of the campaign, planning and battling with satisfaction on a game that needs attention and ability over situations thankfully non-easy nor banal. Dealing with improvements on the less considered sides of this role-playing game, like story, characters history or C&C, would make a perfect sequel for an already substantial and well-directed game.

reviewText:
I bought this because I was bored. And WL2, did pospone their Beta.
And man Im happy.
Its not really my style to play the bad guy. I'm always nice in computer games.
The game has so good npc, they are so colorful. (The dwarf remind me of the dwarf Khelgar, or Wrex from ME.)

The game is hard and sometimes unforgiving, but they never cheat, and there are no scripted events, there is always a possebilety to save an npc (Even if it is microscopic.)

If you like turnbase, fantasy, love a good story, want a laugh or two. This is your game.

reviewText:
I really recommend this game to anyone who likes tactical games.

This game is great fun when you like a bit of a challenge. Intriguing story with compelling characters and solid combat mechanics make this game one of my favourites at the moment.

If like me, you are looking for a well-thought-out tactical RPG, look no further. However, if you are looking for some mindless bashing and instant gratification, look elsewhere.

reviewText: This game is such a tight experience.  Combat is refreshingly good, and it offers a healthy amount of customization for your characters, with multiple viable builds.  The story is sufficient to get you to keep moving, but it's no Planescape: Torment (which is fine by me).  With all of the other RPGs on the horizon and in Early Access, I took a bit of a flyer on this one, and I'm really glad I did.  I don't know who these devs are or where they came from, but they have created a really good game here.

reviewText:
man seems to me alot of these reviews are harsh on this game. i have played many tactical strategy games over the years and this is a pretty good one in all parts.  I think the thing most people have a hard time with in this one is the dificulty of the game and them not really explaining on how attacks work. like in the percent chance to hit someone.  but if you do a little research you can figure out how to make it easy.

like all spells have three attributes allocated to them. so if you want to cast a spell that has agi, cha, const then you would want all 3 of those stats to be high. the higher they are and the higher the spell lvl is the better chance you have to hitting someone with them.

for rng and mele you want have the stat to be high to hit. for range its dex for mele its str. think there are also others that help. then you need the weapon you are using good also. plus therre is also a slider on the weapon. that lets you decide if you want to defend or attack better. so if you are on defend on the item you wont hit as often or as hard. so set it to attack.

all in all i think this is a decent game worth a shot. at least on the demo for anyone who has an interest in tactical strategy rpgs.  i got it on sale and im not disapointed at all. also the difficulty can be a little harsh you will not win a battle the first time everytime. but im not one for easy games i loved temple of elemental evil and others that are harsh.

However I like this game's world. I just wish they let me play in it outside of their story.

reviewText:
Just finished Blackguards, and it took about 50 hours of play time (this includes the DLC). I am a big fan of turn based tactical RPGs, and Blackguards does very well with the genre. Game difficulty is good, the story (though not amazing) is told well. Graphics are all right, but nothing to write home about. The maps are well designed and do not feel re-used, but the characters look like something from a game that was released over 6 years ago, not just over 6 months ago. Only being able to pick a head out of a choice of 6? I expect that from an indie company, not an established development studio.

Enemies are diverse, and they tossed in a good amount of missions with different obectives so the goal it's always just to wipe out the other side. There are times when it does get frustrating as the number of enimies can be many on a map, and we feel like you're spending more time waiting than actually playing the game.

When I first started playing Blackguards (during version 1.2) the game was buggy af. Some trainers did not work, some healers did not work (including what that was kind of critical to being able to progress in the game). Thought this was fixed in patch 1.3, but the game still has its bugs. These range from minor annoyance (I swear 25% of the achievements are bugged), to Why isn't this fixed yet" (Big huge massive spoiler --> Seriously
date: what's up with Aurelia? I trusted her and sided with her on everything
recommended: and in the end she still dies... Not that I even got the achievement for that)\n\nDespite the frustration of the bugs
hoursPlayed: it is a very good game
voteText: and one I would say should be added to anyone's list if they like turn based tactical RPGs. Just be aware that it still needs some work."

reviewText:
Definitely a must-have for old cRPG turn-based fans.
This is the first turn-based I'm enjoying so much after years (on PC Plattform).
Simple but very nice story, characters with his own personality, battles are never boring because different goals or external elements interaction, enough spells/skills to customize (shame that you know already all spells in game from the beginning, was more interesting if talents/spells would be revealed only when meeting NPCs who can train it)
A game that reminded me FFT and Vandal Hearts on PSX, and definitely a good one! No resource management, no extreme high graphic, just turn-based battles, equipping/healing in cities and pure enjoyment...as it used to be!

reviewText:
This game have too much variables that it's confusing.
It really is a hard game because of that. You have to consider every step carefully. One wrong move and you can end up GAME OVER. Always save your game after battles.
Characters attribute vary through Base Values, Weapon Talents, Talents, Spells, and Special Abilities.
The environment also play a huge role in the battlefield.

As for the story this game, it's a plain linear story, not like what I expected from Daedalic Entertainment.
They usually managed to pull out a great plot but not with this game.

Well, I recommend this game if you're up to challenge.

reviewText:
I have to admit that I bought this game blindly: Daedelic had such a good name with me that I didn't read any reviews. So maybe this is just a case of disappointed love. Anyway: I only played a few hours and then stopped, because:
- imho the dark eye rpg system is clumsy and makes for rather boring fights
- the game restricts you to fights on small hex fields without any exploring or experience of a world, to small towns (basically a static screen which allows you to click on merchants and trainers), and static travel screens.
- the story and the characters are stereotyped, especially strange from a company wellknown for its storytelling.
- the interface is very counterintuitive (fighting, selling etc.)

reviewText:
Blackguards by Daedalic - A promising game with some annoying flaws
I've spent 112 hours meticulously stripping down every area, every character and every side quest I could find during my first (and so far only) playthrough of this game. For the record, I'm a seasoned RPG-player and accustomed to the old-school turn based games.

Short version: Bl♥♥♥♥guards is an average game which could have been a lot better without some of the bugs and a more intuitively developed story engine.

For those of you who remember the glory days of the genre with Baldur's Gate I and II, IceWind Dale amongst others, Blackguars might still be worth looking into. I enjoyed playing it, but I would also like to post a warning about some of things that knocked down the total score for me:

The main plot is... kinda slow. And dull. I actually enjoyed several of the side-quests a lot more than the main story. The ending is very dissapointing (and without giving any spoilers, that is an understatement). I also missed having background stories unfold for the main characters, but perhaps Daedalic are saving those for the sequel(?).

Several achievements are (still) bugged. 5 of them simply can't be completed at all (confirmed by the steam community) but I've had a total of 6-7 that bugged in my game. It's been more than a year since these bugs were first reported and the steam forums have had no response from the developers yet. Like I just mentioned above, they are currently developing a sequel to Blackguards, so chances are that these bugs might never be fixed. Hence: be warned if you're one of those players (like me) who wants to cross off every achievement from the list. For future reference: I have not bought or played the DLC.

Some of the game mechanics are not explained (at all) in the manual and I had to scavenge the steam forums to see if they actually worked or not. Armor is perhaps the most obvious aspect, where players have no way of telling if the armor skills makes any difference or if the character is encumbered (and if so, what penalties to expect in battles).

An abundance of spells and skills makes things look very promising at first glance, but in reality, most of them are pretty much useless. Even when taking in account different preferations/play styles, at least 50% of the spells are likely to never be used by any player. Unfortunately, that goes for weapon types, talents and weapon skills as well. I can't shake the feeling that these worthless skills where put only there for marketing purposes rather than adding flavour to the game. It's either that, or Daedalic simply ran out of time/funds and had to release the game without proper (re)balancing tests.

Although you are frequently presented with alternatives and choices in NPC dialogues, it rarely matters what you choose. I guess you could say that they are there to add some RP, but even so it could have been handled with more finesse. Instead you're bound to a main plot that you have no chance of altering the outcome of.

I really don't want to spoil anything for you, but a frequent bother is when the game removes one ore more of your followers (and sometimes even your main character) without warning. A new player might have to start from scratch halfway through the game. Hint: make sure that your main character is at least somewhat decent in ranged combat.

The 20th time the game presents you with two choices where one gives you a handsome reward (typically the evil" aligned choice) while the other leaves you empty handed you can't help but wonder why? Most players expect good deeds to add up to some kind of greater reward later on. In my personal opinion
date: this is perhaps the single biggest flaw Blackguards has
recommended: and it feels like the developers rushed the story instead of taking time to plot out great stories. Let me underline that I don't think that "good" alignment should be favoured in any way. The rewards doesn't have to be better gear or more gold
hoursPlayed: it could for example be new dialogues/NPC's that are unlocked at some point further down the line. For a game that relies so heavily on RPG stereotypes it's dissapointing that karma is pretty much non-existant in Blackguards
voteText: And yet
helpfulPercent: sometimes the choices you make are actually so important that it could warrant starting over from the beginning. I would advice all new players to SAVE
votesHelpful: SAVE and SAVE their game as often as possible. Think of Blackguards as a Bethesda title in that aspect.\nWith the bad stuff out of the way
votesTotal: let's round things up with the more positive aspects of Blackguards:\n\nit's an ambitious attempt at rebooting the genre (yes
votesFunny: I'm aware that there are several other similar games on the market nowdays) based on a popular tabletop theme. The graphics are decent and the voice acting is top notch.\n\nCurrently priced at €39.99
commentsCount: I'd recommend potential customers to wait for one of the steam sales before buying. For that kind of money you'll likely to find plenty of better alternatives. Personally I bought it in a Daedalic bundle and 120 hours of gameplay is more than I expect to get from most titles these days.\n\nAll in all I'd score Blackguards a somewhere between 6 and 7 out of 10."

reviewText:
Stale and unappealing, but it's close. If I could give a thumbs-sideways, I would.

Actual battles can be enjoyable, offering challenge and rewarding strategy. Too often, though, the challenge is presented unfairly, in a way the player can't possibly avoid; taking away your party's gear or positioning your party disadvantageously at the start of a fight are examples.

Character building has interesting elements, the way stats and abilities interact and a slider for individual weapons to favor chance to hit or block/parry.

But Blackguards as a whole is disappointing.

reviewText:
This game should be a manual about how to fail a game.

It has been a long time I had not the chance to play a game so frustrating:
- wrong hit percentages (I once missed 99% 3 times in a row and I would say 95% means 70% for them)
- difficulty is scaled not on ennemy becoming stronger but you getting weaker (poison lowering stats, map full of traps) or them becoming more numerous (how great to play a turn based game with 20 ennemies)
- repetitive fights (always the same)
- useless quests (you can forge a 9 element spear which is as good as other one you can find easily)
- mage are useless. You have a low mana pool and will always run out of mana. Mana potions are so expansive you just cannot afford them (but the ennemy can).

This game is just a punition. If you are masochist, go for it. For normal people, it is a waste.

reviewText:
Blackguards is a RPG with a decent number of dialogue choices. The story has its ups and downs and early it is a bit confusing because they throw alot of unknown terms at you and and most of them you will only learn halfway through the game. And the end is kinda lackluster in my opinion.

The combat is turn based and the battles are mostly diversed since some can have puzzle elemnts others can have a few stages and so on. And your choices along the game influences some of the battles you have.

One of the biggest problem in the game is the amount of stats and character builds you can do makes the game way to difficult and players that dont understand how the game works in that regards can completely screw their games and be forced to start from scratch. The game does a really poor job of explaining how the overall stats work and the only way to learn about them is looking at help menu and read it or go to the manual.

On the positive side when you learn to make a proper build your mid-late game characters can have quite impressive abilities and power, the high level spell effects are rather impressive.

Also it is worth mentioning some of the achievements don't work properly or don't work at all.

Overall I liked the game however the high learning curve that can really punish you is something that only some people can tolerate. And the game only really offers a couple of playthroughs in terms of story and in regards to builds I dont think that people will play purely on the interest of seeing builds with diferent weapons, the spells are nice but they will not make the players play the game again just to see their high level form.

reviewText:
Firstly let me say I'm a big fan of RPGs but I'd never really played a turn based one until Blackguards. My first impression was that I'll get bored playing this very quickly, but they change the dynamics of the battles throughout the game so it's often not as straightforward as killing all the mobs.

The overall mechanics of the game are very familiar. Collect experience (action points) and use it to buy upgrades to your character. The battles are all turn based so you essentially get a number of action points per turn with which to move your character and perform a single action. Not being used to this type of game I wasn't too sure I would  like it but I ended up really enjoying it.

The graphics are pretty nice, not spectacular, but nice, The voice acting is a little ropey but doesn't spoil the game.

Overall I really enjoyed the game and would recommend it.

reviewText:
Blackguards is a good game but has it's flaws. Mostly I had fun playing the game.

- The difficulty of the game is quite easy at the begining but later on it becomes really annoying because mostly your enemies use spells that lower your move speed, attack chance and health. Also it will become quite impossible to fight your enemies if you don't finish all of the side quest.

- Interface/Combat  is excellent, but the controls are a little wonky and sometimes quite slow. There are some monsters that take up more than 1 hex ( places on the field) and it's hard to locate the spot to hit but it's not that bad that you will ruin your whole turn.

- Information is a little unclear  but after few hours you should figure it out.

- Loading screens. You will spend some time on loading screens.

- There is not much of different gear and weapons. Don't expect to find a lot of variety of great weapons, few of my characters had the same weapon from the 1-2 chapter to the end of the game. Also my wizards had the same clothes from the 1 chapter to the last part of the chapter 5.

- Opponents. There are a lot of different opponents and interesting ones. There are also opponents that are just frustrating you because they have have spells that lower everything (so yout hit chance isn't 95% but 45%) so they are hell to beat but when you beat them it's beautiful.

- Characters. All of the characters u play have different personalities that are unique. In some dialogues you can choose what your characters will say.

- Story. It's not a bad story at all and has some twists.

- Graphics. Some people might not care at all about graphics but I like it when the game I play has at least deacent graphics. The graphics are not that bad at all but when you talk to some people they will look totally different in the picture then they look in the game.

- Playability it depends on what difficulty you choose to play but It will surely have around 40 hours (surely more).

- To conclude this review I recommend you buy this game but on sale. You will enjoy it and be frustrated.

reviewText:
Pretty good SRPG, decent graphics,gameplay and leveling mechanics in terms of many choices to level up in and really create characters you want for your tactics.
Some of the fights, or rather mechanics in the games are kind of broken. You can miss like 10-15 times on a row, even with maxed skills and thus lose fights on it, and other times you might hit and crit on bosses constantly and wipe them extremly fast... A quick examples are bosses that has 40% dodge on any attacks you do. Now imagien that they also poison you, and spawning mobs that are basically impossible to kill. Now, you can lose this fight, like I did 10+ times because you keep missing everytime. And yes, then another time, you might hit basically every swing and boss is down before you know it. Thats not balanced, its just random and in a SRPG based on tactics luck should never play a big part into it. I can understand some luck mechanics for the rpg-elements, but 40% miss on a boss that hit hard back? and he is a tank? Come on...

I would give this game maybe a 7.5 or 8.0 of 10. When this game is at its best its actually really good, but when its at its worst its horrible. Probably need better beta test for the sequal in terms of balancing out battles, be more open about what to level up in, lots of trial and errors if you dont know what your supposed to level up or not. Also, the story and sidequest need to be better... basically as it is now, side-quest are kind of neccessary to finish for that vital AP which you level up in. So its not even a choice to do them or not.

I finished the game in 40 hours on normal difficulty, so this is a pretty lenghty game I guess 35 to 45+ hours.
Would I buy the sequal? Probably, yes, especially when its on some kind of a cheap discount, because I love srpg's and wanna support them (Final Fantasy Tactics need a sequal...) - but if the sequal for Blackguards, which is in development at this moment, get good reviews from the critics, I would probably buy it at launch.
As I said this game could be great, it isnt however atm in this state in terms of balancing and storywise.

reviewText: The game is based on a complex rule system, which is not explained very well, if at all. reviewText:
Blackguards has a pretty standard premise, in that it is a save the world fantasy story.  Unfortunately, the dialogue is stilted and often disjointed and the gameplay is dense and perhaps overly complicated.  I can forgive the voice acting, and odd story easily, but it is the game mechanics themselves that perhaps need tweaking.

The dice rolls are punishing and heavily weighted towards failure.  It is laughably common to miss 3 75% chances in a row and taking a risk on anything under a 50% chance is pretty much a guaranteed miss.   It has been said on various forums that there are many mechanics that are affecting the probabilities that don't appear in the shown hit chance.  That sounds to me like a User Interface failure and a pretty important one at that.

Perhaps the most glaring issue of this is the arena fights at the beginning of Chapter 2.  When you have to pull off 6 hits in a row to kill the first enemy and then another 8 hits to kill the second.  Unfortunately you A) will die in 3 hits, B) Will get poisoned if you take a single hit, and C) the NPCs don't have an issue with the weighted hit dice.  Add to this the fact that you can't go back and level due to your captivity, can't buy potions (though the enemy gets 2 or 3) and lose all of your items means that you are pretty much screwed.

All in all I was pretty disappointed.  It was exactly the kind of game I wanted.  It just wasn't.

reviewText:
I won't repeat what the other reviews already said, so I keep this short:

Pro:
-Round-based strategy game (its like X-Com but with an actual story!)
-complex character builds are possible and a lot of content (there are 5 chapters but I am still in the middle of chapter 3 after 19 hours of gameplay)

Unfortunately the negative points are too much of an issue to recommend this game

Contra
-all towns kinda look the same and it gets repetive if you don't love grinding and collecting item sets
-incredibly difficult to play because of unbalanced setup ( since you can build every character the same, you basically choose between characters that can use magic and characters which dont)
-RNG makes your game so much more painful and very frustrating ( e.g. you have 2 casters who got a success spell cast of 93% but both still fail 3 times in a row which leads to an abortion of the spells; similar cases also with 95% melee hit chance and still missing several times)

I don't know what the numbers of these probabilities are for, since they do not reflect the actual probability of hit or miss, but probably its a feature and not a bug. As long as this issue is not fixed, I cannot recommend at all.

Update (after finishing the game):
Another negative point: story is extremly linear. Your choices make no difference at all, because the outcome is always the same. The choices only affects the ending you may get but you notice this only at the very very very end (if you can keep playing that long that is...)

reviewText:
This game gets so close that with a few tweaks it really could have been something special. The combat would be great if it wasn't so RNG dependent. Attacks are more limited by being able to actually hit stuff than they are about causing enough damage. Chance to hit of 65% or lower is normal for everything but a basic melee attack even when you've pretty much maxed out your character's relevant stats and weapon skill, and that 65% is actually more like 30% chance to hit because the percentage shown is just your character's accuracy. Your attack can and will still be parried or dodged half that percentage again.

You have to buff your characters with magic before they're worth a damn, but guess what. The magic has a chance of success too. So until you spend a few thousand points levelling up your mages' stats and getting them a certain ability, the highest chance of success with casting spells is ~85%. But I don't know how many times I had a mage miscast 4-5 times in a row even with a (supposedly) 80-90% chance of success.

You lose more battles because of unlucky streaks of whiffed attacks and spells fizzling out than you do from anything else.

In short, it was fun for a while, but became tedious by the end. It's worth picking up for $5 or so, because I really loved the battle set ups (there's very few boring battles because most try to do something unique and no two are the same) and the style of the game, but there's just too much wrong with it to be worth full price.

reviewText:

reviewText:
Graphics: 7/10
Music: 7/10
Animations: 6/10
Story: 8/10
Humour: 8/10
Replayability: 9/10
Naurim's voice acting: 11/10

I'm so glad I bought this game even though it had rather mediocre reviews on Steam (don't know rly why).

Blackguards is a turn-based RPG taking place in Aventuria world (Dark Eye franchise) where the main protagonist is accused of murder and must find a way how to redeem himself.

I have played 80 hours so far and still have not finished the game (which is huge).. but I must admit I rerolled my main character couple of times just to try out new skills/approaches. :)

I love the story. I love the quests. I love the in-game humour - I dare to say the humour is even better than in Borderlands 2. It's not so forced and it's generally cooler. :D

You lead your party of loveable outlaws throughout a dangerous world and you are balancing on a narrow edge of legal and illegal behavior. Don't expect any clichés. These guys are not your normal do-gooders, but you will love them. :D

Chapter 1 and 2 are very linear but that changes in Chapter 3 which is huge and has lots of side quests. The game can be  (sometimes) pretty difficult even on normal difficulty and you WILL have to use your brain (or Google). :D

The game is not likely worth the full price (39.99 EUR) which is a bit overpriced but I would definitely recommend buying it for 15-20 EUR on sale. You will spend hours and hours playing it.

Even though there are only 3 classes in Normal game mode to pick, you can always switch to Expert game mode and create a new game and a hero from scratch.
You will be able to create your champion as a mix of warrior/mage/hunter with emphasis on various skills/abilities and talents of your liking.

If you like turn-based RPG's or strategies with a good story, I highly recommend you buying this game.
