reviewText: I have really been enjoying Blackguards.  I love turn based combat but most of the other similar games I've found have you manage squads.  Here you manage a band of adventures with your main focus on a single party member.  The combat is challenging and the graphics are beautiful.  Between combat it feels like more like a point and click adventure which is a novel concept I really enjoy.  The story isn't particularly complex but feels well told and engaging.\n\nThere are a few small bugs in the UI I've come across but nothing that impedes game play.  I'm hard pressed to think of any other game like it and I'm looking forward to future DLC's in the series.

reviewText:
Bloody brilliant. There are some seriously bizzare negative comments on this game but let me clarify some points.

1. Does it have a plot? Yes. Is it linear? Yes. Does it matter? Not really.
2. Is the interface aweful? No not in the slightest, you can choose between a right click menu or a standard button bar.
3. Is it full of bugs? No, the bugs like the character inventory head and feet images in the wrong place has been fixed.
4. Is the character creation and character sheet bad? No, actually its very good. You spend 10-15 mins reading everything and realise there is so much death there are lots of replay options to have a different game. Its essentially D&D stats. Played Baldurs Gate, Diablo or any other game like that and its simple, intuitive and in this case, very good.
5. Its all combat, is this bad? Not really, I enjoy limited dialogue and lots of fighting. Baldurs Gate 1&2 are mostly this and they are cult classics. How good was The Banner Saga, I mean we all loved the talking but the hexed passed fighting where was it all was. This is that game on steriods.
6. Is the fact the game based on a roleplay system a problem? No its actually its strength as it has lots of depth. You can turn the battle log to simple mode if you like or you can have the log go mad with the dice rolling detail. (I turn it off).

Its a damn fine enjoyable game, the fact the scenery is a part of the game (Giant birds dropping rocks, crates being knocked over, tenticles from a monster breaking walkways, oil being set on fire, slippery mud, quicksand and bogs) makes this an awesome and unique experience.

reviewText: Very refreshing, classic strategic RPG!  In a world filled with games that have RPG elements and say they are RPG's, Daedalic has finally got it right! The story is engaging and, like the old SSI D&D games, lets your imagination fill in the rest!  You earn what loot you get and the character development is in depth almost to a fault.  Battles are turnbased and fun and you have to manage your resources.  This game will not be for everyone, though.  The demo is coming, so try before you buy.  Well worth the investment, if you love traditional cRPG's!

You go to the main map screen different cities and town, and areas of interest, but there is no in game screens of wondering through the woods or anything.  All exploration is done in areas other than cities with a simple overlay of your icon lines leading to circles with events where you fight, and only fight.  Combat is a whole other thing entirely mostly coming down to you see that little 90% hit chance on the icon to attack nah not gonna happen".  I've had dozens of time where I will have a 90% or 95% chance to hit an enemy and miss more often than a character with a 65% to hit; it is the most extreme level of riduclous. reviewText:
Overall it seemed like an interesting game.
The combat is what I dig for and the huge charactercustomization is just the thing I like.

But it pains me how the companion are handled.
Basically every other character than your main/self-created-one has predetermined stats, which cannot be reset.
So you're more or less stuck with what the game gives you, instead of developing the team that you want to play.
You can also lose companions midway through the game, for the sake of the story, which makes it even harder to have complete control over your team.

The story seems decent and the combat is okay, but It would have been better just giving us overall predetermined characters, included our starting one, and make it fit the overall game, if the story was that important.

reviewText:
With the popularity of Dark Souls at the moment, difficulty seems to be the buzzword of the industry. This can be a great boon and imbues games with a sense of accomplishment and worth when done correctly. Blackguards seems difficult for all the wrong reasons, from an obtuse user interface to mindbogglingly poorly designed stats pages.
While I appreciate that any game coming from an existing Pen and Paper world will always have a higher step up for the user than most, Shadowrun earlier last year seemed to create a system both faithful and functional while Blackguards seemed bogged down in it's own mechanics.
The story is about par for course and the voice acting is quite refreshing, but it just seems like the clunky mechanics just get in the way of that experience and the difficulty wildly differs so much you bound between feeling elated and cheated every few minutes.
While people howl off the rooftops at the percieved dumbing down" of videogames
date: sometimes it has a point. Parts of the design feel snobbish
recommended: as if it wants to pat it's faithful on the back and tell them how smart and clever they are while with the other hand swatting away the "casual
hoursPlayed: filthy masses". Blackguards needs to get down of it's high horse and reduce the barriers to entry that stop it from being the good game I know underneath is has the potential to be."

reviewText:
A game with the feel of a decently run D&D campaign, well worth the money. Especially if you get it on sale like me.

The combat is usually more than just filler between story, it is part of the story and flows very well.
There is a lot of versatility in your main character (mage/fighter/archer) and secondary characters as well.

The skill point system is a bit unclear at times, but if you save often you can always go back and change something that wasn't as good as you thought it would be.

Remember, though, that spells will not be great at first -- you'll have to use points carefully to make a good character.

The story is also very engaging, and voice acting is quite good too -- for the most part.

And side-quests: plenty of interesting little adventures to explore, and skill points to earn.

All said, this is one of my favorite games from recent years, and I highly recommend the experience.

reviewText:
Before playing this game I spend some time with Blackguards2, and ultimately decided to wasn't worth my time.  I fired up Blackguards 1 to see if the original got it any better.  Surprisingly, the first game has a better pace to it, things move along a bit faster and the story gets way.  The protagonists seems more interesting, at least to me, and my crew is certainly an improvement.

Ultimately, the gameplay is still just so slow.  The combat and movement crawls like a snail.  Other titles like Banner Saga have succeeded quite well with turn-based combat.


Pros
144hz support
Decent graphics, art tends to look reasonably good, it will immerse you.
It’s better than Blackguards2
Cons
Even though the game is turn based it needs to allow the user to speed things up a bit.  It takes far too long time to accomplish anything in the game
No camera rotating?  Some objects are placed behind others with an obscured view.  It's not an isometric game so this is seemingly pointless limitation.
Combat doesn't seem to have a lot of strategy to it.

reviewText:
Blackguards is an interesting concept with quite poor execution. The main problem is that it's built around an obscure role playing system that is both punishing and not fun. It's based on the Dark Eye role playing system in Germany. It's a fairly punishing system that gives too much power to the RNG and not enough to the player.

What do I mean by that?

It's just no fun having a 50/50 chance of casting a spell fail 6 or 7 times in a row and that costing you a battle. It's luck, not tactics or skill, that will get you through battles and luck doesn't make for a fun game. The tactics" are minimal and your choices in leveling a character are severely restricted because if you don't take certain paths with certain classes you simply won't be able to proceed through the battles. This is the core problem with the game. It's like playing chess with an RNG. It simply defeats the purpose.

The game wants you to play it one way. It discourages experimentation and creativity while demanding that you play it the "right" way with the "right" skill and classes or woe to the user. This isn't a strategy game but more of a puzzle and one that's not fun to piece together. Either you read a guide or you will be forced to start over at some point. That's just really poor design.

As for the other aspects of the game
date: consider me unimpressed. The voice acting is truly horrible and the plotline is both forgettable and so dumb as to be insulting to the player. You can't rotate the camera and often enemies are obscured. The graphics are decent but nothing fantastic. The videos stutter and tend to happen too often.\n\nWhen it comes right down to it
recommended: there's really nothing redeeming about Blackguards beyond the fact that when you finally uninstall it you'll clear up 17GB of hard drive space to use for something better. You'll get better tactics out of King's Bounty and Divinity: Original Sin than this game plus better exploration and more personality. Save your money
hoursPlayed: buy those and you'll have far more fun than you would with this game."

reviewText:
I was not certain whether I will like it or not due to some negative reviews on the  board complaining

1. random battle results
and
2.  the difficulty of the game.

However, it turns out that this is one of the top 5 games I played in 2014 (including Last of Us, Distant Worlds, Dominions 3, and Tomb Raiders). If you like turn based combat in a fantasy world, this is a must. I enjoyed this game far much more than I did for UFO Enemy unknown.

I do not have any experience with the dark eye world so I browsed steam community guides (class guide was most helpful) and some forum posts. Concentration (on certain skills or spells for a character) was advised and it is really important.  I tried to max weapon talent, base stat and skill which are matched (refer community guide). Chapter 1 was a bit difficult since the system was new to me but the remaining chapters became more comfortable as I learn combinations of spells and base stats (for example, one of the  spells that I specialized requires cleverness and constitution). All the information is well presented in game. Carefully building your character not wasting points here and there is crucial. (Dont be afraid if it sounds complicated. If you play 3-4 hours, every thing becomes clearer).

Certainly, randomness is there but every RPG has that element. So it wasnt a big deal for me.

I am looking forward to Blackguards 2. Congrats Dev for a quality game.

reviewText:
As of this writing, I am at a point where I believe I am close to completing this game on the hardest difficulty. My experience thus far is that the game is well worth while, and I would recommend it to any fan of tactical RPGs. This review will cover positive aspects of the game, negative aspects of the game (and why they don't matter much), and advice for potential adventurers.

Positive aspects:

First and foremost, the leveling system is vast. You are confronted with tons of options right at the outset, which provides a good degree of clarity about how to plan your path. It is definitely viable to create hard class archetypes, and is likely also viable to create more versatile heroes. There is a solid mix of cheap levelling options that help do what you want your character to do now, and choices that allow you to transition to new skills later.

Second, the tactical combat is varied enough to prevent approaching all battles in the same way. Differences in enemy types  and compositions, apparent environmental attributes, hidden environmental objects, and varied victory conditions  all help to keep things fresh. Depending on these scenarios, I've had success with tactics involving methodical advancement, bait and run, divide and conquer, run and gun, and defensive walling. I imagine that if you built for it, you could plan to finish some battles with ranged attacks before the enemies even reach you.

In addition, it is worth mentioning a few things other than the core gameplay. The story is well-told and evenly-paced, and is compelling enough to justify the  constant fighting. The music is solid (though repetitive). And the world map is easy to navigate.

Negative aspects:

First, the graphical quality for character models is a little poor when seen up close. Characters don't look quite right facially, and when they talk you can even see that they don't have an inside to their mouths. Character portraits look little like their polygonal counterparts. While this can be offputting, it is not so apparent in battle view, and is not a major detriment.

The only other negative point is the tedious exploration. While map exploration is simple, it is a tedious point-and-click affair. Finding a quest sometimes means visiting each town (many of which look and feel the same) on the off-chance that it will have one, and clicking through each of the people to make sure. Because this is quickly accomplished, it is not a huge drawback, but it is a boring aspect of the game.

My advice:

Some helpful pointers for those who do choose to buy this game (my first piece of advice is that you do) are below:
- Start with a notion of what you want each of your characters to do, and focus solely on that at first (melee vs. ranged vs. magic, choice of weapons, choice of spells). Plan to branch your characters out later.
- It is probably best to make your starting character a magic user, even if you don't plan to focus on spells right away. I don't feel particularly disadvantaged by not having done so, but I can see how an additional magic user could be helpful down the road.
- Don't focus on magic for your starting character, even if you make them a magic user. You will get other characters, and you probably don't need more than one pure mage.
- Magic users aren't great early on, but focusing on healing first is a big help to boosting their early-game usefulness without taking away from long-term viability.
- You will want at least one ranged character, and it will be obvious at a few points in the game who can fill that role.
- Stats and skills that accomplish more per turn/action are more valuable than capacity stats like HP and Astral Points.
- Gold matters a ton in the early parts of the game, and not at all after. Your priority spending should be on the best weapons you can find, followed by set armor.
- It is okay to skip a quest you're not ready for. Some builds can't handle some scenarios, and you may need to level up a little more to take it on. This is a likely but infrequent occurrence. As far as I can tell, quests don't disappear just by waiting.
- Don't be afraid to re-roll and start over. It is tempting to try different things, and you may discover early in the game that your build isn't working like you wanted. Your second try will be much improved.

Thank you for reading, I hope it was helpful, and please let others know whether or not you found this review informative.

Peace!
AFoolToFollow

reviewText:
6.5/10

Blackguards is a decent turn-based tactical RPG with gameplay mechanics based on The Dark Eye, which is basically the German equivalent to Dungeons and Dragons.  But unlike most games based on D&D, Blackguards (and most TDE games) is based on a relatively low-magic world.  This and some other things makes me think that TDE was perhaps not the best ruleset to base the game's engine on.

THE GOOD
-Challenging difficulty
-Characters are cliche, but well written
-Battlefields are almost always unique for each battle

THE BAD
-Needlessly complex character customization with very linear results
-Extremely frequent loading times
-Occasional chore-like battle
-Story falls flat

Blackguards plays like a more linear King's Bounty, except more linear and with actual party members instead of squadrons of soldiers.  I played Hard Mode on my first playthrough I found it to be very challenging; the game punishes you greatly for building characters incorrectly, doing poorly in certain battles (because you don't get healed for the next at!), and picking the wrong fights at the wrong time.  However, there is a good amount of diversity in game objectives and the battlefields are mostly unique for each battle.

Strategy in this game favors positioning above all else, because the strongest abilities in the game belong to melee and rangers whose primary attack abilities have no cooldowns and insignificant downsides to their use.  Mages are primarily support characters, and their best spells simply involve turning your melee guy into an even stronger skill spammer.  Had they used a different ruleset or made one of their own, they could have improved the strategy element of the battle system.  If you're going to make a turn-based strategy RPG, isn't strategy a lot of what the whole idea is about?

Don't expect the same kind of class diversity that D&D games have.  Despite the complexity of TDE's character customization, there isn't a lot of customization to be done.  Blackguards doesn't take a lot of steps to simplify the rules, but despite all of the little things the player must keep track of, the end result is almost always the same; melee and ranged guys hit hard, mages either cast support spells or suck.

Load times are unnecessarily frequent.  The game features a lot of cities, most of which don't have much unique to offer, yet trying to find quests in them involves watching a loading screen for each one.  It gets ridiculous because some of the cities have more than one section, with each section requiring even more time at the loading screen to move around to.

It was suggested by previews that Blackguards would set the player in the role of being the bad guy" or at least the guy most people think is the bad guy.  The story even sets itself up with an intriguing mystery of laser guided amnesia

reviewText:
This game somehow made me feel nostalgic for the first turn-based combat rpg I played as a kid, which was Farland Tactics 3. This is a good thing since I can hardly get into most games these days, but this one sucked me right in.

I happened to love the town overview and simplified map where I only need to click the things I need without needing to walk around and finding things. This helped me to focus on combat, while the town illustrations and some dialogues from the overview gave me a sense of adventure at the same time.

The difficulty is perfect when I played this on hard - a little challenging but rewarding. Also, the combat does depend on luck quite a bit, but I felt like this kept me at the edge of my seat.

Character creation and development was simple and intuitive. I didn't need to spend time trying to figure out how to build my characters by looking up at numerous guides, so it made me focus on my own game.

All in all, this game was what I was looking for. If you love turn-based combat while being able to have some rpg experience without certain tediousness that comes with rpgs, this would be it.

reviewText:
Blackguards is an interesting turn based game. It is ultimately focused more on preparation than on actual strategy in combat. Generally speaking basic resource management and a bit of luck when it comes to the (sometimes infuriating) RNG will win fights.
I found the poison & trapping elements of Blackguards to be more to it's detriment than benefit, with poisons and traps being prohibitively expensive both in terms of currency and the use of a turn to apply them and a belt slot to carry them. Most enemies are immune or highly resilient to poison and trap effects, and there are many enemies which will poison you with debuffs for the whole battle if they land a hit. The only spell which works to remove poison is ineffective against the stonger poisons, which by endgame most enemies use. Overall a couple of unlucky dodge/parry rolls and a couple of unlucky attack rolls will result in your whole party being poisoned and the battle becoming much more difficult.
Blackguards has a very deep character development system, with many core stats which affect different battle stats. The game could have benefited from fewer weapon skills and perhaps a poison resistance skill, however overall I found the stat system worthwhile.
The final act is very padded - there is substatially more combat than previous acts and it can get a little dry. Overall I enjoyed my time with Blackguards but was happy to be finished - usually a sign that something that was fun in the beginning got a bit tedious.
I would say if you like turn based RPGs, give Blackguards a go.

reviewText: This is my first early access game.  I had reservations, but so far I put in a few hours into it. It's fun, there are some mechanics that are not as intuitive, and I'm early on in the game.  For instance buying weapons.  Would be nice when buying a new sword, that it would list all the characters that can use that sword and their +- stats if they were to buy that sword. Hoping for more weapon variety in upcoming patches.  The game is sufficiently challenging.  Gold is hard to come by so items you purchase can be frustrating at times. If you spent all your money on an axe, you just happen to find during the next battle for instance.  But that's the nature of the beast I guess.  The battles are a bit more like HOMM vs xcom.   Overall, I would recommend this game! Good turn based strategy games are hard to come by so lets support them!  btw Bellarita mission =  Worse most frustrating mission ever.

reviewText:
The game itself is fun and worth a full playthrough, but that's about it. The loot is pretty uninteresting, and I wish there was more things that mattered.

EDIT:
Finished one playthrough. The game story itself isn't that interesting honestly, it feels rather cut in pieces. Also, the whole 'choices' thing seems to be a trend lately mostly along with the popularity of visual novels that actually are totally based off only those choices...but if you're going to have a game that really wants a diverging story up to that level, blackguards isn't your thing.

The selling point, however, is that the battle system is awesome and pretty fun. True, it can get a bit repetitive and annoying, and perhaps easy if you're not playing hardmode. Still, the combat is solid and pretty fun.

Overall, I'd give this game a 3.5 / 5. Good enough for a single playthrough unless they come up with more updates. Is it worth the money? I honestly dunno, but I'd pay around 20 i guess. If you want this, perhaps wait for sale period or something

reviewText:
Blackguards is an interesting turn based game. It is ultimately focused more on preparation than on actual strategy in combat. Generally speaking basic resource management and a bit of luck when it comes to the (sometimes infuriating) RNG will win fights.
I found the poison & trapping elements of Blackguards to be more to it's detriment than benefit, with poisons and traps being prohibitively expensive both in terms of currency and the use of a turn to apply them and a belt slot to carry them. Most enemies are immune or highly resilient to poison and trap effects, and there are many enemies which will poison you with debuffs for the whole battle if they land a hit. The only spell which works to remove poison is ineffective against the stonger poisons, which by endgame most enemies use. Overall a couple of unlucky dodge/parry rolls and a couple of unlucky attack rolls will result in your whole party being poisoned and the battle becoming much more difficult.
Blackguards has a very deep character development system, with many core stats which affect different battle stats. The game could have benefited from fewer weapon skills and perhaps a poison resistance skill, however overall I found the stat system worthwhile.
The final act is very padded - there is substatially more combat than previous acts and it can get a little dry. Overall I enjoyed my time with Blackguards but was happy to be finished - usually a sign that something that was fun in the beginning got a bit tedious.
I would say if you like turn based RPGs, give Blackguards a go.

reviewText: What do you get when you combine a modern adveture dialogue/story with turn-based combat and an incredibly rich RPG character customization system?  Blackguards.  With the world map travelling system and tactical battlefields, Blackguards has a real old school feel to it, in a very good way.  Blackguards is a lot of fun to play and thoroughly enjoyable.  Replayability, since you control 5 simulaneous characters, is a bit iffy since you already have the opportunity to develop all types, really, and the story is pretty much the same though and through.  The only complaints I have is that the story is not as coherent as it should be at times.  Unfortunately, this is most markedly recognizable at the end of the game, when the story pretty much falls completely apart and the end game" you been promised from the beginning ("the Name") never truly materializes or wraps up.  Worse
hoursPlayed: have nothing further to do but wander the world map and its areas
voteText: completely unimpeded.  A deep dungeon or more really would have helped here."

reviewText:
I was not certain whether I will like it or not due to some negative reviews on the  board complaining

1. random battle results
and
2.  the difficulty of the game.

However, it turns out that this is one of the top 5 games I played in 2014 (including Last of Us, Distant Worlds, Dominions 3, and Tomb Raiders). If you like turn based combat in a fantasy world, this is a must. I enjoyed this game far much more than I did for UFO Enemy unknown.

I do not have any experience with the dark eye world so I browsed steam community guides (class guide was most helpful) and some forum posts. Concentration (on certain skills or spells for a character) was advised and it is really important.  I tried to max weapon talent, base stat and skill which are matched (refer community guide). Chapter 1 was a bit difficult since the system was new to me but the remaining chapters became more comfortable as I learn combinations of spells and base stats (for example, one of the  spells that I specialized requires cleverness and constitution). All the information is well presented in game. Carefully building your character not wasting points here and there is crucial. (Dont be afraid if it sounds complicated. If you play 3-4 hours, every thing becomes clearer).

Certainly, randomness is there but every RPG has that element. So it wasnt a big deal for me.

I am looking forward to Blackguards 2. Congrats Dev for a quality game.

reviewText:
As of this writing, I am at a point where I believe I am close to completing this game on the hardest difficulty. My experience thus far is that the game is well worth while, and I would recommend it to any fan of tactical RPGs. This review will cover positive aspects of the game, negative aspects of the game (and why they don't matter much), and advice for potential adventurers.

Positive aspects:

First and foremost, the leveling system is vast. You are confronted with tons of options right at the outset, which provides a good degree of clarity about how to plan your path. It is definitely viable to create hard class archetypes, and is likely also viable to create more versatile heroes. There is a solid mix of cheap levelling options that help do what you want your character to do now, and choices that allow you to transition to new skills later.

Second, the tactical combat is varied enough to prevent approaching all battles in the same way. Differences in enemy types  and compositions, apparent environmental attributes, hidden environmental objects, and varied victory conditions  all help to keep things fresh. Depending on these scenarios, I've had success with tactics involving methodical advancement, bait and run, divide and conquer, run and gun, and defensive walling. I imagine that if you built for it, you could plan to finish some battles with ranged attacks before the enemies even reach you.

In addition, it is worth mentioning a few things other than the core gameplay. The story is well-told and evenly-paced, and is compelling enough to justify the  constant fighting. The music is solid (though repetitive). And the world map is easy to navigate.

Negative aspects:

First, the graphical quality for character models is a little poor when seen up close. Characters don't look quite right facially, and when they talk you can even see that they don't have an inside to their mouths. Character portraits look little like their polygonal counterparts. While this can be offputting, it is not so apparent in battle view, and is not a major detriment.

The only other negative point is the tedious exploration. While map exploration is simple, it is a tedious point-and-click affair. Finding a quest sometimes means visiting each town (many of which look and feel the same) on the off-chance that it will have one, and clicking through each of the people to make sure. Because this is quickly accomplished, it is not a huge drawback, but it is a boring aspect of the game.

My advice:

Some helpful pointers for those who do choose to buy this game (my first piece of advice is that you do) are below:
- Start with a notion of what you want each of your characters to do, and focus solely on that at first (melee vs. ranged vs. magic, choice of weapons, choice of spells). Plan to branch your characters out later.
- It is probably best to make your starting character a magic user, even if you don't plan to focus on spells right away. I don't feel particularly disadvantaged by not having done so, but I can see how an additional magic user could be helpful down the road.
- Don't focus on magic for your starting character, even if you make them a magic user. You will get other characters, and you probably don't need more than one pure mage.
- Magic users aren't great early on, but focusing on healing first is a big help to boosting their early-game usefulness without taking away from long-term viability.
- You will want at least one ranged character, and it will be obvious at a few points in the game who can fill that role.
- Stats and skills that accomplish more per turn/action are more valuable than capacity stats like HP and Astral Points.
- Gold matters a ton in the early parts of the game, and not at all after. Your priority spending should be on the best weapons you can find, followed by set armor.
- It is okay to skip a quest you're not ready for. Some builds can't handle some scenarios, and you may need to level up a little more to take it on. This is a likely but infrequent occurrence. As far as I can tell, quests don't disappear just by waiting.
- Don't be afraid to re-roll and start over. It is tempting to try different things, and you may discover early in the game that your build isn't working like you wanted. Your second try will be much improved.

Thank you for reading, I hope it was helpful, and please let others know whether or not you found this review informative.

Peace!
AFoolToFollow

reviewText:
6.5/10

Blackguards is a decent turn-based tactical RPG with gameplay mechanics based on The Dark Eye, which is basically the German equivalent to Dungeons and Dragons.  But unlike most games based on D&D, Blackguards (and most TDE games) is based on a relatively low-magic world.  This and some other things makes me think that TDE was perhaps not the best ruleset to base the game's engine on.

THE GOOD
-Challenging difficulty
-Characters are cliche, but well written
-Battlefields are almost always unique for each battle

THE BAD
-Needlessly complex character customization with very linear results
-Extremely frequent loading times
-Occasional chore-like battle
-Story falls flat

Blackguards plays like a more linear King's Bounty, except more linear and with actual party members instead of squadrons of soldiers.  I played Hard Mode on my first playthrough I found it to be very challenging; the game punishes you greatly for building characters incorrectly, doing poorly in certain battles (because you don't get healed for the next at!), and picking the wrong fights at the wrong time.  However, there is a good amount of diversity in game objectives and the battlefields are mostly unique for each battle.

Strategy in this game favors positioning above all else, because the strongest abilities in the game belong to melee and rangers whose primary attack abilities have no cooldowns and insignificant downsides to their use.  Mages are primarily support characters, and their best spells simply involve turning your melee guy into an even stronger skill spammer.  Had they used a different ruleset or made one of their own, they could have improved the strategy element of the battle system.  If you're going to make a turn-based strategy RPG, isn't strategy a lot of what the whole idea is about?

Don't expect the same kind of class diversity that D&D games have.  Despite the complexity of TDE's character customization, there isn't a lot of customization to be done.  Blackguards doesn't take a lot of steps to simplify the rules, but despite all of the little things the player must keep track of, the end result is almost always the same; melee and ranged guys hit hard, mages either cast support spells or suck.

Load times are unnecessarily frequent.  The game features a lot of cities, most of which don't have much unique to offer, yet trying to find quests in them involves watching a loading screen for each one.  It gets ridiculous because some of the cities have more than one section, with each section requiring even more time at the loading screen to move around to.

It was suggested by previews that Blackguards would set the player in the role of being the bad guy" or at least the guy most people think is the bad guy.  The story even sets itself up with an intriguing mystery of laser guided amnesia

reviewText: A good hexagon based rpg, decent visually, with a fun storyline, my only primary complaint about this game is the rng and percentage based moves appear to be broken- I'd never try to keep count of the amount of times an 80 or 90% chance of spell success would result in casting failure. That frustration aside, it's still a pretty tactical and interesting experience among rpgs.

reviewText:
This game somehow made me feel nostalgic for the first turn-based combat rpg I played as a kid, which was Farland Tactics 3. This is a good thing since I can hardly get into most games these days, but this one sucked me right in.

I happened to love the town overview and simplified map where I only need to click the things I need without needing to walk around and finding things. This helped me to focus on combat, while the town illustrations and some dialogues from the overview gave me a sense of adventure at the same time.

The difficulty is perfect when I played this on hard - a little challenging but rewarding. Also, the combat does depend on luck quite a bit, but I felt like this kept me at the edge of my seat.

Character creation and development was simple and intuitive. I didn't need to spend time trying to figure out how to build my characters by looking up at numerous guides, so it made me focus on my own game.

All in all, this game was what I was looking for. If you love turn-based combat while being able to have some rpg experience without certain tediousness that comes with rpgs, this would be it.

reviewText:
Starts solid, fizzles BAD later.

Balckguards is challenging tactical RPG great focus on tacital, the characters strenghts are based of of the skill points you allocate into different areas such as weapon profficancy and constitution, and to note you can only carry four items per character in battle that includes arrows.  Combat is the typical turn based Hex grid goto but this is when the game can be a pain, traps are invisible of course you can take an action to scan the area around you for them, BUT to scan furthur areas you must move another character into the area avoiding the traps that are reveal. Movement is crap, the Hex grid makes thing wonky and you end up having the character accidentally move through a trap, inflicting damage, possible status effects, and ending their turn. If you don't end up walking through a trap on your way to the empty space you will likely hit a trap that is still hidden. Also the  AI opponents know where the traps are so unless it plays stupid and tries to make it's way to a weakend ally it will almost never hit them.

I am saddend by this spike in difficulty but if you enjoy masocistic gaming feel free but other wise avoid.

reviewText: For a game stripping down RPGs down to the basics - combat encounters - it sure does a tremendously bad job. The combat UI is clunky as hell. You cannot turn map apparently, so every obstacle on the map is also an annoying obstacle for your mouse and eyes. The game loads a lot and I have no idea why, because the graphics are not anywhere near current single player games standard, but rather low on the MMORPG scale even. Inventory management really sucks a lot, not too mention quirky little fun things like characters using bandages to cure lasting injuries only on themselves - means you cannot reliably heal with a character you build for such stuff. This game is a big disappointment, if you want DSA nostalgia, buy the very old Nordland-Triology, still better and technically more adapt than this here. Certainly not worth the price of a AAA-game, which sadly it features.

reviewText:
Shame really, there's a good / great game desparate to show itself among the mess that overrides it. The balancing is just wrong for me in this (as others have said) and it's never a good sign when you have to change difficulty just to have a chance at doing a quest (save person in 4 combat moves with 9 men on you, hidden traps and objects / said men blocking path for instance even having done all side quests).

It also doesn't help when your playing an excellent turn-based combat game at the same time that gives you freedom and reward in levelling and experimentation like Divinity Original Sin (just buy that!) where while challenging the rewards match the effort and the party feel capable against all odds (not missing 4 out of 6 times on a 85% swing) and complement each other truly.

So in closing if you don't mind shifting difficulty or following a strict guide to levelling / using characters etc (all of which feel cheap as your not making your own choices / victories) then go for this otherwise go for suprior alternatives like the excellent Divinity Original Sin or XCOM Enemy Unknown heck even XCOM Bureau (early days on that one but seems far more balanced / rewarding / less restrictive).

This is a game that was recommended by my games magazine. Still after reading the reviews here on steam I was not convinced so it ended up on my wish list,  I gave it at a try when it was for sale at 75%.

This is a game of tactical rpg combat but for me it gets old very fast, I want more from my rpg:s than only combat. Also since this is combat only they should at least have let you build all characters but no you can only build one, you are stuck with the rest of the team.

reviewText:
I bought this on sale for like $3. I regret buying it.

Pros:
Hex-based tactical combat
Lots of character customization
Points system for leveling skills
Environmental effects such as setting bushes on fire, slipping in puddles, or knocking stalagtites off the ceiling of a cave

Cons:
You will likely hit your opponents maybe 10% of the time. You have a hit percentage ranging from 0 to 100. This is based on your skill with the weapon, your attack stat, and the level of the creature you're attacking. This does not take into account their ability to dodge or parry. A character (opponent or ally) can parry the first physical attack against them each turn. They can dodge any number of attacks per turn. So, if you have a 90% chance to hit, it is then further reduced behind the scenes by their dodge rating, and again by parry if they have not yet been hit. If you have anything less than say, 80% chance to hit, it may take you dozens of turns to end a battle that could have ended in like 6.

Enemies at the beginning of the game hit every hard, and rarely miss. You can increase your dodge and parry ratings through skills, but at character select you can't exactly make it huge. This would be fine, if it weren't for the fact that enemies can quite often hit for 10-15 damage, while your character only has about 30 health. Early game you only have 3 party members, and very often face off against 5+ enemies. It's easy to get swarmed, so using choke points is a must-- at least it would be if the majority of the levels they put you in weren't open rooms.

Cover doesn't seem to do anything. One of the earliest tips you get is that you are harder to hit in partial cover, and even harder to hit in full cover, like behind a tree. Archers have no trouble hitting you from the full length of the map behind full cover for 5-8 damage a turn, and it will take at least 2 or 3 turns to be able to reach them.

Some quests/scenarios are outright impossible if you try them too early, and the game has no qualms about sending you to your death. A good example of an early scenario in this game is facing a Wood Troll (like a treant). It has a ton of health and does a lot of damage (like 15-20 per hit), but it's slow and in a gaseous swamp. You can stand in front of a gas pocket and  use a fire spell or torch on the gas to explode it a few times to win the fight. You could do this at level 1 if you wanted, but an uninformed player would try to rush it and die quickly.

A bad example is later on. You fight some dwarves in an arena. They have a lot of health, do a lot of damage, and can move as far as you. You're *supposed* to use the same method as the Wood Troll. Stand in front of the mace trap before it activates, lure the enemy into it, and do most of the damage through the trap. My issue is I was underleveled, and there was no way for me to know this until it was too late. The enemy dodged 100% of my attacks, knocked down a character per turn, and the melee dwarf hit for 15+ damage per turn plus 5 poison per turn while 2 of my characters had ~30 hp, and one with 46. The melee dward also parried the trap that was supposed to deal the damage to him each turn, so he was functionally invincible. I tried at least a dozen times, looked online, and saw the only real way to win the fight is to ignore the mission until you had another party member and were a little more leveled. Looking at my saves, I had one auto save right before the fight, a quick save right before the fight, and a manual save about an hour and a half prior (Which isn't the game's fault, but frustrating nonetheless).

You can't level skills without finding a trainer, even if you meet the pre-requisites to unlock it, or had the option to learn it during character creation. If I don't spend at least one point into the mend wounds ability at character creation, I cannot learn it until much later when I find the right trainer. I would understand for some skills, but for the basic levels of some passive abilities or skills it doesn't make much sense.

Overall, the game is difficult for the sake of being difficult, but not in a way that self improvement can make it any easier. Unlike an action game like Dark Souls, dying isn't always the result of you ♥♥♥♥ing up. A lot of the time, it's because a creature rolled the highest it possibly could 3 turns in a row, or all 3 of your characters missed every single roll 3 turns in a row. If you're okay with restarting a mission over and over just to beat it, or to avoid getting knocked down and started on fire before your first turn, go for it. If you're as easily frustrated as me at a game where RNG is the core mechanic of the game, avoid it, even for $3.00

reviewText: Blackguards was released over a year and a half ago and it STILL hasn't worked out all the bugs (First series of lizard fights, I could take out the first crystal with melee or ranged, but the second crystal doesn't allow a ranged OR magic attack, only melee. Either way you look at it, there's a bug in there), a sequel has been released before the first one was balanced correctly (apparently a foot of water has a 75% chance of knocking over someone walking through it - total bullsh!t), and the devs didn't fix NUMEROUS complaints that I've read about on forums (You have a fixed AP pool as you play the game, if you pick the wrong skills to level then you literally and I do mean literally F yourself right into a corner and are completely unable to recover unless you want to start over. Random battles on already-completed maps would be an easy fix for this but apparently the coding team is too lazy to put in the work to make it happen)......I'm glad I got this game for 4 bucks and waited for the sale. I won't make that same mistake on the sequel. Uninstalled. I had high hopes for this game but when the devs don't fix problems and the game clearly has balancing issues, there's no way I'm going to waste more time and effort trying to play it or bothering with a sequel.

reviewText:
It is a good purchase if you can buy it for $20 or less.

Game style is squad turned base tactical strategy and has a lot of customization within normal high fantasy.  You have the ability to play Fighters, Mages and Archers of varrying types.

Fighters - two-handed, dual weild, sword and board, single handed
Damage types - slash, bash and penetration

Mages - Customization is really based on your ability to find and afford training the spells.  They start out weak, mid game are super powerful and in the end of the game are better at buffing your Master Archer and Two-Hand DPS meleer

Archers - You get 4 skills, 2 early on, extra damage shot, bypass armor shot and then later 3 arrows dps on single target (highest damage I can find in game) and then AoE rain of arrows.  Past that there is 1 good bow in game and Crossbow users can use those abilities it seems so 1 archer should do.  My main character was my archer.

If you like turned base squad tactical games this is decent but to me not worth $40, I would wait for a sale and get it at $20 or less if possible.  I did so at the last Winter Sale.

reviewText:
I could not safely recommend this game to anyone, because I'm not sure who it appeals to, and this is why:

1.  It's certainly not for rpg gamers because at its core, Blackguards is nothing more than a series of battles, one after the other, with the 'choice' being where you're going to fight next and a brief respite in 'towns' that are no more than venues to heal and restock between fights.

2.  Strategy gamers will find the combat tacky and repetitive because it always comes down to enemies trying to overwhelm you with odds with very simplistic AI.

3.  It can't possibly appeal to people looking for a great story because the story is clearly an afterthought.  You get brief looks into your characters pasts between drawn out combat sessions but there's no real development.  Things just happen and force you into the next fight.

So really, who was this game made for?

reviewText: Blackguards has issues. As an avid fan of turn based games, this is severely lacking. Inconsistency is the biggest flaw. reviewText:
Having worked on turn-based RPGs in the past professionally and as a fan of them, I am open to enjoying an imperfect game. Blackgaurds has decent graphics and gameplay and I enjoy the battles that require real thinking to resolve. I can also appreciate the aspect of the game where you need to be very careful how you expend your experience because there is a fairly linear event horizon and if you have mispent too many points you may not be able to win the next fight.

What I very much do not appreciate about the game are the various idiotic things you need to do to stay alive where you aren't really roleplaying, you are trying to beat the ganme:

1. You dont seem to be able to buy a potion of healing and just drink it. You need to enter a fight then waste your time drinking it.

2. I have mana regenration and healing (basically over time unlimited healing) I can sit in a fairly safe town but need to entera fight to regenerate mana. I would be fine with this in an arena with 10 seconds between fights but in the narrative I have hours to lounge around the town. However, I cant heal myself even though I have the ability.

3. When you have a character with a healing spell and mana regeneration, you have to sit around with one monster left hitting one character (or behind a force wall) as your mana regenerates and you heal. You spend 40 turns getting your mana and health up to full.

All in all an okay game. I cant really get into it thought because I spend too long having to game the system.

reviewText: Blackguards really opens up as you proceed through it, there's a lot of great content here. In the game though, the traditional aspects like the resting and healing really show through, reminding us why we moved on from some of these mechanics. You are not going to enjoy this game if you don't have a passion for this type of combat system. Make sure you like this kind of combat before you purchase the game. For me, I love it, because I love the hex based strategy gameplay. This game is going to be a hit or a miss between different player types, a niche audience is going to truly love this game while other players may feel a bit intimidated and put off by the pacing. reviewText: Blackguards is a full game for a fair price, which is a rarity these days.  No silly DLC or micro-transactions.  Just a solid, fun, tactical game for one price.  The game, based on a German pen-and-paper RPG system has a deep stat system, and great tactical battles.  It lacks real exploration, and the plot is on-rails, but servicable. This is a great game, no doubt about that.

Every battle location is custom drawn.

reviewText:
Blackguards is a very interesting TBS game. You take on the role of a criminal that has been accused of murder and your ultimate goal is to escape the people that are after you and find out exactly what happened to you... and probably save the world.

You can pick from a roughly customizable melee fighter, an archer, or a mage to start out with and you will acquire a melee fighter and a mage in your party after the first couple of fights. You do not get your 4th party member, an archer,  until about half way through chapter one.

The fighting is actually strategic with being able to move and take an action, move further but not be able to take an action that turn, or wait and the rest of that characters turn will move to the end of the queue for that turn. There are a lot of things that can be interacted with in the battles for various effects, such as lighting things on fire to cause damage to anything moving through them, activating traps, or removing items that are giving enemies buffs.

There is the occasional difficulty spike, but if you think strategically you can work around them. Your choices also have at least short term consequences, and possibly long term ones. Enemy AI can be used against them, which is a bit sad to watch occasionally. It is a bit disappointing watching as the enemy stands in the same spot turn after turn and takes trap damage because one of your characters is standing one spot over and within melee range.

Character interactions are amazingly fun. The stock melee character you get at the start of the game is very gruff, and will shout out lines if you heal him with magic, just as an example. The dialog outside of battle is just as fun, with one of the characters being obviously very self-serving and causing a bit of trouble because of it.

Skill trees seem to be fairly balanced, but within the first couple chapters of the game having an archer or 2 is a godsend. My archers have probably taken out more enemies than my melee fighter, so I make sure I am very well stocked on arrows. Mages start out very weak, and don't pick up until they get some levels on their skills to improve their accuracy.

Now the bad, some of the encounters are annoying or just outright boring. I hate seeing crypt lice because they're boring to kill. Another couple instances had me defending an endless stream of helpless NPCs until they got through a gate, and the enemies respawn until a certain number of NPCs get out of the gate. Boring, tedious, and not very fun... especially when the respawning enemies have a throw attack that is capable of instantly killing the NPCs on an unlucky roll. Money is not exactly easy to come by early on and items are EXPENSIVE. So you will be getting a lot of your gear through drops for a fair bit... and enemies drop weapons far more often than armor.

Good game, definitely worth checking out, especially if you are a fan of the TBS games.

reviewText:
Blackguards

Blackguards eschews the traditional “you are the hero!” trappings of most games and instead places you into the shoes of escaped convicts. Granted you are still on a quest to save your world, but you do go about it in a slightly different manner. Does the game differentiate itself enough from similar competitors, or should it have remained in solitary confinement? Suppose you’ll have to read on to find out eh?

Let’s be honest, if you have enough interest in the game to have happened upon this review then you’ve probably seen a couple of videos. From there we can assume you know what kind of art style is at play here. It’s dark, it’s got a lot of browns and grays, and it’s a high-fantasy setting. Dwarves, mages, swords and archers are all present. This is all to be expected, so we won’t cover the art beyond that. It’s pretty generic but it does the job. So we’ll go ahead and move on to cover something you’re more interested in instead.

The gameplay! This is what you were looking for, right? It’s alright. You don’t have to be ashamed that you skipped directly to this section. I won’t hold it against you. I’ll still tell you all about the game and help you decide if it’s worth the price or not. Let’s begin shall we? Blackguards is an isometric turn-based strategy game with all the expected trappings that come along with it. You begin by creating a character via a fairly detailed skill/attribute tree using a preset number of character points. You may begin as either a warrior or a mage, with the mage class costing you extra points to unlock. Points may be spent on spells, skills, attributes and upgrades for all of those. Further character points are earned by completing quests and missions throughout the game.

As you play, you collect various companions who can be fully customized in the same fashion, giving a great deal of customization options and variations to be had. Each character, including your own, is fully voice acted and animated. Though it is hit or miss, none of it is particularly bad. It certainly doesn’t detract anything from the game even if it doesn’t always add to it either. The gameplay itself boils down to what you might expect; characters act in turns based on their initiative values, which are affected by what armor you have equipped. Heavier armor lowers initiative, light armor lowers it less. It’s fairly straightforward. Combat is equally typical of the genre. During a turn you may move and attack, or move a little further and not attack. It has a bit of depth, but not so much that it needs any more detail listed here.

Where Blackguards separates itself from the pack is with its tone. You aren’t a band of heroes out to save the world. You are a band of outlaws, cutthroats and brigands who just happen to be on the path that might end with the world being saved. As a result a lot of your quests have to do with helping a party member engage in some…bedroom fun times, we’ll call it, with a local baroness. Also robbery, murder, chaos and overall mayhem. It’s a nice change of pace from the usual save this person or that thing and be all heroic that usually come in games like this.

Overall, Blackguards is a fun game. It has some downsides, being low-budget, but nothing that detracts in any meaningful way from the quality of the game. It’s worth the price of admission if you’re looking for a turn-based rpg to sink some time into. Give it a shot if it looks interesting and you like the genre. I don’t think you’ll regret it too much.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I personally fell in love with this title, the writing is some of the best I've seen/heard in a while. The combat is nice once you get used to it. and the leveling systems is really well layed out.

As for the price, personally i payed the full price for it, i don't regret it as the game has a lot of replay value as the skill set and leveling is extensive and i cant help myself wanting to see how the game would play if i played as a mage (even though i have not finished the game).

reviewText:
Blackguards

Blackguards eschews the traditional “you are the hero!” trappings of most games and instead places you into the shoes of escaped convicts. Granted you are still on a quest to save your world, but you do go about it in a slightly different manner. Does the game differentiate itself enough from similar competitors, or should it have remained in solitary confinement? Suppose you’ll have to read on to find out eh?

Let’s be honest, if you have enough interest in the game to have happened upon this review then you’ve probably seen a couple of videos. From there we can assume you know what kind of art style is at play here. It’s dark, it’s got a lot of browns and grays, and it’s a high-fantasy setting. Dwarves, mages, swords and archers are all present. This is all to be expected, so we won’t cover the art beyond that. It’s pretty generic but it does the job. So we’ll go ahead and move on to cover something you’re more interested in instead.

The gameplay! This is what you were looking for, right? It’s alright. You don’t have to be ashamed that you skipped directly to this section. I won’t hold it against you. I’ll still tell you all about the game and help you decide if it’s worth the price or not. Let’s begin shall we? Blackguards is an isometric turn-based strategy game with all the expected trappings that come along with it. You begin by creating a character via a fairly detailed skill/attribute tree using a preset number of character points. You may begin as either a warrior or a mage, with the mage class costing you extra points to unlock. Points may be spent on spells, skills, attributes and upgrades for all of those. Further character points are earned by completing quests and missions throughout the game.

As you play, you collect various companions who can be fully customized in the same fashion, giving a great deal of customization options and variations to be had. Each character, including your own, is fully voice acted and animated. Though it is hit or miss, none of it is particularly bad. It certainly doesn’t detract anything from the game even if it doesn’t always add to it either. The gameplay itself boils down to what you might expect; characters act in turns based on their initiative values, which are affected by what armor you have equipped. Heavier armor lowers initiative, light armor lowers it less. It’s fairly straightforward. Combat is equally typical of the genre. During a turn you may move and attack, or move a little further and not attack. It has a bit of depth, but not so much that it needs any more detail listed here.

Where Blackguards separates itself from the pack is with its tone. You aren’t a band of heroes out to save the world. You are a band of outlaws, cutthroats and brigands who just happen to be on the path that might end with the world being saved. As a result a lot of your quests have to do with helping a party member engage in some…bedroom fun times, we’ll call it, with a local baroness. Also robbery, murder, chaos and overall mayhem. It’s a nice change of pace from the usual save this person or that thing and be all heroic that usually come in games like this.

Overall, Blackguards is a fun game. It has some downsides, being low-budget, but nothing that detracts in any meaningful way from the quality of the game. It’s worth the price of admission if you’re looking for a turn-based rpg to sink some time into. Give it a shot if it looks interesting and you like the genre. I don’t think you’ll regret it too much.

reviewText: I'm only about 4-5 hours into it but this is great! The combat system reminds me of king's bounty, or maybe Heroes of Might and Magic where your characters are on a hex grid and you move then attack/ability. It has the feel of a proper RPG though, with various attributes/skills/powers that have points put into them that are subsequently used in the fights. The out of combat system isn't as interactive as, say, fallout 3 or skyrim or something. It's almost exclusively chatboxes accompanying a thumbnail picture of the speaker while there is a static background image, like many JRPGs (especially back in the day), and there is a map with nodes on it to which you may travel but you don't run around freely looking for stuff. Personally I don't consider that a drawback per se but others might. I can't say for sure how much your choices effect the story because I'm too early in the game, but the element of your choices mattering seems to be there, for example *spoiler* there are twin brothers that want to kill each other and you can choose if or which one you help them kill and you fight different battles and get different rewards depending on which one you choose. It's a sidequest though so I'm not certain it's a big deal.\n\nAnyway great game! Definitely worth the buy!

reviewText:
This is a game that was recommended by my games magazine. Still after reading the reviews here on steam I was not convinced so it ended up on my wish list,  I gave it at a try when it was for sale at 75%.

This is a game of tactical rpg combat but for me it gets old very fast, I want more from my rpg:s than only combat. Also since this is combat only they should at least have let you build all characters but no you can only build one, you are stuck with the rest of the team.

The layout is also in my opinion clunky and you can't rotate the map to get a better view, sometimes characters can be hard to see hidden behind objects on the map.

I cannot recommend this game but if you are really in to the tactical combat part of roleplaying games and want a challenge give it a try.

reviewText:
Saying that this is an easy game is simply a load of arrogance. This is an easy game to get into but a hard game to master. Unlike many games of this genre, Blackguards is very unforgiving and will teach you a solid lesson for every mistake you do. Every action, moves and attacks you do should not be taken lightly. Even if the odds appear in your favour, not using cover, trying to get an attack on every turn and forgetting to equip valuable potions and such will quickly turn your battle sour.

While a bit frustrating at times, I rather find this game a lot of fun. For the few hours that I've played, the storyline isn't bad and the characters are interesting. This basically a straight to the point, no BS RPG. There's no running around a village 2 hours just for the scenery. You get somewhere, talk to the npcs, get quests and you're in battle.

The difficult battles are what keeps you hooked and satisfying. This is probably more of a 90s generation type of game.

reviewText:
Start the game with two-handed sword fighter, realise everything except one-handed bashing is literally useless because that's all the game is scripted to give you.

Struggle and get to the mission where you have to rescue the Baroness, realise it's literally impossible and just try to finish by killing the enemies.

First few rounds are spent trial and error restarting to figure out there's invisible traps, and you need to start the round with a spell that has a 45% chance to destroy the boxes and set enemies on fire.

First try: Slowly skip through cutscene, wait for enemies to move, fail 45% chance spell, restart.

Second try: Slowly skip through cutscene, wait for enemies to move, fail 45% chance spell, restart.

Third try: Slowly skip through cutscene, wait for enemies to move, fail 45% chance spell, restart.

Fourth try: Slowly skip through cutscene, wait for enemies to move, fail 45% chance spell, restart.

Fifth try: Slowly skip through cutscene, wait for enemies to move, fail 45% chance spell, restart.

Sixth try: Slowly skip through cutscene, wait for enemies to move, 45% chance spell works, dwarf decides to move through 2 hexes of fire rather than one losing 20 health, take two critical hits from archer, in the end only dwarf left with 2hp and archer enemy with 22hp. Dwarf power attacks archer, deals 18 damage, archer attacks dwarf, deals 4 damage.

Stop playing. Look at achivement stats, only a quarter of people finished Chapter 1. I wonder why.

reviewText:
Where to start?
Most reviewers/trolls/noobs outright complain about the difficulty of the game, calling out bugs on things like dmg type resistance or getting knocked down because they cant figure out character builds.
if you want a game that its pretty much like click here to win, you are in the wrong genre.
if you want a game where you dont want to retry the same fight a few times to get it right, you are in the wrong genre.
This is a turn based rol-playing game, you won't get things right from the beginning withouth knowing the game beforehand.
I can almost assure you that you might screw up the builds of your party and there wont be an easy way to fix that, but thats the idea of the game, you either push through, start over or go to forums or reviews to whine like a noob because you failed to see the game manual/help/build guides.

Now if you like challenges, and turn based RPGs this one is for you, you have magic, killer snipers and swords!

bit of a spoiler if you may
you get a very functional party consisting of: A greedy sort-of-crazy dwarf, a gigollo magician, a stoner elf, a killer jungleman and a witch.
you can mold the characters as you damn well please, with some restrictions of course, but who dosnt want to have a mage in his party?

what else? main character is not gender or class locked so that gives you some freedom to choose what you want to do.

oh and yes don't forget: willpower -> def vs spells : body control -> falling/getting knocked!

reviewText:
This is a game for the hardcore.  I got Blackguards 1 & 2 for $11 on sale; I wouldn't buy it before because of the mixed reviews.

It's basically like old school King's Bounty but better.  I'm only 10 hours in, but it feels like 20, which is a good sign.  I love the customization of the character and I am annihilating ♥♥♥♥ on normal, though I've read that the game is extremely hard.  Maybe I am just hardcore.

If you like a challenge and are willing to reload, get this game.  I can't reccomend it at full price; I would never risk $40 on a game with 60% positive reviews.  If it's $8 or less, go for it.

reviewText:
Scripted mis-chances and rather insane mis-chances are just the start. (I had a 5% chance to hit a troll 7 hexes big...really? Or tried to cast a spell and had it fail 3 times with a 90% and then another 85% all in a row...which is about a 1 in a million chance I believe)  As well I at least disliked both the dialog and the leveling system which rather then letting you pick what you want if you do not go up in certain skills you will make the game impossible since there are no methods of leveling up other then the pre-set battles.  I tired with 4 different setup and every time(sometimes sooner then others) ran into a just stupidly setup battle where I would have selected a much different skill set then I had.

I did end up not playing this game much but unless it takes off(always a possibility) it seems that you are just meandering through life without much direction other then random people giving you quests that I mean go to X and have a battle...no real interesting battles other then some I get to run through enemies with everyone killing me in a time limit or press a button causing some other random thing to happen that I feel was just put there to make the battle go on longer rather then for flavor.

I am sure there are plenty of people who like this game but I just don't see why I would play this when there are so many better games out there even in this genre then this.

reviewText:
I bought this game having read a lot of the reviews. I was expecting it to be primarily centered around hex-grid combat. I knew this and dived in - I love games like HoMM and Kings Bounty. Other reviews have mentioned that the game is essentially battle to battle, with a few static village screens thrown in to try and create a background. Even so, I was expecting so much more. Everything in the game seems to have been implemented with the minimum amount of thought. There are relatively few upgradable skills and I found it fairly easy to just divide skill groups between party members and max them out fairly early in the game. Other reviewers have mentioned difficulty spikes in certain battles and this is occassionally true - some of the early battles are harder than the 'legendary' arena battles you have to overcome later on.

Actually, one of the main sticking points for me was the distinct lack of equipment - or at least variety of equipment. If the game is going to be based entirely around battles, surely you should feel like winning is going to bring some great bounty, but in the end all you get is a pair of boots and 5 coins, or whatever. There aren't even any item conditions to mix things up (rusty swards, superior buckler, etc). The amount of XP you get after a battle seems to bear very little resemblence to its difficulty either. All of this leaves the game without any reason for you to be excited or want to carry on into the next battle (apart from the inherent addictiveness of turn-based RPG combat). You feel like maybe you should be progressing the story, but I also found the story boring for the most part, apart from a few of the cut-scene events. I recently bought the Baldurs Gate 2:EE and played for a few hours, the contrast in characterisation is ludicrous - straight away I was enjoying the quips and comments from party members - while the characters in Blackguards just aren't really memorable, I found myself interested at the beginning, but raply lost interest, either through poor writing or due to the incredibly slow pace of storytelling.

Overall, I felt there weren't really any redeeming features for Blackguards - sure its graphically competent (although by no means pretty), sure the combat and strategy is acceptable (but by no means exciting or ground breaking in any way), sure the character concepts are interesting, but they just don't go anywhere. It's all a bit of a muddle really.

reviewText:
This game was terrible.

To elaborate, the game draws you in with the idea of a turn-based RPG with an unkown and intersting story and encourages the idea of character customization, dialogue options, and all that awesome stuff.

Its lies, simply said and done its all lies.

1. You will be stuck with a pre-determined 'party', with pre-determined skillsets, there is no 'designing a party'.

2. The story is predictable, you loose your memory and gotta figure out what you forgot...

3. The 'dialogue/charisma' options  while changing minor things are so few and far between there is almost no reason to do anything but SMASH and kill everything.

4. Mages can't learn new skills until you purchase books for them (which are extremely expensive, so you won't learn any new magics till mid-late game.) While I am on the topic of mages there is a checkbox at the start of the game which effective says 'magic abillity' if you select that, you get mana and can be a mage- otherwise you'll never have that option.

5. The skill tree is the same for everyone, so your sword wielding guy will go into swords and use the same 1-3 skills the entire game. (but will have extra points so he can get the same skills as your... archer!)

If you haven't decided to quickly run away from this game yet, there are more 'great' things about this game I can only hope you never find out. The ending is as bad as you think its going to be about half way through (and its almost 100% predictible from the start...).

If you haven't fled by now, you either love torture or your so dense this game might be for you (join the other <7% that have played through more than half of this game...).

If you want a game like this, go play Dragon Age I or II, Divinity (for gods sake its way better), or pretty much any other turn based RPG game.

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game.  I am a big fan of D&D and have played more RPGs than I can count.  I am also a huge fan on XCOM and that style of strategy so this looked like a match made in game heaven.

Alas it was not to be though.  Here is the good the bad and the ugly.

Good:
- Graphics are wonderful.
- Voice acting is top-notch.
- There appears" to be a lot of character customizations.

Bad:
- Storyline beats you up in the second chapter and you lose your "investment" arbitrarily.  Sad really.
- There really is a lack of "strategy" as you are at the whim of roll of the dice.  Not XCOM calibre
date:
not even close.
- $39.99?  I got is pre-release cheap.  Save your money it isn't worth that much.


Ugly:
- XCOM style strategy doesn't play as such.  Random roll really makes this a flawed game.  You can employ the exact same strategy move for move and breeze through a level
recommended: and other times get decimated.\n- There is no place to "grind" it out to build up your characters if you are so willing to do so.  Early in the game you will find yourself redoing levels because you got a bad roll and you haven't enough Ducats (money) to do what you need.\n- Some levels (first one) become closed the moment you go to another map.  There is no turning back until later.  A big map
hoursPlayed: but very linear and very unforgiving.\n\nYou have to REALLY love D&D style play to get into this game.  It will take a while to get used to
voteText: and even longer to become skilled at this game.  It feels more like work and less like fun.\n\nI would not buy this game again."

reviewText:
I would first like to pre-face this review by saying that I bought this Deluxe version and Blackguards 2 as part of the Daedalic bundle for £9.99, making each game in effect worth £4.99 to me. Based on this price I think Blackguards is definitely worth it. The full price of £29.99 is however WAY off the mark for the amount of game you get (hint: not much)

Despite me finishing the game in 40 hours, it is a very combat focused where pretty much every event you’ll encounter will be a fight. Whilst this is fun to begin with, as a lot of battle maps are quite interesting, after 20 odd hours it just got tiresome. After every cut scene, conversation, exploration, etc I knew I would be fighting something. So you can imagine my utter delight when after defeating the final boss, the final cut-scene was just that a cut-scene!

Outside of combat there is unfortunately very little to the game, hence I only recommend it at a steep discount. There is no exploration to speak off, the town screens are static and the story kind of gets lots amongst 180 fight scenes you’ll have to slog through.

I also have a few gripes about the story, but these could just be personal preferences. For example, I don’t see how this is a “dark” story as it seems very much like any other RPG where you-are-our-only-hope-to-save-the-world story (spoiler: you save it). Also this games is called Blackguards and makes the point of your character being an outlaw. I was picturing more of a vagabond, a mercenary on the run, or some petty thief down and on his luck. What I wasn’t expecting however was for my character to be buddies with a PRINCES whilst chilling at a home of a COUNT in the first “memory” cutscene. Less of a BlackGuard, more of a Brodude! Also in this game you have no meaningful choice – it really just railroads you along the main story-line with some side-quests where you have a choice between killing guy A or guy B... with no impact on main story-line.

A lot of negative reviews about this game are regarding the dodgy RNG, and whilst I have encountered some odd miss on a 95% chance, I have never experienced a 3 in a row miss. If you read the manual and understand how the rules work. The % you see isn’t the % to inflict damage, but rather to do an action, then the enemy gets a couple of saving rolls – parry / dodge. So you might have successfully rolled an action, but then the enemy might have rolled a saving throw and so all you see is your guy missing or spell fizzing out.

reviewText: This is one of those games that makes you wish there was a maybe button. I really enjoyed the first chapter of this game, the combat and the class system seemed rich. But the game really starts to go downhill from there. There really aren't a whole lot of choices to how to build your characters and the combat gets really easy after the first chapter. To be honest after the second chapter of the game it felt like they weren't putting the same amount of effort into the game at all. Many of the fights are very similar and the game basically becomes a grindfest to finish it, it practically plays itself. During the first chapter it seemed like they put effort into every sidequest. I still recommend this game if this is your sort of thing but it isn't without it's problems. I would also like to point out that many of the achivments are broken and rarely register. Also the story which seems like it might be cool at first starts to go downhill pretty fast and will seem pretty silly to most players. Overall I'd say if your willing to overlook this games flaws you won't regret this purchace but definitly don't buy this game for it's full price, wait for a decent sale. I really feel like this game had potential though, hopefully Blackguards 2 is better.
