reviewText:
I have not been so bored with a game in a very long time. Blackguards is a hex turn based rpg type game, with much less of the traditional rpg feel and much more of the board game elements. As a genre, it’s not my cup of tea but I can see why people enjoy the thoughtful strategy of it.

Playing Blackguards felt sort of like playing a chess match over and over again with the outcome being nearly entirely based on luck. Perhaps it boils down to the visuals not being all that visceral, but even things like positioning relative to the enemy seems to have no effect on combat outcomes. In the hour and a halfish I played I did little more than click on enemies and wait to either win or have to reload. It was as if the game was trying to distance itself from me.

Definitely not a recommendation on any of my lists; if I wanted a strategic RPG I’d reinstall Neverwinter Nights, if I wanted a board game I’d find a free online chess game.

reviewText:
Blackguards is without a doubt a fun game for the old-school turn-based RPG-combat interested. It feels like a solid title through and through and it has hours of fun and enjoyment in it where you will be redoing battles over and over until you find the right strategy for them and beat them easily. This is definitely a challenging game with a lot of good sides to it, but it has one major flaw, and that is that it is far from complete and full of game-ending bugs. Expect to go somewhere and not being able to play if you make that choice because the game will crash if you make that certain turn, if you were lucky you had savegames prior to that choice, if not - then you have to start all over again.

By game-breaking bugs I mean that when you reach a certain location, the game will just crash every single time you go there. Reloading the game won't help, it will continuously crash and if you had an old savegame you can get around it, otherwise you are screwed until they either fix it, or you move on to another game, alternatively give this game another try and remember what choice you made that led to the crashing.

Unfortunately this is a dealbreaker for me, and while I did have a lot of fun, I didn't get to experience the game as I played it, and I refuse to go back to change how I played just because the game is unfinished. Supposedly it's going to be done this autumn, but I doubt there will be much more development on this title, they've been releasing a DLC for it already, and announced a sequel, which is underway. It's a pity that a title that has such great core mechanics get ruined in the details, but such is the way right now.

It is quite possible that you do not run into these bugs, and have an excellent experience, but keep in mind, you might end up like me.

reviewText:
I wasn't sure what to review this game, but I thought a thumbs down would get the attention this comment merits as an OG gamer.  The biggest problem is that the harder settings make experience points go down and the mission harder...  breaking the standard expectation of harder missions and more experience that I wanted.  I don't want to go through on uber hard mode and end up with a nerfed character.

I suppose the other problem, and if you're thinking balancing trouble is the deal with the criticism, I know, I've thought of that, the problem is that you're pigeon holed into one kind of min/max or maybe two if you want to beat the game on hard.  This, to me, is not acceptable, lol.

But, also, not that the difficulty setting thing means that, when you finally have to switch back to normal to kill the gators with your incorrectly min/maxed character build, you might have to make the disgusting decision to set it to easy...  which I know a lot of gamers like me just cannot fathom, lol.

I suppose this brings me to another failure of modern gaming...  it's not like and can grind out another level in the middle of the story, which I would love to do rather than abandon my character... but why nerf my powers when I have it on hard, really...

reviewText:
Great game - FUN. I recommend this game if you like turn-based tactical RPG's. Overall the game is a fun experience. The biggest aspect of this game is gameplay and story. Other strengths such as atmosphere and tone create a nice world. Great soundtrack as well.

Couple things to point out. The world map movement is point and click/adventure, which I did not expect to enjoy so much at first. This creates a little slower pacing then I am used to in other RPG's. Just kick back and relax during world map movement and you'll learn to enjoy it.

Customization can be a gift or a curse
date:
depending on your personality. Personally, the party customization screens were cumbersome and confusing for the first 5-8 hours. If you get overwhelemed at charcter customization screen, I recommend going with the default builds, or research other builds online for direction. Try not to waste allocating points until you decide on a main build. By the end of Chapter 1 you can handle all of the customization options though. If you love stats and numbers, you will no doubt enjoy the customization. Sometimes battles take party-management prep work before you engage.

Overall the game is a good experience and I recommend it if you enjoy turn-based RPG's. Great story involvment. The game has a slower pacing, but this is not a bad thing. Just relax and enjoy the world, story, and gameplay!

reviewText:
Finished this game about 2 weeks ago.  Wish I had reviewed it sooner when it was fresh in my mind but here it goes.

The difficulty is very high and there is a ton of content to explore over 5 chapters.

Can't stress this enough.  If you are easily frustrated you may not enjoy this game.

But it sure does feel good when Naurim wins the battle with only a few points of health left, or when you manage to outrun that damn poison mist :)

Story is good, I got really into it from the beginning.  You are trying to investgate the murder of the princess and its possible you are the killer.  As you play more of the story is revealed.

Some good walkthroughs can be found online if you feel the game is too hard, but basically whatever character type you go for you need to invest in one weapon skill to at least 14-16 to avoid missing most of the time.  Also its a good idea to save your experience points until you absolutely need to spend it, and its a good idea to plan ahead what kind of skills and spells you want to invest in as experience points are limited and there is no going back once you purchase a skill.

Don't be afraid to turn the game to easy in order to enjoy the game :)  I did in some parts and its a great RPG experience.

reviewText:
This game has a lot going for it: good battles, nice RPG elements, the whole package. But it's also buggy. They're not game-detroying bugs, but they're just sloppy enough that it just makes me want to play something else until the devs patch them. Healers that don't work, screens that suddenly go eye-bleedingly magenta... it's not insurmountable, it's just not fun. Also, the game features many environmental objects that must be manipulated to succeed. They're puzzles, in a sense. But there's a thin line between something being a puzzle and something just being underdocumented or unusuable. There are a couple of times when Daedalic crosses this line. Even a spoilers page documenting what these things are would be helpfull.

With small fixes this game would rock. At the moment, why play it when there are so many other good games out there?

Daedalic has a good reputation, and I purchased this, my first Daedalic game, on the strength of that reputation. I'll think twice before buying a game of theirs again -- which is a shame.

reviewText:
So I have only played this game for a few hours, but I think what I have learned already will not change throughout the course of the game.

Blackguards is a hard, challenging game, it is most certainly fun and the voice actors REALLY make this game a story to be part of, I simply love them.
Now, don't get me wrong here, I'm all for % chances to hit, finding tactical ways to defeat the enemy and such, however I really resent the constant <70% chance to hit, and even at 70-90% I've had several times alredy where I do this action 3-4 times and each hit has missed (or failed)(not including piercing to skeletons etc.)
Therefor this game is very inconsistent in how any battle will turn out even by using the same movements and actions each time, and this kind of (almost) luck based combat makes Blackguards very hard to want to play again.

HOWEVER, I would recommend this game to anyone with the inclusion of this shortcoming.

reviewText:
This is a turn based tactics game where you control (after about 30 hours gameplay) up to 5 heroes who walk between nodes on a world map in a very linear way and follow a more or less entertaining story (At least I found some of the dialogue mildly enjoyable). Some nodes are cities where you may learn skills, buy equipment, and get/perform quests, other nodes are quest nodes that may sometimes be skipped. Most of the time is however spent in  hexagon based maps fighting various bad guys.

The game has a lot of skills and stats that you may experiment with, but mostly it makes little difference what you chose to skill up (For spells any nuke will do, some early bosses are weak to fire, but it makes little difference for most enemies, a healing spell is pretty much required, you will alternate between those two and auto attacks for the whole game), and as most stats and skills are needed in the end anyway the customization adds little depth to a shallow game.

The major problem with Blackguards is that fights are mostly based on luck. Want to attack someone? Well, usually you have a 90% chance to hit (not bad, but that's as good as it gets unless someone is knocked down), but if you use a more powerful attack it might drop down to 85%, 70%, or 60% (based on dodge stat vs dexterity I think), further reduced with wounds that are randomly obtained when taking damage (I think your to hit chance can potentially go all the way down to 30%). If you manage to hit at all the damage dealt is then further randomed in a fairly large spread, and rarely it will crit for double damage. The damage is fairly high, so 3-4 good attacks is enough to drop most enemies and heroes.
This means that missing more than a few attacks will result in one of your heroes getting knocked unconscious, and the enemies snowball from there.
It's typically the enemies who get the good dodge stats, so while your heroes will mostly take full damage from anything that attacks them late game, your heroes will miss, miss, miss,miss, and miss some more as you watch them slowly die in frustration.

The game's difficulty" slowly ramps up as you play. Every encounter is level (in)appropriate
date: so every fight is a challenge. Since spell damage is fixed your magic users slowly get weaker after their 2 main spells hit level 3. While this makes sense in a way you will never get to be satisfied with how much stronger your heroes have gotten. Enemies have about the same stats and skills and do about as much damage as the heroes do
recommended: so fights vary little in practise between various encounters.\n\nThe game could still be a mildly enjoyable grind with the above mentioned issues
hoursPlayed: but clearly the devs were obsessed with making the game into a never ending series of encounters by a power tripping DM trying to make your party lose.\nI got through several unfair fights like Running past all the enemies who get to hit you for free for 6 turns to get to the girl before she's killed
voteText: shoot a giant tree with 150 hp to death with arrows that each do 1 dmg because it 2 shots everything in melee range
helpfulPercent: run through a basement filled with traps to get to the guy you need to kill before he gets away
votesHelpful: kill the necromancer who's surrounded by unkillalbe skeletons that block your spells and arrows
votesTotal: and many many more. The straw that broke the camel's back for me was the fight against the tiger lilly where one of your heroes is turned against you
votesFunny: you have to run up to a plant that always has a 60% hit chance
commentsCount: is immune to magic damage
column16: every turn one of your heroes is knocked down
column17: and 5-6 tentacles you're not supposed to kill get to attack your heroes freely while blocking off healing spells you might want to cast on the hero being bullied.\nI understand that something like this was necessary to make the game interesting
column18: as the fights by themselves clearly aren't. With a different combat system these fights might have been fun
column19: but in Blackguards you will just keep doing the right thing again and again untill it finally works and you get to go on.\n\nSo
column20: TL;DR: Turn based fights heavily based on luck
column21: little customization in practise despite the wealth of options available
column22: you get weaker as you keep on playing
column23: and gimmicky fights where the devs metaphorically throw your miss chance and weakness in your face again and again by setting up scenarios that force you into doing stupid things over and over untill the RNG gods decide that you may finally pass. If it sounds like your cup of tea then you will probably enjoy Blackguards

reviewText:
Blackguards is an tactical turn-based RPG game that brings some new soultions and points of view to the table, that are not always good.

(New feature - Simple city interface.)
If you remember Drakensang, Dragon Age or most other RPGs cities, large, vast, many NPCs, a lot of chests to look and barrels to smash for loot. Nothing like that in Blackguards. City is a simple one screen view with most important NPCs, merchant, healer, trainer, quest giver, tavern, the end. If you have business in the city it takes you about a minute to get it done and leave to get back to action. Some might like it, some might not. I like it, as it saves time, no more need to remember where was that cool merchant or a hidden pass etc.

So you may wonder how does this tactical turn base combat looks like.
(Character summary)
Before we get there you must know that Blackguards are based on The Dark Eye RPG pen and paper system. And character development is very much like in the pen and paper game. If you played Drakensangs before you will be very familiar with the system.
In most RPG games you have classes to select. There are no classes in this game. When creating character you select if you wanna be spell-casting able or not and then you build character on skills/spells you chose. In that this system is similar to Elder Scrolls. If you wanna be a warrior you can be a warrior, if you wanna be a warrior-priest you can be warrior-priest it's all based on how to chose your skills, not limited by class.
So characters have attribiutes that calculate their base stats like vitality, astral points (manna), base attack, dodge and parry. Attriubutes cost a lot of adventure points to raise. By chosing how to spend attribiutes you craft base for your character, if you invest heavy into strength, agility, courage and constitiution you will end up with a fighter with almost no chance to cast any spell. If you go for intuition, cleverness and charisma you will end up with solid base for mage with poor fighting abilities. You can also walk the path of average, but you must be careful and just select few spells and weapons to invest in those heavy.
Keep in mind that mages are limited by metalic armor - they will not regenerate astral points while wearing even a single piece of it and will have negative casting modifier, so a melee mage is a hard to play, but possible with correct spell investment.
Then are the skills. Skills are divided into weapons, talents (perception, traps etc) and spells. And in that game every weapon is another skills, so if your character is an expert swordsman (18 swordsmanship skill), when he will be forced to use an axe, he will be very poor with ti because he has no skill in axe, he will have very small chance to hit and large to be hit by enemies.
Skills make your characters use stuff. Skills are rated from 0-18. Spells and talents unlock bonusses at 8,13,18 levels. Here you choce which spells your character can cast and weapons to use.
At the end are special abilities - special attacks for melees, ranged and boosts for mages.
The better the special attack the harder it is to hit with it.
Original pen and paper game used three 20 side dices for skill tests, to make it computer game, devs changed that into % chance. So unlike dragon age it is not enough to unlock a spell to cast it, you must unlock the spell and invest points into it.
(Note on spells)
For me spells in this game are net design to be used mainly at blunt offensive magic. Spells play a support role in this game. You can cast offensive spells and they will do a lot of damage, however doing so will deplete your astral points in two shots so after your mage will not be able to do anything else than bash stuff with his staff.
(Note on weapons)
I really love games which make using axe different than using a sword for example. Blackguards is such a game.Every weapon type has it damage type (piercing for spears and fancing weapons, slashing for swords and blunt for maces). Every weapon type also uses a different skill. So if you wanna use few different weapons you must spend points on different skills. Different weapons also have different special attacks, you cannot make armor ignoring attack with maces, but you can make attack that tripples the damage with them.

(Combat)
Having explained the above. Combat is turn based in which your heros and enemies take their turns in order of initiative. On their turn everyone can move a little and make action (attack, cast spell, place trap, disarm trap, spot for traps, use item etc) or move further. You can hide behind objects or other heros to break line of sights of enemy archers to your mages as well, there is no other cover system.
Combat map is divided into small hexes for movement and there can be varius hazard spaces on the map like oil set on fire will deal you fire damage when you cross it, while mud can make your character fall down unless he passes bosy control test.
(Tactical combat)
By using combination on magic and physical attacks you must cripple and defeat enemies. Enemies will usually outnumber you as well and some of them will also cast spells, use healing potions and have special attacks. So this is where tactic comes into place.
Use your melees to block enemies before they reach your mages, or run to enemy mage to bash on him. Use obejects on the map and magic walls to block enemy movement and shoot them directly. You have options.
Cast damage spells to finish fight quickly, or same astral points for buffing and healing magic.

(Plot - Story)
Unfortunately game story is quite linear and not really involving. Characters are a bit shallow and the only one who really feels realistic is the dwarf who is fun and really combat oriented.
At few points in the game you will be stripped of your gear and forced to make through with given equipment untill you can regain your stuff. So it is goot to invest a little into maces(as you will usually end up fighting with a torch or a club) and offensive magic.

(Flaws)
There are some flaws to the game:
-Horrible mouth work. Unlike other modern games, the speaking animations here are just horrible, you will see heros open mouth like fish trying to catch a breath, it has no connectiong with what is being spoken.
-Very bad equipment comparison system. There is no way to compare one set of armor with another other than noting down the stats, changing set and seeing new stats.
-I have really no idea what in this game make it be 20gb large.
-Game does little to introduce players who are new to the difficult character creating and developemtn system. [there is good help&tips in the menu if you can spend a moment to read and understand it]
-Not involving plot and shallow characters.
-Not intuitive UI.
-No crafting system.

(Merits)
+Realistic when it comes to weapons and armors. Armors comes in sets, so it is no longer find best pieces, but you need to wear a complete set of armor to have best benefits. And I like it that way.
+Deep and difficult tactical combat. I like the games that are not easy.
+Quick cities exploration.
+You are not limited when crafting your heros, you have a lot of freedom in systems without classes.

Overall I would give this game 7/10.
I hope most of the flaws will be corrected in the upcomming Blackguards 2.

reviewText:
I really tried to like this game, in spite of reading very mixed reviews. Alas, I ended up quite frustrated with a few aspects that are quite game (and immersion) breaking:
1. losing vital companions at crucial times makes party build options very limited. Essentially, once you figure out what will happen to X, you need to rethink your entire strategy for party build. This sometimes means restarting from scratch, or a very earlier save, as party build is very important in some of the encounters (especially the main ones)
2. lack of clothing for non-metal wearing characters - while there are several pretty good sets of armour for warriors, the (complete) lack of mage oriented outfits is a bit mind baffling. I could not fathom that no mage outfits EVER dropped, although you battle many mages wearing unique outfits. And none can be bought. As a consequence, you mage characters have to either wear horrible looking leather armour, or spend a lot of time buffing/running/dying. This is also important for...
3. almost 100% spell failure when wearing metal armour. I can accept offensive spells (cast outward) failing, but having a healing/self-buff spell have a <25% of success is nonsense. So playing as a battle mage/arcane warrior/cleric type role is pretty much out of the question
4. tedious battles - which can go on for a long time, with a lot of time sitting, and staring at the screen while seemingly endless hordes of critters/monsters/lice/etc. go thought their turns. Even tentacles get their own turns, and usually have a higher initiative than your party...
5. endgame decision disasters - going back to #1 - at the end game you find out that you are 'supposed to' have made certain vital conversation decisions with one companion, otherwise they will be lost, which as mentioned before, can be a disaster for the party.

So, if you want to play this:
a) read the guides and build a cooky cutter type that the developers had in mind, and
b) follow a pro-forma discussion template to placate one party member, or lose them at a crucial stage (or build with their loss in mind)
c) have a good book/magazine handy to read during battles, as you otherwise stare at the screen waiting endlessly

Pity, had potential

reviewText:
So I have only played this game for a few hours, but I think what I have learned already will not change throughout the course of the game.

Blackguards is a hard, challenging game, it is most certainly fun and the voice actors REALLY make this game a story to be part of, I simply love them.
Now, don't get me wrong here, I'm all for % chances to hit, finding tactical ways to defeat the enemy and such, however I really resent the constant <70% chance to hit, and even at 70-90% I've had several times alredy where I do this action 3-4 times and each hit has missed (or failed)(not including piercing to skeletons etc.)
Therefor this game is very inconsistent in how any battle will turn out even by using the same movements and actions each time, and this kind of (almost) luck based combat makes Blackguards very hard to want to play again.

HOWEVER, I would recommend this game to anyone with the inclusion of this shortcoming.

reviewText:
This is a turn based tactics game where you control (after about 30 hours gameplay) up to 5 heroes who walk between nodes on a world map in a very linear way and follow a more or less entertaining story (At least I found some of the dialogue mildly enjoyable). Some nodes are cities where you may learn skills, buy equipment, and get/perform quests, other nodes are quest nodes that may sometimes be skipped. Most of the time is however spent in  hexagon based maps fighting various bad guys.

The game has a lot of skills and stats that you may experiment with, but mostly it makes little difference what you chose to skill up (For spells any nuke will do, some early bosses are weak to fire, but it makes little difference for most enemies, a healing spell is pretty much required, you will alternate between those two and auto attacks for the whole game), and as most stats and skills are needed in the end anyway the customization adds little depth to a shallow game.

The major problem with Blackguards is that fights are mostly based on luck. Want to attack someone? Well, usually you have a 90% chance to hit (not bad, but that's as good as it gets unless someone is knocked down), but if you use a more powerful attack it might drop down to 85%, 70%, or 60% (based on dodge stat vs dexterity I think), further reduced with wounds that are randomly obtained when taking damage (I think your to hit chance can potentially go all the way down to 30%). If you manage to hit at all the damage dealt is then further randomed in a fairly large spread, and rarely it will crit for double damage. The damage is fairly high, so 3-4 good attacks is enough to drop most enemies and heroes.
This means that missing more than a few attacks will result in one of your heroes getting knocked unconscious, and the enemies snowball from there.
It's typically the enemies who get the good dodge stats, so while your heroes will mostly take full damage from anything that attacks them late game, your heroes will miss, miss, miss,miss, and miss some more as you watch them slowly die in frustration.

The game's difficulty" slowly ramps up as you play. Every encounter is level (in)appropriate
date: so every fight is a challenge. Since spell damage is fixed your magic users slowly get weaker after their 2 main spells hit level 3. While this makes sense in a way you will never get to be satisfied with how much stronger your heroes have gotten. Enemies have about the same stats and skills and do about as much damage as the heroes do
recommended: so fights vary little in practise between various encounters.\n\nThe game could still be a mildly enjoyable grind with the above mentioned issues
hoursPlayed: but clearly the devs were obsessed with making the game into a never ending series of encounters by a power tripping DM trying to make your party lose.\nI got through several unfair fights like Running past all the enemies who get to hit you for free for 6 turns to get to the girl before she's killed
voteText: shoot a giant tree with 150 hp to death with arrows that each do 1 dmg because it 2 shots everything in melee range
helpfulPercent: run through a basement filled with traps to get to the guy you need to kill before he gets away
votesHelpful: kill the necromancer who's surrounded by unkillalbe skeletons that block your spells and arrows
votesTotal: and many many more. The straw that broke the camel's back for me was the fight against the tiger lilly where one of your heroes is turned against you
votesFunny: you have to run up to a plant that always has a 60% hit chance
commentsCount: is immune to magic damage
column16: every turn one of your heroes is knocked down
column17: and 5-6 tentacles you're not supposed to kill get to attack your heroes freely while blocking off healing spells you might want to cast on the hero being bullied.\nI understand that something like this was necessary to make the game interesting
column18: as the fights by themselves clearly aren't. With a different combat system these fights might have been fun
column19: but in Blackguards you will just keep doing the right thing again and again untill it finally works and you get to go on.\n\nSo
column20: TL;DR: Turn based fights heavily based on luck
column21: little customization in practise despite the wealth of options available
column22: you get weaker as you keep on playing
column23: and gimmicky fights where the devs metaphorically throw your miss chance and weakness in your face again and again by setting up scenarios that force you into doing stupid things over and over untill the RNG gods decide that you may finally pass. If it sounds like your cup of tea then you will probably enjoy Blackguards

reviewText:
Blackguards is an tactical turn-based RPG game that brings some new soultions and points of view to the table, that are not always good.

(New feature - Simple city interface.)
If you remember Drakensang, Dragon Age or most other RPGs cities, large, vast, many NPCs, a lot of chests to look and barrels to smash for loot. Nothing like that in Blackguards. City is a simple one screen view with most important NPCs, merchant, healer, trainer, quest giver, tavern, the end. If you have business in the city it takes you about a minute to get it done and leave to get back to action. Some might like it, some might not. I like it, as it saves time, no more need to remember where was that cool merchant or a hidden pass etc.

So you may wonder how does this tactical turn base combat looks like.
(Character summary)
Before we get there you must know that Blackguards are based on The Dark Eye RPG pen and paper system. And character development is very much like in the pen and paper game. If you played Drakensangs before you will be very familiar with the system.
In most RPG games you have classes to select. There are no classes in this game. When creating character you select if you wanna be spell-casting able or not and then you build character on skills/spells you chose. In that this system is similar to Elder Scrolls. If you wanna be a warrior you can be a warrior, if you wanna be a warrior-priest you can be warrior-priest it's all based on how to chose your skills, not limited by class.
So characters have attribiutes that calculate their base stats like vitality, astral points (manna), base attack, dodge and parry. Attriubutes cost a lot of adventure points to raise. By chosing how to spend attribiutes you craft base for your character, if you invest heavy into strength, agility, courage and constitiution you will end up with a fighter with almost no chance to cast any spell. If you go for intuition, cleverness and charisma you will end up with solid base for mage with poor fighting abilities. You can also walk the path of average, but you must be careful and just select few spells and weapons to invest in those heavy.
Keep in mind that mages are limited by metalic armor - they will not regenerate astral points while wearing even a single piece of it and will have negative casting modifier, so a melee mage is a hard to play, but possible with correct spell investment.
Then are the skills. Skills are divided into weapons, talents (perception, traps etc) and spells. And in that game every weapon is another skills, so if your character is an expert swordsman (18 swordsmanship skill), when he will be forced to use an axe, he will be very poor with ti because he has no skill in axe, he will have very small chance to hit and large to be hit by enemies.
Skills make your characters use stuff. Skills are rated from 0-18. Spells and talents unlock bonusses at 8,13,18 levels. Here you choce which spells your character can cast and weapons to use.
At the end are special abilities - special attacks for melees, ranged and boosts for mages.
The better the special attack the harder it is to hit with it.
Original pen and paper game used three 20 side dices for skill tests, to make it computer game, devs changed that into % chance. So unlike dragon age it is not enough to unlock a spell to cast it, you must unlock the spell and invest points into it.
(Note on spells)
For me spells in this game are net design to be used mainly at blunt offensive magic. Spells play a support role in this game. You can cast offensive spells and they will do a lot of damage, however doing so will deplete your astral points in two shots so after your mage will not be able to do anything else than bash stuff with his staff.
(Note on weapons)
I really love games which make using axe different than using a sword for example. Blackguards is such a game.Every weapon type has it damage type (piercing for spears and fancing weapons, slashing for swords and blunt for maces). Every weapon type also uses a different skill. So if you wanna use few different weapons you must spend points on different skills. Different weapons also have different special attacks, you cannot make armor ignoring attack with maces, but you can make attack that tripples the damage with them.

(Combat)
Having explained the above. Combat is turn based in which your heros and enemies take their turns in order of initiative. On their turn everyone can move a little and make action (attack, cast spell, place trap, disarm trap, spot for traps, use item etc) or move further. You can hide behind objects or other heros to break line of sights of enemy archers to your mages as well, there is no other cover system.
Combat map is divided into small hexes for movement and there can be varius hazard spaces on the map like oil set on fire will deal you fire damage when you cross it, while mud can make your character fall down unless he passes bosy control test.
(Tactical combat)
By using combination on magic and physical attacks you must cripple and defeat enemies. Enemies will usually outnumber you as well and some of them will also cast spells, use healing potions and have special attacks. So this is where tactic comes into place.
Use your melees to block enemies before they reach your mages, or run to enemy mage to bash on him. Use obejects on the map and magic walls to block enemy movement and shoot them directly. You have options.
Cast damage spells to finish fight quickly, or same astral points for buffing and healing magic.

(Plot - Story)
Unfortunately game story is quite linear and not really involving. Characters are a bit shallow and the only one who really feels realistic is the dwarf who is fun and really combat oriented.
At few points in the game you will be stripped of your gear and forced to make through with given equipment untill you can regain your stuff. So it is goot to invest a little into maces(as you will usually end up fighting with a torch or a club) and offensive magic.

(Flaws)
There are some flaws to the game:
-Horrible mouth work. Unlike other modern games, the speaking animations here are just horrible, you will see heros open mouth like fish trying to catch a breath, it has no connectiong with what is being spoken.
-Very bad equipment comparison system. There is no way to compare one set of armor with another other than noting down the stats, changing set and seeing new stats.
-I have really no idea what in this game make it be 20gb large.
-Game does little to introduce players who are new to the difficult character creating and developemtn system. [there is good help&tips in the menu if you can spend a moment to read and understand it]
-Not involving plot and shallow characters.
-Not intuitive UI.
-No crafting system.

(Merits)
+Realistic when it comes to weapons and armors. Armors comes in sets, so it is no longer find best pieces, but you need to wear a complete set of armor to have best benefits. And I like it that way.
+Deep and difficult tactical combat. I like the games that are not easy.
+Quick cities exploration.
+You are not limited when crafting your heros, you have a lot of freedom in systems without classes.

Overall I would give this game 7/10.
I hope most of the flaws will be corrected in the upcomming Blackguards 2.

reviewText:
The battles are really drawn out with a high RNG probability of reduced damage, missed shots, dodges, blocks.  Can take several turns just to do a few damage to a target with as much HP as you.

Battles are made difficult by swamping you with enemies, given the drawn out nature of tying to do any damage to enemies this can lead to really long, fustrating fights.

It is difficult, which is a good thing, but difficult because of the RNG system and the fact that you will be outnumbered several times over or forced to do multiple fights with no chance to rest.  Healing potions and mana potions are over priced.  Weapons are over priced and there is little variety.  Armor is so over priced i assume you need to go back to some of the starting towns once you are deep in game to afford nominal upgrades.

Basically its 3 of you vs 5-20 enemies of equal strength.  Majority of combat is spent whiffing shots, fizzling magic, and doing low to no damage.  RNG tends to ensure that vital heal on a tank fizzles several times in a row.  One lost character is losing the battle in the end, have fun restarting that 40minuet drawn out battle.

Its not an awful game, just a huige missed oppertuinty.  Buy only when heavily discounted if you LOVE difficult TBS combat.  Its got a very linear story with arraged battles, story is meh.

reviewText:
I wasn't sure what to review this game, but I thought a thumbs down would get the attention this comment merits as an OG gamer.  The biggest problem is that the harder settings make experience points go down and the mission harder...  breaking the standard expectation of harder missions and more experience that I wanted.  I don't want to go through on uber hard mode and end up with a nerfed character.

I suppose the other problem, and if you're thinking balancing trouble is the deal with the criticism, I know, I've thought of that, the problem is that you're pigeon holed into one kind of min/max or maybe two if you want to beat the game on hard.  This, to me, is not acceptable, lol.

But, also, not that the difficulty setting thing means that, when you finally have to switch back to normal to kill the gators with your incorrectly min/maxed character build, you might have to make the disgusting decision to set it to easy...  which I know a lot of gamers like me just cannot fathom, lol.

I suppose this brings me to another failure of modern gaming...  it's not like and can grind out another level in the middle of the story, which I would love to do rather than abandon my character... but why nerf my powers when I have it on hard, really...

reviewText:
If you are looking for a solid challenging turn-based tactical RPG, loving to prepare carefully before each battle, enjoying conquering seemly uncontrollable RNG madness, you probably will like Blackguards.

Otherwise, if you're not hardcore enough, you might will hate this game a lot due to its difficulty and unfriendliness against causal gamers. You have been warned.

Pros:
storyline
soundtrack
spells
character development (mechanics)
depth of the combat system

Cons:

reviewText:
The ap and loot system feels more like living real life as a poor person oppressed by over priced rent, wishing he could buy steak at the grocery store only able to eventually afford the spam.. But only after he spends a few more days cleaning urinals. The limited amount of story line options in general make this a lack luster experience for a RPG, as its pretty much linear. For a tablet game, playing this while traveling on a plane, would be a decent experience, for a pc game it serves to make me want to go back outside and spend time in the real world despite trying to escape from it for a moment.

I do continue to play it, and yell words I dont want my mother to hear when I miss 95% chance to hits over and over while the archers on the enemy side hit with 5% chances. Reminds me of my childhood when I played ninja gaiden and swore the game cheated hahah.

All that said, once you get across the border, things get a little more interesting and slightly more free.

IF you can find this game on a deep sale, and love this sorta play style youll find it is an easy game to fill the void between what ever else you are doing with your life.

reviewText:
I put 84 hours into it and quit with the end in sight.  I love turn based combat, and that kept me going in the linear game.  Combat became more about figuring out the trick to the map, rather than strategic play.  It sadly be came tedious.
You only get a clean slate on your own character, and because the way the trainers are laid out you can’t develop your character the way you want, his all ties into the game being very linear.
You can’t rotate the camera expect on one axis, which makes some fights awkward.
Shield only helps per parry you get, so shields are not that great.
Never once saw the point in disarming traps, but spotting them was very important.
NPC you build into your party come and go, to me when I specialize a party it is crippling to lose one of its team members.
I wanted to love it.  It is a good looking game.  I like the character development, except the trainer availability.
voteText: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I have, so far, enjoyed this game. The mechanics are solid, and I've always been a fan this style of turn based strategy/RPG games.

I haven't gotten far enough along to really dig into the story, or develop my characters much, but that's not due to a lack of interest.

The problem that I'm having is that this game crashes pretty frequently. I don't think it's my computer causing it, but I could be wrong about that.

If, and when, any stability issues have been worked out, either by the developer, or by me, I will change my recommendation to yes.

As of right now, I don't know many people that would be willing to restart their computers to advance the plot for 45 minutes or so before restarting again.
voteText: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Graphics:  4/10
Sound/dialog:  6/10 (Characters say some really dumb things)
Gameplay:  3/10    (CHANCE BASED COMBAT SUUUUUUCKS)
Performance:  Just pathetic (choppy and very low framerate no matter what quality on any system)

Chance based combat is the single biggest pile of garbage you could hand an RPG player.  This isn't RPG so much as digital slot machine with swords and spells, don't play it if you're a prone gambler because it'll trigger you.

FOR EXAMPLE:  The mage...

Your AOE attacks, the whole reason for having a mage present (because single target spells are far weaker than ranged weapons) only ever has a 45% chance of casting.  At All.

You can't rely on ANY actions from ANY of your characters once you factor in dodge/block/parry because EVERYTHING is just as likely to fail as it is hit.  EVEN HEALING.

Nailed-to-the-floor linear with no chance to do random battles and level up - even levelling is on rails, rails of garbage that can derail your team-train.  I'm on my third dead-end playthrough at 3 hours because I keep hitting dead ends without proper abilities.

Bought thinking 'Awesome, a final fantasy tactics type thing!'  Instead I got crap gameplay and gambler's rage.

reviewText:
Pros:
*Interesting system mechanics, with a LOT of depth to advancement.

Cons:
*Tutorial and Tips are useless.  I had been playing for over 2 hours (8+ combat missions) before I got a couple of the tips on how to do basic things.
*Horrible camera system.  Unable to rotate the camera, forcing you to revert to top down view in many areas just to be able to see the hex map behind objects/allies/enemies.
*No resource regeneration out of combat.  You can camp to restore Health and Astral points, which isn't bad, but when you hit one of the first major fight areas, you are prevented from camping.  You are forced to use town healers to restore HP out of combat, even if you have 2 mages with healing in your party.  No Astral Point (mana) regeneration outside of combat, even with talents that grant passive Astral Regen per turn, forcing you to use your very expensive Astral Potions to be able to actually use a mage character.
*Treating injuries with bandages has a chance to fail (very high chance) outside of combat, and almost useless to try in combat (6% chance of success at first rank).
*You are forced to buy belts to be able to carry many items into combat with you, but you are encumbered in combat by ALL the equipment in your bags, even you quest items and camping resources.
*Almost no income, with horribly high priced item.  At one point, you are given a large amount of money and told to go to the armorer to get equiped to help defend a town.  The armorer has 1 type of armor, 2 sets of it, and you are given enough to buy 1 piece of equipment.  Not a set, 1 piece.  You have to choose between upgrading a single piece of heavy armor, or to buy Astral and Health potions.
*Horrible UI.  Almost no explanations as to what means what, or as to how anything is calculated.  When comparing armor pieces, it does not compare piece to piece, only how it will change your whole, and armor/encumbrance always shows a penalty, even if it is an upgrade.
*Horrible combat encounter design.  In many of the fights, all of the mobs will sit back throwing poisoned javelines at you, each of which hits your heavily armored character for 15-30% of his total HP, and also poisons him.  Was forced to use the fighter as a tank, both of my mages as pure healers, while slowly grinding down the mobs hp with my archer (arrows cost a lot, and have weight.  I overmaxed my encumbrance just from provisions, which you need to camp, and arrows alone).
*Buff, healing and utility spells have default fail chance, which until you pick of a very very expensive talent, are almost impossible to cast (22% fail chance to heal an ally, 68% chance to fail to dispel a poison with a spell that only dispels poisons, 48% chance to fail to cast a wall" spell
date: etc).  Combined with no innate astral regen
recommended: very low astral point pool and high astral point cost to cast makes playing a mage character feel like your being penalized for playing the game."
hoursPlayed: April 15, 2014

reviewText:
Want to smash your monitor? than buy this game.

if you have any range of spells they'll fail more often than not, also the percentage that it gives you as you casting chance means nothing, a 70% casting chance but it will fail four out of five times. rage quits everytime, especially when you get hard missions and your success is completely based on luck not tactics.

so i restarted the whole game (because you have to max 3 specific stats just to make one spell actually work) and made a character that could cast 2 spells. how quickly does that get repetitive.

you can't go and level your characters, there are no optional quests because the apparently optional ones are nessesary for you to get xp. it takes for ever to actually level enough to make it worth it to attempt casting a 3rd spell.

i love rpg and turn based because it is about tactics not button mashing but the messed up casting just makes it all about non existant luck.

reviewText:
I wanted to like this game. I was really, really optimistic. And, if I'm fair, I probably have myself to blame for believing the game description and getting my hopes up. But no, I ended up loathing the game to such an extent that when the last chapter of the story was released I didn't even WANT to find out how the story ended.

My main problems are with the story and the combat, which considering how the game bills itself is unforgivable. Both are shallow, boring and slow, which is in no way helped by a quest system and map that seem to conspire to drag things out even more.

I will say that the game could be challenging in interesting ways at times.

Honestly, if I could refund this game I would do it in a heartbeat.

reviewText:
Turn based combat system? Yes please!

One thing I appreciate about the game is that so far I haven't encountered any battles that felt repetitive. The maps, the environments, interactive elements on the maps (starting fires ftw!), and the variety of opponents have kept it fresh so far. Of course I need to state that I'm only on Chapter 2 at this point, so maybe that changes. Some battles have been easy enough, others have been challenging. There's been a few battles that I've had to retry but it's been a fun challenge, not a drain on my enjoyment of the game.

So far, I'm loving this game and have been looking forward to playing it as time permits. I started over 6 hours into the game to switch from a basic character to an expert (custom) character. Having become more familiar with the game, I wanted to be able to customize my character more. I'm 20+ hours into this game and I'm still enjoying it which is a positive sign!
voteText: 12 of 27 people (44%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Blackguard is difficult. Blackguard is long. Blackguard is fun.
The game forces you to utilize your envirounment on the maps of the different battles you will fight. The Mano a mano approach often leads to defeat or severe injurie. There's a lot of thinking, planning and retrying involved (when a strategy doesn't pan out), especially since you can only save before and after a battle, not during it. It's great though, makes the feeling of accomplishment that much stronger once you beat a battle while achieving all optional goals.
The length of the game is very refreshing. 40 hours can very well be exceeded, depending on how often you fail ;)
All said and donde, Blackguard is a real treat for all fans of tactical round based gaming. The story is kind of nice, but the gameplay is what kept me glued to this game for hours since I started.

reviewText: Calling this a tactical RPG is insult to all the real Tactics games that came before it.  The combat is from Heroes of Might and Magic.  Flat hex map walk towards each other and swing, over and over.  90% of the skills are useless (spend points on being able to see the hit chance of the guy I'm swinging at anyway, or spend points on +1 to hit), and the 3d20 skill system may be novel for the RPG this is based on but here it is just opaque and weird.   Going straight from battle to battle is actually a good thing, so don't fault it for not being the JRPG it is not.  But boring battles and boring equipment and boring skills in a Tactics game is a bad thing.  I'm going to go play Disgaea to wash out my brain.

reviewText: I want to start off by saying that despite its many apparent flaws there is something that I find deeply compelling about this game.  The battle system is pretty good, you have quite a few options during combat and the interactive battlefields add a layer of fun and somewhat fresh gameplay.\n\nMy primary gripe with Blackguards is the difficulty.  To say that Blackguards is a challenging game is an understatement, but I feel that the way that Blackguards challenges you is a bit contrived and ultimately kind of cheap.  I've played difficult games in which I've lost or barely won a battle and have walked away thinking wow that was a good fight".  In Black Guards if I lose I usually feel like I've been robbed.  You constantly miss spells and attacks and the enemy constantly connects whether you're fighting a semi-♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ goblin
date: a backstabbing rogue or a giant tree.  And the dire situations that you are placed in again and again suggest to me that you're not so much a group of badasses so much as you are really gullible and kind of incompetent.    The main character feels really generic.  Pretty much everyone or everything that you encounter seems better suited for combat than the protaganist.  And so far I don't feel like the four playable characters that I have encountered live up to the name Blackguards.  They actually seem like relatively nice guys.  When I saw the name Blackguards I got excited because I had assumed that I would be taking on the roles of the Lannisters from GOT.  Instead it feels more like I've signed on with the Partridge family.  I've only  played a few hours so far and I'm not giving up on the game entirely just yet
recommended: but that's mostly because of the price tag.  This is not a 40 dollar game and I would not recommend that anyone pay that much to play this.\n\nI work as a merchant sailor and I am literally stuck on a boat for the next month so I will be playing on.  If I get to a point in the gameplay in which I feel that my assesment was premature or unfair I will return to humbly apologize and I sincerely hope that
hoursPlayed: that happens."

reviewText:
A non-biased quick look @ the game:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TrU3b1p3oQ8

What happens when the only hope of a threatened world lies not with heroes in shining armor, but in the hands of a band of misfits and criminals? Blackguards, a new turn-based strategy RPG, explores this very question. You will discover over 180 unique hex-based battlegrounds within a dark and mature story of crime, drugs, and murder.

Play as a warrior, mage or hunter and customize your character's skills as you see fit. The challenging campaign delivers a story of doubt, treason and loss. You decide the course of the story at key turning points and determine its outcome. - Recommended!

reviewText:
i regret buying the game at 50% off . I enjoyed the first chapter then it got a bit tedious , it seemed a game designed to make sure you had no fun. I love turn based tactical games and i dont think i've ever played one i didnt enjoy before.

character develpoment and advancemet is dreadful , worst of any RPG or CRPG i've ever played , It's so boring and mundane. There's an illusion of freedom but really you just stick to a few skills and spells that are clearly miles better , if you dont you end up with useless underpowered skills and characters.

I think i am still using the same 1 skill with my melee and archer characters 10 hours into the game and the same 2 spells on my casters. There's just not enough variety to the game. In another 10 hours i probably be using the same 2 skills. Thats not enough depth for a tactical game or an RPG.

As an RPG it is without doubt poor but i expected that and assumed the tactical combat would make up for it , it didnt , the combat was worse than i expected and that is the reason i eventually got bored of clicking the same 2 buttons and stopped playing

reviewText:
The term tensile RPG was once a very common and well-known, but in recent years, these games almost completely disappeared from the gaming scene. This year is fortunately again fruitful for this style and is experiencing a minor revival. How, then turned one such RPG from relatively unknown Daedalic Entertainment?

Right at the beginning, after selecting a new game in the menu, the player can choose either the simplified selection of attributes, or expert, according as it is familiar with the style board game The Dark Eye. In the selection of the division are three different professions, namely Warrior, Magician and Hunter. In addition, it is possible to choose from several preset face and sex. Already here, I have to criticize that particular types of female faces look sometimes very belligerent manner and at the same time from each other and a little different. Overall graphics page, especially dealing with details of the figure was weaker.

The second setting, ie expert player allows much more extensive treatment of the characters and follow the rules of points. Basically, a player has a choice to 10,000 points, labeled BD from which you can then has any assembly dream champion. At the outset, it must pay 500 if you want to have a magical character. After this selection opens a few talent trees, which can be additionally porozdeľovať points to a maximum of up to 14 properties, the talents and spells 8. However, while playing and later acquire new levels of these attributes can continue to accrue. Points can be reallocated in several areas, namely core values, Fighting talent, talents, spells, and finally special skills. It is important to all of these points divided as effectively as possible, because after creating new characters and the plot itself enters into all the remaining points are canceled.

The core values are called major modifiers in creating characters, namely strength, charisma etc., these in turn affect many elements such as the capacity of heroes, the number of lives, or the ability to communicate with the outside world and the characters in it. Between fighting talent then there are various weapons from daggers, crossbows over, after two-handed swords. By investing points into the player's weapons of course increases the attack or the defense of a given type of weapon, depending on how it is set. Among the talent is also possible to choose from nine different talents. For example, the ability of the trap, which allows the player to identify, considered, or even defuse traps or Ranhojičstvo, which in turn allows the player to heal from injuries. We walk the kids, which are of course only applicable if a player chooses a character magician. Spells are divided between the offensive and strengthening and debilitating. Found them quite a decent amount of fans and fiery, respectively. ice magic school here will surely enjoy. Finally, we get the special abilities, which are different upgrades for close combat, ranged or magic, or even passive abilities.

Edit character is indeed fairly complex and enthusiasts making such tailor-made nature of certain very pleased. Conversely, players who want to jump into the story as soon as possible to be able to circumvent these adjustments using automatic reallocation of points in the selection of the games.

Whether a player chooses to basic or expert mode, after completion of the selection starts intro and the player is familiar with the mysterious death of Princess Elanor. Here are gradually unveiled on different battle tactics such as moving figures after hexagonal boxes, or attacking. However, the main protagonists are caught in a stationary body guards pathetic Princess and cast him into prison. The initial steps of the story thus seek out of this place and the run will help the player and other figures rough dwarf Naurima and individually mage Zurbaran. Later, therefore, the player will control the widening of the characters, and it is therefore important to learn the capabilities and advantages make the most of the fight.

It should be noted that the combat encounters tend to be really hard sometimes, or vice versa, sometimes very simple. At times it can be unpredictable for the game, which depends on various calculations, attack, defense, and to recover the attack power of intervention, and the like. Another element is the very place where the fight takes place. You should be commended on one side of the creators, because these so-called arenas are interactive and can be, for example, to hide his magician for any obstacle from enemies and calmly zosielať healing spells at his comrades, or even drop, for example luster on unsuspecting opponents. On the other hand, sometimes these interactive game environment, they can do very easily, so will everyone else struggle and it's up to the player as will be careful to monitor the area in which the fight takes place and whether it will be able to benefit or not.

After deliverance from prison pending player main story line, which is of course finding a clarification of the death of the Princess, in which the main character was involved already. Later, however, the procedure of the story in five different chapters player looks at different places of the world and in addition to the main storyline is of course possible to perform a secondary task, which can be obtained, for example, also visited cities around the world.

As regards the visual side of the game is not any graphical champion, but what should be on-screen instructions, it handles. The environments are quite varied and dark stomp the player gets to the green meadows, respectively. in different forests or cities. After zooming in, however, and examining the details of the characters come often unpleasant experience, which is especially noticeable when prestrihových animation. The game simply can not cope with these details, but I must say that in this type of RPG is not a graphics page and so important.

Audio is contrary to the relatively high level of quality musical accompaniment and a good dubbing. The only thing you can criticize the common neprecítenie some situations Daberas (initial torture when choosing a female protagonist in the prison).

Blackguards is certainly an interesting title and if you're a fan of tensile RPG, or even know the style of the game The Dark Eye, you will not be disappointed. For other players, the game offers many hours of tasks in an interesting world where the most important temporize and think through each move before the player how to fix it. Playing on the other hand suffers quick repetetívnosťou and certainly not for hotheads who like to do so and then they think. Through it all, however Blackguards among the titles above average and certainly have their supporters and fans found.

reviewText:
Highly recommended for fans of turn-based fantasy and role-playing games in general.

Pros: The adventure system is a welcome relief from wandering around huge towns of useless NPCs. It's similar to point-and-click adventures of old. Let's you get to the story and/or combat quickly.

Cool level-up system. Characters really start to feel powerful at later levels.

Attractive graphics and runs smoothly.

Neat battle set-ups. Battles have traps, special objectives, secrets, and ambushes. There are a good number of straight up fights, but the set piece battles really spice things up.

Interesting (but not completely original) story with an compelling (but really not original) cast. It keeps you interested enough to follow along rather than just clicking through the dialogs, and the cut-scenes are simple but well done.

Cons: I strongly recommend starting on Easy" difficultly. This really feels like it should be the default and is best for first-time players. The mechanics of the game are a little obscure
date: and having one play-through under your belt is best. Easy offers a good challenge without being frustrating
recommended: and gives you freedom to explore the game.\n\nAgain

reviewText:
Blackguards is great. Based on The Dark Eye setting and tabletop roleplaying game rules this game really captures those rules and lets them shine in a way previous real-time titles have not. The turn based nature of the combat system in the game really lets you see the benifit of the various different builds of characters where in a realtime combat game such as Drakensang based off of the same rule set does not.

The plot is engaging, lengthy, and at times really does feel like a transcript of a tabletop campaign, which is great for someone who maybe used to tabletop and just doesnt have the time to, or doesnt get the opportunity to as often as they would like.

All things said, I paid full price for the game, and don't think I spent even a penny more than the game was worth.

reviewText:
Blackguards is a turn-based strategy game with strong RPG elements, rather like XCOM but with a much greater variety of character customization. (Though it has a reasonable story, you might be disappointed if you're looking for an RPG. It isn't open world, there aren't many meaningful story choices for you to make, and there isn't much customization available for your character's appearance.)

The campaign is reasonably long, though the game doesn't feel repetitive thanks to reasonably varied fight scenarios and win-conditions. Early problems with bugged quests and translation issues from the original German seem mostly resolved at this point (I only noticed some spelling errors in the English version and had no problems with bugged quests.)

Common complaints about the game focus on numerous loading screens and an unintuitive UI. I found the UI fairly easy to pick up myself, only issuing incorrect commands once or twice. Though there are a lot of loading screens between scenarios, each one lasted only 1-3 seconds for me so they didn't detract from my experience. People playing on systems using HDDs rather than SSDs may find the loading screens take longer and so are more annoying, though.

I was worried by the relatively low Metacritic score for this game, but I'm glad I wasn't deterred. If you like single-player, turn-based strategy games that put you in control of a small group of specialized combatants, you'll probably like this.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
In a nut-shell, you'' definetely like Blackguards if you are into turn-based, hex-based linear tactical RPGs. For one, i do!
The combat is nicely done and obviously the strong point of the game - it works, and keeps you challenged (at least, up to now).
The graphics are nice, but a little too cartoon-ish for my taste (and for the atmosphere the game tries to create).
The story is good enough to carry you from chapter to chapter, although it's a little obvious in its twists.

There are obviously a few cons as well:
- The biggest minus for me it's the inventory, and the way it works. You don't get a clear comparison between your equipped item and another one, in your pack or at a vendor - this alone makes choosing weapons a nuisance at later stages. The inventory also becomes cluttered extremely easy.
- Also a minus is the auto saving system. The game makes it that, quite a few times, you have to fight battle after battle, without possibility of resting&healing. And the autosave saves as you enter a new battle. This means that, if you don't take extra care, you'll end up (it happened to me once) in a position i hate most in RPGs - making some bad decisions in a 3rd-in-a-row battle, i had no chance of winning the 4th. And the autosave was only for the 4th. So i had to restart not only the 3 battles before, but the whole branch of the chapter (a lot of dialogue and cinematics included) - and i hate remaking choices i already made, listening to the same lines over and over again etc. They should have made an auto save for each battle, and an autosave for entering a chain of events/battles - this way, you can restart the fights without restarting the story itself.

Anyway, all in all, is a nice game (and i bought it during a sale) - so i give it 7.5/10.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: I'm really enjoying this game, even in early-access. It still needs some polish, but it is very impressive at its current stage. The characters, while not very deep during Chapter 1 (only chapter available yet, of 5), are still very fun and you get a good sense of their personalities through their dialogue and opinions on the situations. I see a lot of potential with this game. The combat can be a little shallow at the moment, ending up with just moving across the battlefields and attacking/healing as necessary, but I also have not acquired many of the bountiful skills available. Plenty of skills available, but the game does not hold your hand; acquiring and saving the necessary points is definitely part of the challenge and not unwelcome. While it definitely isn't paced to have you being dragonslayers within the first few hours, it isn't overly difficult either. A few battles required multiple tries from me, but only because I was trying to reach bonus objectives in the alloted time. I've burnt through other SRPGs and got bored within the first few hours of playing, but this game has just enough flavor and interest to keep me coming back to the well for more. It is not a AAA title by any means, but an impressive soundtrack, very believable voice-acting and dialogue, and earnest, hard work prove to be more than any flash and bang a mainstream title would use. Once again, very impressed with the quality of this product. I am in it for the longhaul now, and very interested to see where this (and possible future titles) go. Bravo.

reviewText:
Why do I keep buying games that use the TDE (Dark Eye) game rules?  They're ALWAYS ♥♥♥♥.  ALWAYS.   Demonicon?  ♥♥♥♥.  Drakensang?  ♥♥♥♥.  Drakensang 2? ♥♥♥♥.  This game?  ♥♥♥♥.   Whatever positives this turnbased rpg has, they're completely negated by the unrelenting terribleness of TDE as game rules.

If you have no idea what I'm ranting about, imagine picking up Baldur's Gate 2 without ever playing D&D 2nd ed before.   What armor class is better?  What's a save vs. death compared to a save vs. spell?   Multiply all that by 3000x.  That's The Dark Eye.

It was made by Germans who hate you.   And that's why.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Pros
genre is underrepresented
No game breaking bugs
Significant protag customization
Interesting crapsack world
Portraits, mesh, and texturing is fairly decent
Voice acting is competent
Gave a moderate sense of player choices' mattering on first playthrough

Cons
Balance is poorly implimented in virtually every aspect of the game, from weapon and spell utility and encounter design, to difficulty curve, and pervasively undercuts every aspect of the gameplay
Mechanics are vastly overcomplicated, convoluted, and poorly explained.  VERY POORLY EXPLAINED.
Animation is very basic

After I got over the needlessly high learning curve by experimenting with several builds, restarting the game a few times when they proved extremely frustrating to play, then reading several character build faqs, I discovered hamfisted, though not completely fruitless, neutral dark storytelling and moderately enjoyable, if one note, TBS gameplay.  Having finished the game I can conclusively say this is a game ONLY for extremely dedicated, veteran fans of the genre who are tolerant of some pretty serious lack of polish.  If you are such a person (and unfortunately since I completed it I was) you may consider this game a frustrating but sometimes enjoyable exercise of the TBS muscles.

If you are such a person (and unfortunately since I completed it I was) you may consider this game a frustrating but sometimes enjoyable exercise of the TBS muscles.

reviewText:
After playing the game for ten hours I can see why it has such mixed reviews. I wouldn't recommend it based off of my standards for games but others might still find it enjoyable.

Cons
Terrible story ( Confusing, presents a lot of questions but gives few answers. Main character seems like a loser)
Flat characters, characters seem to blurt out whatever is in their head instead of talking to each other
Plot twists are in poor taste (They come of as 'we did this to you because we can')
Somewhat steep learning curve when it comes to training your characters
Weapon system seems biased in the sense that there is little to no benefit to pick x over y in any scenerio
Game consistantly pushes you back to square one by taking your gear/characters away from you and forcing you to fight at a severe disadvantage

Pros
Characters are customizable in their fighting style, although non mages have a limited non passive special talent selection.
Difficult (although for the wrong reasons imo)
Tactical turnbased game
Bug free from what I have seen.

If you are a diehard fan of tactical turn based games and do not care about story elements then this game might interest you. I would recommend watching youtube videos first before committing or wait for it to go on sale.

Overall rating 6/10

reviewText: Just so much failure in this game. I really wanted to like it, but it just does so many things just wrong. Everything is ridiculously expensive, there is zero immersion. For example my guys all have crappy torches, and we have had crappy torches for well over an hour, killing guys with axes and swords. When we defeat said guys, you'd think we get a sword right? NOP! Still stuck with the crappy torches! And still can't afford 1 crappy hand axe, which the game seems to value at 13 gold! These developers are clueless at both medieval history and game balance (a hand axe would NEVER cost anywhere that much) !  Oh, and then the game wants to kill gigantic troll with your crap weapons! It's like the game is trolling you! I didn't even mention that almost everything to do in this game can just fail as it does nothing and waste your turn. It seems the way the developers want you to  get through this game is to save scum your way through, just hope you hit the all the monsters all the time and load if you don't! How fun!  This game is just a package of false promises that ends in dashed hopes and shame; just stay away.

reviewText:
Everything that can be wrong about this game is wrong.

The mechanics are broken (IE you get 1 parry a turn except for when you dont, that guy who has parried 3 attacks already, well your 100% to hit which you should never even have got because a 20 is a crit fail, he parried it because he also rolled a 20 on his parry roll, 4th parry out of the 1 he has per round),
They are also counter intuitive (fairly normal for a D&D clone),
And outright stupid (Why do shields give no bonus at all?  Why can you only switch your melee skill between offensive and defensive outside of battle, why does changing it make no difference?  Why can I get 100%s to hit when 19-20/20 is always a crit fail? etc.),
Random to an excessive level (Nothing you do means anything.  Your completely non melee focused mage can work better as a tank than your completely tank focused sword and board char.  Your spell which does 8-18 dmg (firebolt 2) actually rolls for between 3 and 27, before factoring in resists/weaknesses)
On top of that, the AI cheats (They get 100%s to hit fairly regularly, they can parry a seemingly infinite amount of times, they parry your 95%s to hit about 95% of the time, they still maintain accuracy despite having every possible debuff put on them, they get access to things like potions in fights where it is explicitly stated no one has them, they succeed/fail skill checks in a completely disproportionate amount to thier displayed chances of success (etc)),
The story is both unoriginal and bland,
The world is completely nonsensical, you can walk across what is described as a Vast empire" and back in less than a day

reviewText:
I played till the end and it wasn't a bad trip, but there are some points that annoyed me.
Broken achievements the most.
I'm a achievement hunter and this games is so full of bugs concerning achievements it made me crazy. (20% !!)
You just can't get them.

Some achievement don't even make sense!! Why would I upgrade every spell to 10?! Why not 8 where you get to the next level of the spell?! Getting all spells up to 10 is a HUGE waste of EP!?
Same with teaching a character all weapon types. Why would I do that?! That's just stupid!
Why would I upgrade character specifics that are only good for a mage or a warrior?

Second, is there really much of alterning the storyline? Because they tried to act like it but it seems to me that is rubbish.
Fighting system was fun and okay, but it is true that there should have been a little bit more variety of enemies and also goals.

The story... well, could have been better. A bit confusing and in the end I don't really know what we needed that big word we searched so long for... what ever.

I bought the game cheap and I would do it again, but don't buy it for the regular price, it isn't that good.

reviewText:
It's just... bad.  The visuals are average, with bits of them bordering on terrible.  The story and exploration are linear, and the story itself is just plain boring.  The voice-work is just good enough to point out how comically bad it is.  Towns are bland and lifeless.  Combat is stagnant, and shows no complexity.  Even if you buy Blackguards on sale, you likely still won't find the time to sit down with it.  There just isn't any single thing exciting enough to make up for the blandness of the rest of the game.  Nothing to draw you back in, after the first time you've played.

It's well done from a mechanical standpoint - The skill trees are well thought out and balanced.  There's just nothing flashy in them to draw attention, and the execution becomes poor when you see your character dully performing their moves and abilities with passable graphics and poor weapons/equipment.  Blackguards is a pen-and-paper RPG adaptation that never really got past the pen-and-paper bit.  More of a visualisation of some DM's real-world tabletop setup that would seem much cooler set up with cardboard on your buddy's gaming table.

If you're hellbent on playing Blackguards, I hear Blackguards 2 is actually worth the time.  It's on my list of 'soon to play' games, so I'll put up a review ASAP.
